activities.subject: Exclusive Invitation to Participate in XYZ's climate Interview
activities.body:
Dear Janet,​

Over the past 24 years of working with organizations like yours, we have learned the impact internal and external climates have on our clients doing the work to support inclusion within their organizations. These past few years have truly been filled with change, directional shifts, and future uncertainty. We understand the importance of being a true partner and are excited to announce our exclusive initiative to support our stakeholders by conducting a comprehensive climate interview and survey. The goal of the survey will be to assess how the mindsets and systems within organizations have influenced organizational climate over the past few years and impacted inclusive workplaces. The information we collect from the interview and survey will be treated with utmost confidentiality and the key takeaways will be shared with all selected participants. Based on the key takeaways, we will be sharing relevant resources, developing new content, providing action steps, and offering opportunities to learn and collaborate with peers. 

Please select the time that works best for a 30-minute interview: <URL>

Thank you for considering this opportunity. We look forward to your participation and serving as a continued resource to you and your organization.

activities.subject: Commemorating Juneteenth & Its Legacy
activities.body:
Dear Janet,​

Many employers are planning to recognize <LOCATION> this year to celebrate this significant date in <NRP> history. 

<LOCATION>, a federal holiday celebrated annually on June 19th, marks the completion of emancipation of enslaved <NRP> in <LOCATION>, and symbolizes freedom, resilience, and the ongoing struggle for equality.

We believe that it's crucial to take the opportunity to reflect, learn, and engage in meaningful conversations about <LOCATION> and its importance to our employees and clients. To help you facilitate this dialogue, we have developed a one-hour session on this topic.

Our virtual workshop, Understanding <LOCATION> and Its Legacy, has the following objectives:
Explore <LOCATION>’s historical context, its significance in <NRP> history, and how it has evolved over time. Understand how many organizations have historically exploited the holiday. Explore ways in which individuals and organizations can commit to supporting and advocating for <NRP> communities beyond designated months or holidays. We also invite you to sample our “Commemorating Juneteenth” microlearning via this link: <URL> It will remain open and available for you until May 31st. Just enter your email address and name, and you’ll get access.

Understanding the roots of this holiday and its lasting impact is an important element for fostering empathy, awareness, and inclusion. Bringing colleagues together to engage in this opportunity to learn about history and progress has a positive impact in the workplace.

If you’re interested or have any questions, please reply to this email and we can set up a meeting.

activities.subject: REGISTER FOR FREE PREVIEW: Spotlights on the <NRP> & Jewish Communities in the <LOCATION>
activities.body:
Hi Janet,​

As part of our ongoing commitment to fostering cultural understanding and promoting inclusion, we’re excited to announce an upcoming no-cost session previewing our two new programs: "Spotlight on the Jewish Community in the <LOCATION>" and "Spotlight on the Muslim Community in the <LOCATION>." The preview will take place on May 29th, 2024 from 2-3pm ET / 1-2pm CT. 

These two additions to our Spotlights library were carefully designed and vetted by interculturalists and culture-expert members of the <NRP> and <NRP> community. Facilitated by two cross-cultural expert facilitators (one a member of the community and one ally), the Spotlights provide participants with valuable insights into the histories, values, experiences, and influences that shape each of these distinct cultures, and deliver an insightful and nuanced understanding of the <NRP> and <NRP> experiences in <LOCATION> - dispelling misconceptions and fostering empathy. These sessions do not explain or resolve current geopolitical events, do not advocate particular points of view or debate history, and like all of our Spotlights, aim to build cultural competence and understanding. 

The Spotlights helps participants: 
Explore factors that have shaped the lived experiences and cultural values of the community in the <LOCATION>, including shared experiences and common influences. Recognize the depth and diversity of the community in the <LOCATION> Discuss historical and contemporary prejudice against the community. Explore strategies to support and be an ally to your colleagues and the community at large. In our preview we’ll demonstrate sample content from both Spotlights, show you the agenda for each, and answer your questions. 

REGISTER FOR THE SPOTLIGHTS PREVIEW:
Wednesday, May 29th, 2024 from 2-3pm ET / 1-2pm CT Register Here: <URL> 

We believe that these Spotlights can be valuable tools which, in conjunction with other elements of your DEI infrastructure, work towards de-polarization and enhancing participants’ ability to engage meaningfully with individuals from these backgrounds. 

We're looking forward to seeing you there!

activities.subject: Essential Guide to Dialogues about <LOCATION>-Palestine
activities.body:
Hi Janet,​

We know that world events impact us in many ways, and that we don’t stop being who we are when we to go to work. With the ongoing <LOCATION>-Palestine conflict, we thought it would be helpful to provide you with a structure and process for having this type of dialogue. We wanted to send you this Essential Guide to Dialogues about <LOCATION>-Palestine: wanted%20to%20send%20you%20a%20quick%20note%20to%20let%20you%20know%20that%20we%20know%20that%20many%20workplaces%20have%20been%20talking%20about%20and%20affected%20by%20the%20Israel-Palestine%20conflict.%20We%20also%20know%20that%20world%20events%20impact%20us%20in%20many%20ways,%20and%20that%20we%20don’t%20stop%20being%20who%20we%20are%20when%20we%20to%20go%20to%20work.%20In%20case%20you%20or%20any%20of%20your%20colleagues%20is%20interested%20in%20a%20structure%20and%20process%20for%20having%20this%20dialogue,%20I%20attach%20the%20recently%20published%20Essential%20Guide%20to%20Dialogues%20about%20Israel-Palestine,%20put%20out%20by%20the%20organization%20Essential%20Partners.%20%20It’s%20excellent.%20%20The%20bulk%20of%20this%20guide/resource%20is%20about%20how%20to%20set%20up%20such%20a%20dialogue%20–%20including:, put out by the organization Essential Partners: <URL> It’s excellent. 

The bulk of this guide/resource is about how to set up such a dialogue – including:
The difference between dialogue and debate The importance of communication agreements (some really good ones included – please see bottom of p. 6/top of p. 7) Logistics (how, where, what) Structures for reflection, speaking & listening (the Go-Round; the Intentional Pause; Reflect, Write, Respond) Preparing for the dialogue as a facilitator (lots of support provided!) Participant intervention tips (in-depth and valuable) A sample agenda Dialogue prompts (they offer a few sets of prompts, depending on what your audience and context is – please see the one on p. 20 which is designed for the purpose of ‘better understanding different perspectives’: This dialogue guide is a great complement to our two brand new workshops: Spotlight on the Muslim Community in the <LOCATION> and Spotlight on the Jewish Community in the <LOCATION> - one-hour interactive, deep-dive workshops are focused on the experience of being a member of these communities, and aim at highlighting their experiences, influences, values and rich cultures. 

☪️Spotlight on the Muslim Community (1-hr): Explores the complexities of being <NRP> in <LOCATION> and the simultaneously varied and shared experiences and worldviews of <LOCATION>’s <NRP> community. In this session, we unpack the concepts of culture versus religion and discuss current issues and events impacting the <NRP> experience and perspectives. Best practices for allyship and countering bias in the workplace will be shared. 

🔯Spotlight on the Jewish Community (1-hr): Introduces participants to key historical and social/cultural events that shape this community, as well as the cultural values and practices that influence the <NRP> experience. The session will also unpack stereotypes, debunk myths, and address antisemitism and its impact in the workplace today. We share best practices for supporting and providing allyship to our colleagues with the community, and how to counter antisemitic bias and microaggressions. 

If you’re interested in talking further about scheduling these vital learning opportunities, please reply to this email and we can set up a meeting.

activities.subject: Join XYZ as our guest at the DEIB Conference
activities.body:

Hope all is well! We wanted to take this opportunity to invite you to the annual Diversity Woman Media DEIB Conference: <URL> in <LOCATION> this July 23rd.

activities.subject: Introducing Our Enhanced Cross Cultural Learning Partner Program
activities.body:
Dear Janet,​

I hope this message finds you well. At XYZ, we are always striving to innovate and provide the most impactful solutions for fostering Diversity, Equity, and Inclusion within organizations. With that commitment in mind, we are excited to introduce our updated and elevated training program: The Cross Cultural Learning Partner (CCLP).

What makes our CCLP program stand out from traditional DEI training programs? It’s designed to offer a more personalized, in-depth, and continuous learning experience. Here’s how:
Collaborative Learning: Unlike typical trainings where participants learn individually, CCLP pairs each participant with a learning partner that is culturally different in a significant way. This partnership encourages mutual support and shared growth, making the learning process richer and more effective. The cultural differences between partners offer real, lived scenarios that can be explored through open communication. Extended Engagement: While most DEI sessions are limited to just a few hours, our CCLP program spans 6 to 12 months. This extended timeframe allows for a deeper exploration of cultural competencies, continuous learning, and the opportunity to apply and reflect on insights over time. Real-World Scenarios: CCLP moves beyond hypothetical situations by integrating your unique experiences into the training. This makes the learning more relevant and directly applicable to the challenges and opportunities within your organization. Measurable Growth: Understanding your progress is key to effective learning. CCLP includes pre- and post-assessments, enabling participants to track their development and gain clear insights into how much they’ve grown after the program. We believe that our CCLP program offers a transformative approach to DEI training, and we would love to explore how it can benefit your team or organization. If you’re interested in learning more or setting up a time to discuss further, please don’t hesitate to reach out.

activities.subject: Introducing Our Enhanced Cross Cultural Learning Partner Program
activities.body:
Hello Janet,​ 

I hope you're doing well. I wanted to follow up on my previous email regarding our Cross Cultural Learning Partner (CCLP) program, as I understand things can get busy. 

To quickly recap, the CCLP program is an innovative and personalized DEI training designed to foster deeper cultural understanding and sustained growth. The Intercultural Development Inventory (IDI) Assessment is a crucial tool within the CCLP program, helping participants not only identify where they are in terms of intercultural competence but also guiding them through the phases of development. Here's how it elevates the training experience: 
Understanding Key Developmental Phases: Throughout the program, participants will navigate various phases of intercultural development, progressing from a primarily monocultural perspective to a more inclusive intercultural viewpoint. This understanding is essential for fostering inclusive environments and navigating cultural differences effectively. Targeted Growth: By taking the IDI assessment at the beginning of the program, participants establish a clear baseline of where they currently stand in their intercultural development journey. We follow up with post IDI assessments as well conducted at the end of the program. This allows us to clearly measure the progress they've made, highlighting the growth in their ability to navigate and understand cultural differences more effectively over the 6-12 month program. We’d love to set up a time to discuss how the IDI assessment and the CCLP program can be implemented to meet your team’s needs. Please let me know what week works best, and I can send over some times to connect. 

Looking forward to your response.

activities.subject: REGISTER FOR FREE PREVIEW: Spotlights on the <NRP> & Jewish Communities in the <LOCATION>
activities.body:
Hi Janet,​

As part of our ongoing commitment to fostering cultural understanding and promoting inclusion, we’re excited to announce an upcoming no-cost session previewing our two new programs: " Spotlight on the Jewish Community in the <LOCATION>" and " Spotlight on the Muslim Community in the <LOCATION>." The preview will take place on May 29th, 2024 from 2-3pm ET / 1-2pm CT.

These two additions to our Spotlights library were carefully designed and vetted by interculturalists and culture-expert members of the <NRP> and <NRP> community. Facilitated by two cross-cultural expert facilitators (one a member of the community and one ally), the Spotlights provide participants with valuable insights into the histories, values, experiences, and influences that shape each of these distinct cultures, and deliver an insightful and nuanced understanding of the <NRP> and <NRP> experiences in <LOCATION> - dispelling misconceptions and fostering empathy. These sessions do not explain or resolve current geopolitical events, do not advocate particular points of view or debate history, and like all of our Spotlights, aim to build cultural competence and understanding.

The Spotlights helps participants:

  *   Explore factors that have shaped the lived experiences and cultural values of the community in the <LOCATION>, including shared experiences and common influences.
  *   Recognize the depth and diversity of the community in the <LOCATION>
  *   Discuss historical and contemporary prejudice against the community.
  *   Explore strategies to support and be an ally to your colleagues and the community at large.
In our preview we’ll demonstrate sample content from both Spotlights, show you the agenda for each, and answer your questions.

REGISTER FOR THE SPOTLIGHTS PREVIEW:
Wednesday, May 29th, 2024 from 2-3pm ET / 1-2pm CT Register Here<<URL>>

We believe that these Spotlights can be valuable tools which, in conjunction with other elements of your DEI infrastructure, work towards de-polarization and enhancing participants’ ability to engage meaningfully with individuals from these backgrounds.

We're looking forward to seeing you there!

activities.subject: Short, high-impact sessions on the <NRP> and the <NRP> Experiences in the <LOCATION>
activities.body:
Hi Janet,​

We’re thrilled to shared that we’re launching two brand new Spotlight sessions aimed at highlighting the experiences, influences, values and rich cultures of the <NRP> and <NRP> communities in the <LOCATION>

Our Spotlights are one-hour, interactive, deep-dive workshops are focused on the experience of being a member of these communities, and contribute to building cultural competence, inclusion skills, and a culture of belonging throughout your organization. 

☪️Spotlight on the Muslim Community (1-hr)
This session explores the complexities of being <NRP> in <LOCATION> and the simultaneously varied and shared experiences and worldviews of <LOCATION>’s <NRP> community. In this session, we unpack the concepts of culture versus religion and discuss current issues and events impacting the <NRP> experience and perspectives. Best practices for allyship and countering bias in the workplace will be shared. Session objectives:
Explore factors that have shaped the lived experiences and cultural values of the <NRP> community, including shared experiences and common influences Recognize the depth and diversity of the <NRP> community in the <LOCATION> Discuss <NRP> sentiment (especially since 9/11) and its impact on the <NRP> community Explore strategies to support and be an ally to your <NRP> colleagues and the community at large 
🔯Spotlight on the Jewish Community (1-hr)
This session introduces participants to key historical and social/cultural events that shape this community, as well as the cultural values and practices that influence the <NRP> experience. The session will also unpack stereotypes, debunk myths, and address antisemitism and its impact in the workplace today. We share best practices for supporting and providing allyship to our colleagues with the community, and how to counter antisemitic bias and microaggressions. Session objectives:
Explore factors that have shaped the lived experiences and cultural values of the <NRP> community, including shared experiences and common influences. Recognize the depth and diversity of the <NRP> community in the <LOCATION> Discuss the current state of Antisemitism and its impact on the <NRP> community. Explore strategies to support and be an ally to your <NRP> colleagues and the community at large. Below are one-pagers for each session, that you may share with your stakeholders. 

Other Spotlights that you may consider for 2024:
Being an Ally for the Asian American Community (May, AAPI Heritage Month) Spotlight on the LGBTQ+ Community (June, LGBTQ+ Pride Month) Spotlight on Persons with Disabilities (July, Disability Pride Month) Spotlight on U.S. Generations (April, August, December, anytime) Spotlight on the <NRP>/Latinx/e Community (September, Hispanic Heritage Month 9/15-10/15) Spotlight on Indigenous People in <LOCATION> (October, Indigenous Peoples’ Day or November, Native American Heritage Month) Spotlight on the U.S. Veterans Community (November, Veterans’ Day) If you have any questions and would like to connect, please let me what days work best and I’ll send over some times.

10/7/2024 CALL NOTESXYZ part: RP, <PERSON>, AlisaClient part: <PERSON>, <PERSON> – based in <LOCATION>, engagement strategy lead for <LOCATION>, responsible for our Pulse, monthly survey that includes LatAm, <LOCATION>, and US.Take all of our sentiment data from all surveys, we’ve been sending out monthly pulse surveys since 2019.Looking at this data and finding out what are the driving causes – we can see differences in how men and women responded but why are gaps in scores happening? What’s driving it from a gender perspective? In some cases there’s a wide gap.What actions can we take from there?I’ve pulled out over 200k comments, the data we already have.We have done focus groups in the past (as a result of 2021 survey results) but won’t be doing any more. We won’t be sharing any focus group data with XYZ, only the survey comments.We found that there were different expectations pre and post pandemic - before great resignation and after.<PERSON> studied the quantitative answers to questions (Likert scale scores), but we haven’t done as good a job with the sentiment analysis… we haven’t looked at the actual comments.We want you to look at all the comments since 2019. There are 70 questions in the global survey. Every month there’s an algorithm in our platform (Workday Peakon Employee Voice Pulse Survey) that sorts 5-7 questions people receive out of that pool of 70 <URL>e 200k comments is for <LOCATION> (<LOCATION>, <LOCATION>, and <LOCATION>) but we can focus on <LOCATION> only.  <PERSON>: We don’t want you to only look at comments that pertain to specific gender gaps that we found, we want you to look at all the data. What we want are general themes and trends and challenges, this is priority #1 (not necessarily just the ones where gender differences are pronounced).The data we’d send XYZ is organized in spreadsheets (70 of them) with columns by date, business unit, other criteria. There’s no gender column but some of the spreadsheets represent women and men. They don’t have a single cumulative report of all 200k comments. They will send us a sample spreadsheet, with maybe ten rows of info, so we can get a taste.  They’ve used “Power BI” (a platform that helps users analyze, visualize, and share data to make informed decisions, from Microsoft) to try to analyze the comments and have created some initiatives based on that, but it’s too high <URL>e Workday survey has 21 drivers (autonomy, engagement, environment, etc.):Each driver has sub-drivers, and each sub-driver has 1 or more survey questions associated with it.  For example, the environment driver has 3 sub drivers (Equipment with two survey questions, Collab Space with 1 question, and <LOCATION> with 1 question). Example: Screen shot from the Workday survey platform:<PERSON>: This analysis would inform our DEI Strategy. In Nov  we’re meeting with our geographic area leaders (haven’t scheduled the date yet, but it will be before Thanksgiving). We want to make sure that the people in each of our locations, <LOCATION>, <LOCATION>, HOU, <LOCATION>… all have a similar and consistent <PERSON> experience. What are our people saying about their experiences? So that we can focus on actions to improve inclusion and belonging. Right now we can‘t make sense of it or tell up from <URL><PERSON>: Women aren’t scoring as well as men in:·         career growth.·         people manager support·         business strategy·         workplace behaviors and governance·         work/life balance. <PERSON>: we also understand that sometimes respondents make answer comments about questions that are unrelated.Data are segmented by male and female. There’s been an ongoing battle to cut it by ethnicity and race – it’s been two years, and finally got them to OK cutting by Underrepresented Minority (URM) vs. <LOCATION>.·         ‘URM’ = <NRP> (over 50% at <LOCATION>), non-white.  “In <LOCATION> in the <LOCATION>, we define underrepresented minorities (URM) as anyone who self-identifies as: <NRP> or <LOCATION>, <NRP> or <NRP>, Black or <NRP>, <NRP> or <NRP>, Multiracial/Multiethnic, <NRP> or <NRP>, <LOCATION> or <NRP>, Non-URM includes: <LOCATION>”·         We have the data on race/ethnicity but hadn’t been pushing it into the Workday surveySurvey comments do not include URM’s. Eventually, would like to cut by underrepresented minority after this <URL>ope: Look at all the comments, give us trends in general (can’t drill down into other intersectional groups). Show leaders view of global/overall, and also by leader units. Have a clear understanding of the sentiments of the comments and how we can leverage them with action items.  Doesn’t matter what format you deliver the final report in – can be PPT, Excel, etc.

<PERSON> Notes8/20:-Will be 20 years in October of next year. Did IT before. 2012/20213 CDO and first ever in the <LOCATION>. Head of Corporate Social and Responsibly (D&I, emissions, digital volunteering, talent attractiveness, and employee engagement survey). 11 FTE's. Works with <LOCATION> and <LOCATION> 18,000 employees.-Finalizing content for DO's and Don't for leaders in global level (<LOCATION> and <LOCATION> drove it)-Reverse discrimination coming from men.-Went through economic dividends of gender equality through EDGE assessment (started it in April/May).**Needs help with behavior piece for leaders.**-How to cascade to individual employees.**Need facilitated breakouts****Leaky bucket: Hiring more women and minority employees but can't keep them.**Engagement guy, <PERSON>, is great at reading data but not insights from the data.**Sept Delivery, wants help; 2, 1 hour sessions (400 (white or <NRP> men) VP's to join 1 of 2). This is a pilot. 9 defined Do's and <PERSON> and <PERSON> will go through. How to improve. Measurement for Do's and Don't is something they want to do. They are being required to do the training.**Engagement survey needs help with data analysis (gender, tenure, age).has context menu

This email originated from an external source. Do not click links or open attachments unless you recognize the sender and know the content is safe.

Hi Emily,
Thank you so much for your note.  We are excited to put together a proposal.  To do so, can we schedule a ½ hour discussion focused on the role of your Peer Reviewers?  I believe you said that this is the target group.  We have a few delivery ideas, but the content is where the magic happens.  Understanding more about the function and flow of this group is important.

Also, how might you describe your objectives (hopes and dreams) for the investment?  What do you hope will be different because of the engagement?  We are still assuming a modest budget, and hope there could be an opportunity for future activities to support ongoing development.  So, for this engagement, how might you describe success?

This week I will be out of the office Thursday and Friday.  If you have time tomorrow or Wednesday, please let me know when you are available.  My availability includes (EST):

  *   Tuesday 10-12; 2-3:30; and after 4:30.
  *   Wednesday 9:30-1:00 and after 4:30.
  *   Monday 8/13  9:30-10:30; 11-12; and after 1:30.

<PERSON> and I look forward to hearing from you.

Cheers~

activities.subject: RE: XYZ & World Learning Inquiry
activities.body:
Dear <PERSON> and <PERSON>,

Thank you both for your time yesterday, it was very helpful to have a chance to go over what we are looking for and chat through some of the key goals with this training.

In terms of next steps, I checked with our compliance department to be sure we are following the correct protocol; as mentioned, we are under obligation to collect competitive bids from several potential vendors, however they confirmed that there is no specific format required.

At this point, I would greatly appreciate it if you could send a proposal based on our conversation yesterday with an outline of the services and product that XYZ would provide along with a quote.

Ideally, we are looking to be able to make a decision on the vendor by the end of the month so we would be looking to review proposals within the next few weeks. I hope that timing is feasible on your end, I am happy to answer any additional questions as they arise.

Thank you and I look forward to hearing from you.

8/14/23 RP notes internal meeting (<PERSON>, <PERSON>, RP)It's a competitive bidTraining for volunteer-reviewers, senior level folks across the country - about 350 pplHere's what <PERSON> is thinking:PHASE 1:Peer review input -  Online survey - about 10 questions, to capture baseline metrics their level of engagment and baseline around these issues. For ex, why is UB important, what do you know about UB? Where they see UB show up in the current process. What would you do to address UB int he peer review process? And if there's room, ask them a question about their overall satisfaction with the volunteer peer reviewer process. The survey results will also inform session development. We'd work with them to create messaging that engages these peer reviews, to invite them to participate and be a part of this.  Tailored hourlong session that was delivered to <PERSON> to bias mitigation (2 instances). Also includes mentimeter, to save data. Half day to adapt to World Learning. Reccommend prework, included in the <URL>ASE 2Interactive focus group - ability to identify  - structured focus groupBudget is ~ $25KPicking a vendor by end of this month, to be delivered in Dec or beg of 2024

Proposal Plans 8-7-23Ideas for how to present thisNo formal RFP necessaryProspect is making decision by end of monthTarget audience - 350 reviewers, possibly 90 mins of presentation, 25k budget.Looking for a follow up with <PERSON>, ideally this week. <PERSON> will send the email. Ideally we'd have a proposal for them mid next week or by the 21st.

1st MeetingDate 8-3-23Attendees: EmilyXYZ Attendees: Andrea & PedroWorld Learning involved with just Specialist program, under <PERSON> umbrellaAcademics and professionals 2-6 weeks in length, more professional friendlyCapacity building in natureEmily is interested in incorporation of unconscious/implicit bias training Reaching diverse audience is the goalTarget audience: peer reviewers, they review applications from the specialistPeer reviewers are alumni's that use to be specialistThe specialist are mid career to advance, even retired from the <URL> age limits on the specialists Some reviewers have biases, the purpose of this type of training to help with that specific issue. Non for profit entities, medical institutions participate?Projects can happen at any time of the year, no life cycle for the program. Host at any time can submit proposals, host driven.6 peer review cycles, roster acceptanceStart of the calendar year, late December, early <URL>is is when they would bring in the training.Target audience: Peer review folks, not the specialist. They aim to over subscribe the number of reviewers, not all will be selected. How many roughly would participate in this training? Some will be repeated reviewers that are included in this group training. <PERSON> mentioned, she want's to make sure reviewers don't feel like they are being judged because of this type of training. <PERSON> wants to get it right vs just getting it done. Training catered to these folks involved.Raise awareness of participants blind spotsRoughly 300-350 participants, 24 discipline, 3 per discipline at least. One peer reviewer could technically cover more than 1 discipline. All virtual delivery, (module training)Regional meet up possible in the future, everyone is spread all over the <LOCATION>. How much time can we take? Under 30 minutes to possibly an hour. Seems like it won't be obligatory.Budget? 25k - timeline Possible E-Learning prep work to set the stage, post opportunities to follow up on training? They have to look at several options to spend federal dollars. We would be competing with other companies. End of year roll out is the goal for them at this point. Possible opportunity to make it individualized? So people can do it at their own pace. They want to purchase the site license/curriculum, so they can distribute it to folks for them to start and complete at their pace. Rather than everyone all at once in one <URL>ey want to be able to provide something to folks at a later time if needed. Option: pre work training, as well as a module for folks to complete. Option: E-Learning IUMB possibility, tweak micro learnings to customize to their needs. They want to build something of this <URL>cision making process: RFP? Formal request. Panel will review the quotes that come in. A month to make a decision once they have quotes to compare. All proposal to be submitted within in the next few weeks.Fullbright Specialist . world learning . org

2nd Meeting 8-8-23Attendees: EmilyXYZ Attendees: Andrea & PedroThis program is unique, even more accessibly. prestigious and exclusive. Finding that balance, academic and non academic professionals. Peer reviewers understand the mission. They shouldn't judge if the specialist is missing some of the academics. Age bias, experience bias, examples they've <URL>ers don't determine what programs specialist will work on, they just evaluate on their experience and if they can become <URL>e reviewer will make sure the specialist is legit, and that they can be considered for some projects but they do not select them. Roster applications is what the reviewers are determining. Audience: Repeat reviewers, info can't come off the wrong way. Specific approach would be most helpful. Older crowd. Volunteer program.Examples, they run a law firm. CEO's non profit, running their own consulting firm, actor, freelance photographer, journalists, cyber security expert, emergency response professionals, fashion designers, etc. Ideal Outcome: Interactive listening session. We want to engage this crowd. Be the base for work to come down the line.<PERSON>'s big picture: Data driven outcome. How to manage expectations. Show by year 1, these are the changes we saw in our reviewers.

From: <PERSON> <<EMAIL_ADDRESS>> Sent: Thursday, August 17, 2023 10:58 AMTo: <PERSON><EMAIL_ADDRESS>>Cc: <PERSON>>Subject: XYZ Bias Mitigation and the Fulbright Specialist ProgramGood morning, <URL>W has had several discussions in anticipation of developing a proposal to respond to the needs of your organization.  We are excited to explore strategies on how working with your Peer Reviewers, the Fulbright Specialist program can address unwanted bias.  So it is with great enthusiasm that I offer our recommendations in this proposal Bias Mitigation & Peer Reviewers.Let me know if you need anything else.  Of course, I am available to chat anytime.  We look forward to speaking with you further.Enjoy the rest of your <URL>eers~<PERSON> Bowles(She/Her/Hers)Senior ConsultantXYZ

activities.subject: RE: Meeting with Sr Leadership/Next steps and XYZ announcement
activities.body:
Dear <PERSON>,

I hope this message finds you well.

I wanted to personally share an update regarding my professional journey. As of February 5th, I will no longer be with XYZ in my current role of Senior Consultant managing your account.

However, I am excited to be returning to facilitation and coaching contract work, as I was before this important project.
I greatly value our collaboration and look forward to all parties staying in touch as we all navigate challenging times for D.E.I. work in the <LOCATION>, impacting the world.

Please follow XYZ great initiatives at  <URL><<URL>>
and feel free follow me as well as we all make this world a better place:
 <PERSON> | LinkedIn<<URL>>

Effective immediately, <PERSON> hereby copied should be contacted so XYZ can support you moving forward on UL SOLUTIONS pending account activities and when you are ready for the new CCLP and the 2025 GLOBAL FORUM.

Wishing you continued success, and I hope our paths cross again soon!

activities.subject: Following up from Aug 1st meeting
activities.body:
[cid:<URL>g@01D9CED4.2E0CF510]
<PERSON>,

It was such a pleasure meeting with you on 1 August. We appreciate your taking the time to give us an overview of your current DEI needs.
Our understanding of your need:
Southlake Regional Health Centre is seeking a partner to help drive DEI mindsets and behavior within its hospital staff, both clinical and administrative. In particular, there is a need to provide learning interventions to front-line staff, professionals and employees who work directly with patients and the public and who do not necessarily have the time to sit through a workshop, including nurses and PSWs.


  *   In the proposal we include the "Identifying Unconscious Bias" <PERSON>, a short (15-20 min) internally-led lesson and conversation around a particular topic for constituents such as these. The deliverable includes a pdf with Facilitator Guide and <PERSON>, plus a meeting to walk you through the content. I want to send you a sample of this microlesson, but I'd like to tailor it to the health care industry, so I'll send it to you by this Wednesday.

We also talked about embedding inclusion and antibias education within your onboarding Core Curriculum.


  *   In the proposal we've included access to our eLearnings, "Introduction to Managing Unconscious Bias" and "Culture & Identity", both of which you've had the chance to review.
     *   These would sit in your LMS.
     *   Our eLearning pricing is on subscription and it's on tiers of 'seats'. Each seat is  a unique user, in other words a unique email address. So if you went into the system using your email address, you can go in as many times as you wanted during the year. I selected the 1,501-3000 seats tier for <LOCATION>. The next tier is 3,001-6,000 but I'm guessing you may not have that many users in a year?
     *   There is also an option to purchase an enterprise-wide site license, where you could keep one or both eLearnings forever. That would of course entail a significantly larger up front cost. Please let me know if that interests you!



  *   In the proposal we've also included our 2-hour online facilitated course, "Managing Unconscious Bias in the Workplace".
     *   This course explores how unconscious biases influence how we perceive, treat, and evaluate people - and how they prevent us from activating the full potential of our teams. Using relevant, real examples and working through various activities that relate to the real-world workplace, participants learn strategies to recognize, limit, and mitigate biases in making assessments and judgments in our everyday work and relationships.
     *   This course also covers specific cognitive unconscious biases that affect workplace decisions, microinequities and how we can counter them, the impact of coded language, and the importance of not staying silent in creating a culture of conscious inclusion. Participants walk away with ideas, tips, and strategies for addressing bias respectfully and confidently.
     *   Introduction to Managing Unconscious Bias eLearning is recommended as pre-work for this session.

Finally, we talked about possibly presenting the "Spotlight in Indigenous Peoples of North America" in September, in advance of National Day for Truth and Reconciliation. We've also included this 1-hr session in our proposal.


  *   Indigenous societies have flourished for thousands of years in the <LOCATION>, and their cultural contributions continue to impact modern life across <LOCATION>. Today, there are more than 630 First Nation communities in <LOCATION> and over 560 federally recognized <NRP> tribes in the <LOCATION>
  *   This session investigates the complicated relationship between Indigenous communities and the government, explores the rich traditions of Indigenous peoples in <LOCATION> (including <LOCATION> and the <LOCATION>), and shares insight on some of the social issues Indigenous communities face today, so you can begin to understand the experience of your Indigenous talent, clients, and market. This session is co-facilitated by an Indigenous culture-insider and a non-Indigenous culture-ally.

We also very much understand and appreciate that the DEI experience in <LOCATION> is different than in the <LOCATION>, from history to terminology, to immigrant populations, linguistic diversity, and legislation. We would facilitate these sessions through this lens.


Here<<URL>> is a link to our proposal for your review. The amounts are in <LOCATION>. I confirmed with our finance leader that we're able to lock in today's exchange rate at USD$1 = <NRP>.


Chantelle, if our response is only almost right for your needs, then we look forward to hearing from you so that we can respond swiftly, make adjustments, and get you what you need to ensure alignment!

We would proud to have you as a client, given the important work <PERSON> does! I'll send you the microlesson example on Wednesday, then we can check back with you next week if that's okay. Otherwise, please let me know what next steps should be.

activities.subject: XYZ inclusion tools - quick follow-up
activities.body:
Hi Chantelle, great to e-meet you today!

Congratulations again on being the first in our role. I imagine the prospect of shaping it is both challenging and exciting. Thanks for considering involving us in it!

Wanted to list my actions items:

  1.  Send you info and cost for "Spotlight on Indigenous Peoples in North America" - perhaps for delivery in September - in observance of National Day for Truth and Reconciliation on 30 September.
  2.  Send info and pricing for our 'shift start' microlessons (topics include Identifying <PERSON>, Microinequities, and Unstereotyping)
  3.  Send info and pricing of our recommendations for Soutlake's core curriculum: Intro to Managing UB and Culture & Identity eLearnings, perhaps a "Managing UB in teh Workplace" online facilitated session
Please let us know if we're missing anything. If not, you can expect to hear back from us by next week.

Best! <PERSON><PERSON> (she/her)
Head of Business Development
XYZ

Finally, we talked about possibly presenting the "Spotlight in Indigenous Peoples of North America" in September, in advance of National Day for Truth and Reconciliation. We've also included this 1-hr session in our proposal.


  *   Indigenous societies have flourished for thousands of years in the <LOCATION>, and their cultural contributions continue to impact modern life across <LOCATION>. Today, there are more than 630 First Nation communities in <LOCATION> and over 560 federally recognized <NRP> tribes in the <LOCATION>
  *   This session investigates the complicated relationship between Indigenous communities and the government, explores the rich traditions of Indigenous peoples in <LOCATION> (including <LOCATION> and the <LOCATION>), and shares insight on some of the social issues Indigenous communities face today, so you can begin to understand the experience of your Indigenous talent, clients, and market. This session is co-facilitated by an Indigenous culture-insider and a non-Indigenous culture-ally.

We also very much understand and appreciate that the DEI experience in <LOCATION> is different than in the <LOCATION>, from history to terminology, to immigrant populations, linguistic diversity, and legislation. We would facilitate these sessions through this lens.


Here<<URL>> is a link to our proposal for your review. The amounts are in <LOCATION>. I confirmed with our finance leader that we're able to lock in today's exchange rate at USD$1 = <NRP>.


Chantelle, if our response is only almost right for your needs, then we look forward to hearing from you so that we can respond swiftly, make adjustments, and get you what you need to ensure alignment!

We would proud to have you as a client, given the important work <PERSON> does! I'll send you the microlesson example on Wednesday, then we can check back with you next week if that's okay. Otherwise, please let me know what next steps should be.

activities.subject: XYZ inclusion tools - quick follow-up
activities.body:
Hi Chantelle, great to e-meet you today!

Congratulations again on being the first in our role. I imagine the prospect of shaping it is both challenging and exciting. Thanks for considering involving us in it!

Wanted to list my actions items:

  1.  Send you info and cost for "Spotlight on Indigenous Peoples in North America" - perhaps for delivery in September - in observance of National Day for Truth and Reconciliation on 30 September.
  2.  Send info and pricing for our 'shift start' microlessons (topics include Identifying <PERSON>, Microinequities, and Unstereotyping)
  3.  Send info and pricing of our recommendations for Soutlake's core curriculum: Intro to Managing UB and Culture & Identity eLearnings, perhaps a "Managing UB in teh Workplace" online facilitated session
Please let us know if we're missing anything. If not, you can expect to hear back from us by next week.

Best! <PERSON><PERSON> (she/her)
Head of Business Development
XYZ

Dear <PERSON>,



Thank you very much for your invitation to submit an RFP for consulting services. We are delighted by the opportunity to partner with you and hope that we can meet to review our proposal with you. XYZ prides itself on the ability to curate bespoke learning journeys that fit the unique needs of our clients. The recommendations in the attached are based on our understanding of your RFP and recent conversations with you; however, we welcome the opportunity to discuss options with you in detail.



If you have any questions or need additional information, please don’t hesitate to contact <PERSON>, copied on this email.



We look forward to speaking with you again soon and discussing next steps.

activities.subject: Follow-up to our meeting yesterday morning
activities.body:
Hi <PERSON>,
Thanks to you and <PERSON> for spending more of your precious time with us so we can answer your questions.

A couple of things we owe you here:


  1.  Ongoing (post pilot) facilitation costs (all assume single facilitator):
     *   Virtual facilitation (1 hour or less): $3k
     *   Virtual facilitation (1.5-2 hours): $6k
     *   Virtual facilitation (2.5-3 hours): $8k
     *   Virtual facilitation (3.5-4 hours): $9k
     *   Onsite facilitation (daily rate 4 hr session or less): $10k
     *   Onsite facilitation (daily rate over 4 hrs): $15k



  1.  Coaching Services:
     *   Group coaching (3 sessions per cohort): 1.5-hour sessions with the last half hour for Q&A. $10k instructional design, $12K facilitation for all three.
     *   Individual coaching: 3 coaching sessions per manager at $275/per = $825 per manager.



  1.  Complimentary IDI(r) assessment for the ACLU - I believe you mentioned <PERSON> would be the best person to do this. Please let me know if you/she would like to proceed and we'll have a link sent to her.

Please let us know if we missed anything!

Best - Rebecca


<PERSON>
(she/her)
Head of Business Development
XYZ

activities.subject: Follow-up from XYZ
activities.body:
Hello <PERSON>, <PERSON>, <PERSON>, <PERSON>, and <PERSON> –

It was a pleasure meeting with y’all on Monday, we appreciate your taking the time to give us an overview of your translation needs – which includes DEI assets (education materials, newsletters, ERG related items, etc.), HR communications and documents, internal communications and marketing assets, and the JH website.

We’d of course be delighted to be your one stop shop for Jensen Hughes’ translation and localization needs, and believe we’d be a great fit. Our number one priority would be to get to know your needs and preferences thoroughly, and to consistently get it right for you and your employees, clients, vendors and other stakeholders around the world.  We’d also be proud to have you as a client, given the important work you do.

Attached are:


  1.  TRANSLATION RATES & TERMS_2023

A 4-pager that summarizes our standard translation services, including:

  *   Rates
  *   Translation memories
  *   Turnaround times
  *   Rush options
  *   eLearning and multimedia
  *   Cultural adaptations
  *   Desktop publishing
  *   Highly specialized translations
  *   JH internal review option

I underline the word ‘standard’ above because we can exert some flexibility depending on what the project/s is/are.  Are you able to share your budget or budget range for translation of your website for example?


  1.  Two pdf’s: Sample-MgingBiasHiring-ENG and Sample-MgingBiasHiring-CHS: This is a sample of our translated work, a 2-page job aid around managing bias in hiring. We include the source English material and translation into simplified <NRP>.

Additional info:

  *   We routinely translate a wide range of materials/formats: from documents in any Office format, to in InDesign, XML, HTML, eLearnings, videos, other multimedia, etc. And our deliverables are generally in the same as what we received and we include any layout work that may be needed to accomplish that.
  *   We also offer subtitling and voiceover as they are often used for eLearnings.
  *   Usually we’ll give you a cost estimate relatively quickly once you provide us with the source document. When we’re talking about larger projects, like a website, we would I would usually suggest a project call at the start of the project to align on details (volume, deadlines, deliverables in priority order, notes on specialized terminology, etc.).
  *   We’d love to work with you on a relatively small project to start, so you can test us out to see if we’d be a good fit.

If the above is only almost right for your needs, then we look forward to hearing any concerns so that we can respond swiftly and get you what you need to ensure alignment!

All the best, <PERSON>, <PERSON>, and the XYZ team


<PERSON>
(she/her)
Head of Business Development
XYZ

-----Original Appointment-----

activities.body:
Hi. Finally looking at this, apologies.
 
Did <PERSON> end up reviewing it before it went out?
 
I would love to hear a download from you on this type of proposal (from your meeting with <PERSON>), esp the items under Strategy in Phase 1 and 2 (slide 10) as well asl slides 14 and 15. sure.  when I return from <LOCATION>
 
Also about Slide 10:
- Is “Leading a Culture of Inclusion” a client-specific tweak /rewording of “Building a Culture of Inclusion for Managers and Leaders” (slides 62-3
all honesty, <PERSON> called it this on the call. so i thought it was a course.  but its BCI for leaders. but we could also deliver LCI.  we can walk them through both.  they werent specific on what they wanted.  OK. LCI is a little bit more ‘advanced’ – leaders are expected to understand the business case, UB ,and the ‘basics’ about DEI.
-  in Course Catalog deck)? Or did you mean “Leading with Conscious Inclusion” (a different workshop, slide 66 in CC deck)?
- Is ‘college’ Orveon’s language? yes
- Is what you called “Managing UB in Talent Processes” the OTS workshop called “Managing UB for Managers and Leaders” (slides 65-5 in the Course Catalog deck)?  no. i was referring to the series of managin UB in talent acquisition, UB in performance mgmt etc.  When.I  had put together a draft proposal for FTD/FYF, I had discussed a session that spoke to UB in talent processes where we could combine 1 or 2 of these processes.  Still not 100% following but that’s okay, as long as you are on it! : )
 
I like how you circled relevant stuff is slides 8 and 13.
 
Please note that I tweaked the Course Catalog deck last week. I removed the slide that is your slide 5 in this Orveon deck and replaced it with what is now slide 5 in the Course Catalog deck. I also made a tweak to slide 4 of the CC deck        
 
RP
 
<PERSON>
(she/her)
Head of Business Development
XYZ

activities.subject: Orveon - capabilities overview
activities.body:
Hi team
before I send this out, I wanted to share with all of you first for final weigh in.
 
We are very much in discovery phase still, so not sure if I should include the pricing just yet, so <PERSON>, I rely on you to weigh in since you and I were on the call.  what do you think?
 
Thank you to <PERSON> especially who helped me think through pricing and to <PERSON> who provided thoughts on the assessment side.

Hi Adrienne and Crystal,
We have a few clarifying questions and comments that I've noted below. I'm not sure if it will be easier to hop on a quick 10 minute call? 
1. We are suggesting an assessment which includes an audit of cultural mindset (we will review Entromy Survey results and conduct interviews), accompanied by review of key systems and processes (eg talent mgmt, HRIS) as part of the overall evaluation to determine the best and targeted approach to building your DEI strategy and ensuring the focus of that strategy is on point for maximum impact and change.  Many organizations fall into the pitfall of not focusing on the priorities that will help to drive meaningful change and a fuller assessment will help us finetune and target actions that will be more relevant to Orveon.  This would not require a survey but we would review your results from <LOCATION>.  Did you mean something else by "survey"?
2. We understand your financial pressures and are happy to work with you.  We could offer a 15% discount on your discovery and assessment if we started this year. This would be a savings of $4350 and we can work out a timed payment structure to allow you to pay just a portion before year end that could fit your budget. (e.g. a portion of the phase 1 strategy fee). This Assessment phase will not require a heavy lift from the Orveon team.  May we set up time to discuss?
Attached is the new proposal with reworked numbers as well as new discounted offer but I am also offering a quick call as we are open to discussing. 
I have availability Monday, Oct 16 after 4pmET or Wednesday, Oct 18 prior to 12pm ET.
Have a great weekend
	
Deb

activities.note_body: <PERSON> and I met with <PERSON> who introduced us to <LOCATION>, Manager, HRBP at Orveon.  <LOCATION>, and <PERSON> (their HR leader) worked with Paradigm to help conduct a DEI survey (possibly worked with <PERSON> Emerson).They are very new to DEI, new as an organization (result of merger with Shisheido).  DEI is something HRBPs have asked for but Orveon recognizes sensitivity with topic.  want to approach this the right way, to institutionalize, systematize and sustain rather than check the box, superficial.  Tends to be discussion with not too much action or actions without real sustainability.  They discussed ERGs  but experience has been more social coffee networks (we discussed aligning ERG to business impact which received positive reaction).  They are headed into talent and succession process and discussed hiring for diversity. while they have done some things, not tracked, not measured, not formalized.  University education doesnt have much DEI.  They are a global organization and need to think about how to translate and engage around the world and be sensitive to merger culture as well.  they have had some discussions around supplier diversity and supporting MWBE as well but no strategy.  they hired a consultant to assist with comms around heritage months and other activities.  they will NOT be hiring someone full time to do this work but want to be employee driven (we communicated need to be leadership driven- top down/bottom up approach).  They are in budget process now, planning for <URL>rienne is speaking with <PERSON> 9/19.  We are scheduled to follow up 9/26 at 11am
Deb sent Orveon slides from capabilities deck on 8/25/23Follow-up meeting to take place on 9/26 but is being reschuled, hopefully week of Oct 2nd, 2023.

<PERSON> had mentioned via email on Oct 10, 2023 that "I was able to share the deck and review with <PERSON>.  He was very impressed.  We are around 1,000 employees at this point.  Could you re-run the numbers to reflect that count?  Also, we wouldn’t need the survey as we could share our entromy results.  Given the financial pressure we are under at the moment, we wouldn’t be able to start this partnership until <US_DRIVER_LICENSE> of next year, and we can revisit in the new year."Proposed Services & Costs (from Deb's proposal) below

10/11/23 <PERSON> from Deb about <PERSON> originally said 1600 employees but they are at 1000 now.  They want a new revised proposal and mentioned they don't need survey (but (1) we offered a bulk scale discount so the 1600-1000 doesnt really metter but I wll change the range (2) we did not suggest a survey in our proposal, so I have to go back to clarify with them).I would suggest we try to ask them to chunk it and conduct a portion of the work this quarter. Can we get creative with financing?  if we offer a 10% discount if they sign now?  or offer free elearning if they sign now (elearning isnt a cost to us)Other thoughts?

<PERSON> to <PERSON> from <PERSON>: Deb MunsterSent: Friday, August 25, 2023 3:38 PMTo: <EMAIL_ADDRESS> <<EMAIL_ADDRESS>>Cc: <PERSON> <<EMAIL_ADDRESS>>Subject: Orveon/XYZ follow upHi <PERSON>,Thank you for your time earlier this week.  <PERSON> and I enjoyed getting to know you and learning about Orveon's vision to start and amplify your DEI efforts.  You and Crystal have a lot on your plate and should be so proud of launching Orveon University.  Quite an accomplishment for your small and mighty team.  We hope XYZ can partner with you to help you shape and accelerate your strategy as well as supplement the University with our extensive L&D subject matter expertise and content. As a follow up to our conversation, I am attaching a power point deck that provides some preliminary scoping and recommendations based on our discussion. It includes more details about our approach to collaborating and building a DEI strategy as well as an overview of just some of our content, specifically focused on <PERSON> and Building a Culture of Inclusion. We of course, have many other courses such as navigating across cultures, immersive experiences and targeted bias in talent processes but thought we would start with these. Please note that while we did provide some pricing, we are very open to discussing your budget and adapting a plan that meets those needs.  Our goal is to partner with you to find the best, cost-effective solutions for Orveon. It would be great to schedule some time with you to go over your thoughts and reactions once you've had a chance to review.Would the first or second week of September work? Warm regards,Deb

activities.subject: RE: [External] - OLLY & XYZ Follow Up
activities.body:
Hi <PERSON>,



Hope you had a great weekend! No worries, we completely understand. Here is an updated link for the proposal that will reflect the correct number of participants: <URL><<URL>>



Regarding timeline, individuals should take the assessment and participate in the individual debriefs before 9/15, so no changes on that end. For group debriefs, the time is set for 2 hours. Lastly, yes you can add additional at the same discounted rate of $115.50 per assessment. I will ensure the rate is locked into your account and inform the consultant when we bring them in to kick off this project.



Looking forward to next steps!

activities.subject: Re: [External] - OLLY & XYZ Follow Up
activities.body:
Hi <PERSON>,



Thank you again for the information and apologies for the delay while <PERSON> and I discussed best next steps. After some discussion, we would like to keep things simplified for this first phase as we look and not include BCI as part of the phase 1 programming. We would be interested in proceeding with the following proposal but I would like to confirm a few things.  <URL><<URL>>



Could you share how the timeline for the group debriefs (in person) + individual assessments (online) would change with us moving forward without BCI learning?



Could you share how much time is needed for the group debrief sessions? We would still like to have them on:

  *   JEDI Council - Monday afternoon Oct 2
  *   Leadership Team - Tuesday morning Oct 3

For the number of assessments, we do have some JEDI Council Members who are also Leadership Team members, so the total number of assessments needed would be 17. Could we adjust that on the proposal? If our team grows though by Oct, would we be able to add-on any additional individuals at the same cost?



Thank you in advance; we are looking forward to locking in the proposal!

activities.subject: RE: [External] - OLLY & XYZ Follow Up
activities.body:
Hi <PERSON>,

Hope you’re having a great week! For the proposal for BCI, we agree that based on your given group size, the best option moving forward would be to hold two separate BCI sessions that include IDI Group Debriefs for the JEDI Counsel and the Leadership Team.

Recommended Option: Two BCI sessions, where two group IDI debriefs are included.

  *   Timeline, starting with individual IDI assessments & individual coaching.

     *   Participants should take the assessment and participate in the individual debrief before 9/15, allowing ample time for the consultant to build the group’s aggregate results in the BCI program.

  *   BCI sessions on October 2nd & 3rd.

We recommend doing the individual debriefs before you go into a group setting to receive the aggregate results. Doing the IDI assessment and debriefs first helps individuals since they’ll know where they individually sit on the continuum in advance and can find some solidarity in understanding they are not alone in the process. Participants also have a better understanding of what the group dynamic could represent because of the insights from the IDI debrief and their contributions to that group.

As for your question regarding In-Person programming, yes XYZ can be on-site during those days. Travel & expenses will be charged to you at cost. However, we will conduct individual IDI debriefs virtually to allow for greater flexibility around your staff scheduling needs.

Regarding locking in those dates, as for now, our calendar has availability. Keep in mind we cannot secure the dates until we have a signed statement of work.

If the attached proposal meets your approval, we will connect you with a consultant and begin the work of finalizing the details of your program.

<URL><<URL>>

Looking forward to your response!

activities.subject: Re: [External] - OLLY & XYZ Follow Up
activities.body:
Hi <PERSON>,



Thank you for the updated proposal and additional information! <PERSON> and I are reviewing, and I want to confirm a few things:



Since we are focusing on phase 1 for JEDI Council and the Leadership Team first, we would like to put phase 2 on the backburner for now until we see how phase 1 goes. We would be interested in phase 1 with BCI learning since I do think having some follow up learning is important - in looking at the Phase 1 proposals, the proposal for phase 1 with the BCI does not include the two group debriefs. Is this something that we can include in the proposal?



For the group debriefs, we are aiming to do this in the first week of October in-person, ideally for our JEDI Council on Monday 10/2 and the Leadership Team on Tuesday 10/3. Could you confirm that we would be able to have this facilitated by XYZ in person? Would travel expenses for the facilitators be at cost?



Could you also remind me of the timing/order of how this takes place? First, we would have the group debriefs, then we would ask individuals to complete the assessment and then we would do the BCI session? What is your recommendation for timing in between the group debrief, individual debriefs and the BCI learning? Given our group size and purpose of the JEDI Council and Leadership Team, would the recommendation be to do separate BCI sessions?



I know I threw out a lot of questions so please let me know if it's best to jump on a call to discuss!

Anyway, the additional info re: the questions below would be very useful in getting to you a proposal that is accurate and thorough. If it’s easier for you, I’d be glad to jump on a 15 min call vs. replying to this email. Whatever’s easiest for you!

activities.subject: XYZ's UTBE for Estée Lauder
activities.body:
Dear <PERSON> and <PERSON>,

Hope you are well and enjoying the last remnants of summer. As we are pulling together a proposal for you, we wanted to check in and see how you felt the demo went with <PERSON> and <PERSON> and ask a couple of clarification questions.



You discussed the importance of ensuring the content included research and data as your targeted audience was financially/data savvy as well as ensuring content was relevant to your creative/ marketing focused audience.  You are also a global organization with a comprehensive DEI curriculum already.

  1.  How do you envision this rollout?  That is, you mentioned an initial session with your creative group of approximately 40 people. First, is this correct? Second, confirming your creative team refers to Estée Lauder’s Marketing team? And finally, do you envision further rollouts and if so could you add some clarity around target audiences?
  2.  Will this be a global rollout? As you saw during the demo, this workshop is focused on the <LOCATION> experience, and if you are considering a global rollout, we would want to make adjustments to be inclusive of the Black experience in different regions and countries. If a global rollout, with which countries so that we can ensure we are geographically inclusive in our content?  Any additional thoughts on this are greatly appreciated.





<PERSON> is now back from her much- deserved vacation.  She leads our content and business development functions and will be working with <PERSON> to pull things together for you as a next step. If it's easier, we are happy to jump on a quick call with you.  Would love to get your feedback.



Looking forward to next steps,

Deb

________________________________

activities.subject: XYZ's UTBE Demo for Estée Lauder
activities.body:
Hi Keisha & Marilu, Hope all is well! Thank you for meeting with us last week and sharing your insight on ways we could collaborate to continue to drive inclusion and cultural competence within Estée Lauder. Attached are: A three-workshop

Hi Keisha & Marilu,



Hope all is well! Thank you for meeting with us last week and sharing your insight on ways we could collaborate to continue to drive inclusion and cultural competence within Estée Lauder.



Attached are:

  1.  A three-workshop curriculum to upskill Estée Lauder staff on Black/African American cultural competence and inclusion:

·       “Understanding The Black Experience” (UTBE) Cultural Immersion (which we talked about extensively during our meeting)

·       “Upskilling Your Ally Voice” is a ‘part 2’ to the Immersion and gives people a forum to practice answering and addressing frequently asked questions about the Black community. Facilitators provide coaching and feedback, and participants are able to practice having these conversations in a judgment-free, growth-mindset environment, so they can then transfer this skill to their day-to-day. This one’s also facilitated by a <NRP> facilitator and a non-Black Ally.

·       “Developing Inclusively: What You Need to Know About Black Talent” is a 3-hour workshop for people managers, to help upskill them on what their Black team members need to develop and advance within the organization.



  1.  A slide that gives you an overview of our facilitated and digital learning solutions. Please let us know if any of these fill a gap for you and we would be more than happy to send you more information about particular workshops or tools.



Please feel free to share these documents internally with your stakeholders.



We would also like to schedule a demo for our Black Experience Cultural Immersion.  Here are times we have for next week, where our Lead Facilitator <PERSON><<URL>>, would be able to demo the UTBE session for 45 mins:



  *   Wednesday, September 6th at 11am, 12pm, 3pm, or 4pm EST
  *   Thursday, September 7th at 9am, 12:30pm, 1pm, or 2pm EST



Let me know if any of these times work for you, and I’ll send an invite accordingly.



Looking forward to your response!

Hi <PERSON> and <PERSON>,
I hope you are well. I know you are in the midst of internal discussions, but I wanted to send this along. I'm sure you have seen it. I was part of the team that worked on this with <PERSON> and some members of the National Retail Federation.  While this study is a few years old, I still think the data and the lessons are pertinent.  In addition, I designed a series of workshops for another beauty industry's "Power Hour" based off race specific incidents that went viral on social media. Our team wanted to share these real scenarios and data as examples with you for consideration.

activities.subject: RE: XYZ's UTBE Demo for Estée Lauder
activities.body:
Hi Keisha & Marilu,

Thank you for joining us today during our demo session. We appreciate your participation and feedback. Just a quick update, I’m out of office tomorrow, traveling for a wedding but I’ll be back in office on Monday. I look forward to putting together a proposal for you. Below you will find our recommendations.


  1.  A three-workshop curriculum to upskill Estée Lauder staff on Black/African American cultural competence and inclusion:

  *   “Understanding The Black Experience” (UTBE) Cultural Immersion.
  *   “Upskilling Your Ally Voice” is a ‘part 2’ to the Immersion and gives people a forum to practice answering and addressing frequently asked questions about the Black community. Facilitators provide coaching and feedback, and participants are able to practice having these conversations in a judgment-free, growth-mindset environment, so they can then transfer this skill to their day-to-day. This one’s also facilitated by a <NRP> facilitator and a non-Black Ally.
  *   “Developing Inclusively: What You Need to Know About Black Talent” is a 3-hour workshop for people managers, to help upskill them on what their Black team members need to develop and advance within the organization.

Let me know if you feel anything should be added or removed. I understand the target audience would be your creative team, roughly 40 participants. If you have any additional information you would like to provide, I’m sure it will be helpful as I build out the proposal.

Have a great weekend and we’ll talk soon!

Hi Keisha & Marilu,

Hope all is well! Thank you for meeting with us last week and sharing your insight on ways we could collaborate to continue to drive inclusion and cultural competence within Estée Lauder.

Attached are:

  1.  A three-workshop curriculum to upskill Estée Lauder staff on Black/African American cultural competence and inclusion:

  *   “Understanding The Black Experience” (UTBE) Cultural Immersion (which we talked about extensively during our meeting)
  *   “Upskilling Your Ally Voice” is a ‘part 2’ to the Immersion and gives people a forum to practice answering and addressing frequently asked questions about the Black community. Facilitators provide coaching and feedback, and participants are able to practice having these conversations in a judgment-free, growth-mindset environment, so they can then transfer this skill to their day-to-day. This one’s also facilitated by a <NRP> facilitator and a non-Black Ally.
  *   “Developing Inclusively: What You Need to Know About Black Talent” is a 3-hour workshop for people managers, to help upskill them on what their Black team members need to develop and advance within the organization.


  1.  A slide that gives you an overview of our facilitated and digital learning solutions. Please let us know if any of these fill a gap for you and we would be more than happy to send you more information about particular workshops or tools.

Please feel free to share these documents internally with your stakeholders.

We would also like to schedule a demo for our Black Experience Cultural Immersion.  Here are times we have for next week, where our Lead Facilitator <PERSON><<URL>>, would be able to demo the UTBE session for 45 mins:

Let me know if any of these times work for you, and I’ll send an invite accordingly.

Looking forward to your response!

activities.subject: XYZ & Estee Lauder Inquiry
activities.body:
Hi <PERSON>,

Hope all is well! Thank you for reaching out about XYZ's services. My name is <PERSON>, I'm a business development associate here at XYZ.

I wanted to take this opportunity to set up a time to introduce you to <PERSON>, head of business development. We would love to set up a 30-minute meeting with you next week to discuss your inquiry on our workshop, Understanding the Black Experience in <LOCATION>. In the meantime, I've attached a PDF that highlights our session.

Here are some times we have available for next week:


  *   Wednesday, August 23rd at 3pm, 3:30pm, 4pm or 4:30 pm EST
  *   Thursday, August 24th at 1pm, 2pm, 3pm, 4pm EST
  *   Friday, August 25th at 12pm EST

Let me know if any of these times work for you and I'll send an invite accordingly. Looking forward to connecting!

activities.subject: RE: Cultural literacy re: the Black Experience for Estée Lauder
activities.body:
Thanks <PERSON>. Although we’re certainly disappointed, we hope to stay in touch and we’re able to partner with you on future DEI and cultural competency related initiatives.

Also do let us know if you would like our help facilitating any sessions (even if it’s your content). We have a lot of experience navigating hard questions and pushback during deliveries.

Separately – but related – if you’re ever in need for cultural literacy education for people managers, we offer this very effective program:

Developing Inclusively: What You Need to Know About Your Black Talent
This engaging and practical workshop engages with questions like: Where is the African American/Black talent sitting in your organization? How are you ensuring this talent has access to the opportunities, relationships, and networks needed to advance? In this session, people managers are guided through a journey to broaden cultural competency and better understand the experience of their Black employees, so they can create better action plans that will retain and develop this population. Participants reflect on how they and their peers may be contributing to experiences positively and negatively, then practice what they can do better and differently on an organizational level and as leaders.

Good luck with everything and we look forward to another opportunity to work together!

<PERSON>
(she/her)
Head of Business Development
XYZ

activities.note_body: 8/25 <PERSON> from Deb to <PERSON> and RPRebecca and I had a chance to catch up as we were waiting for a prospect to join a call.  We chatted about Estee Lauder and she mentioned a few courses as we were chatting.  What I love about our convo is that its clear we have a great learning continuum for <URL> your response to <LOCATION>, you and I discussed the course catalogue/capabilities deck being really large and needing to streamline. I think we should focus on the following curriculum/continuum:Phase 1 = Understanding the Black ExperiencePhase 2= <LOCATION> Your Ally Voice (structure is a coaching/practice session where participants shape communications, practice and get coaching)Phase 3 = Developing Inclusively: What You Need to Know About Your Black Talent (manager and talent process focused)Its A HUGE differentiator for XYZ that we have this targeted curriculum.  As the <LOCATION> team stated, they have lots of L&D and they're looking for something new and different. I dont know many orgs that have this particular focus and depth as we <URL>so, in reviewing the UBE demo we are scheduling, I think the intent v impact is fine since it has a nice combo of breakout/interaction and speaks to the marketing/imagery- two things they mentioned are important.  I would note a few things to prepare for the demo:they mentioned their global nature, so lets ensure we arent too NA/<LOCATION> focused.  if we can have a global example, scenario to talk through, that would resonatethey mentioned data/numbers, research resonates with their population so citing data/research will also largely resonate.  e.g. dollars lost from ads or gained from strong ads/imagery/DEI intentionalityfocus on the "applicability/behavior change and outcome of the intent v impact sessionHope thats <LOCATION>

1st Meeting 8-23-23Attendees: Marilu & KeishaXYZ Attendees: <PERSON>, Deb, & PedroThey are a referral (cartier)Diversity work for 20 yearsLarry has been involved with the facilitated training: Understanding the black experience since its inception here at <URL>isha would like to build upon their <URL>ey already have an anti racism toolkitCultural sensitivity is a big thing for them due to all the brands they work with and represent.Where would it be helpful to focus on for the purpose of this call?Cultural immersions: several topicsDeeper dive into those populations (history, Identity & content)Immersions:150 countries where they sell their products. Diverse leadership team. Not <LOCATION> centric.4 hour session, co facilitated, one native to the demographic, as well as an <URL>eak out sessions are a part. Deeper dives into bigger conversations.Difference between <LOCATION> vs <LOCATION> in terms of understanding the black <URL>ent vs impact, covered in the training sessionLevel of inter activity? Designed to be about 60% lecture, 40% <URL>ssion focuses on marketing. Marketing that went wrong. Think about the intent, scenario based.Timeline?Budget?# of initial participants?How many different versions? 4 already created. Marketing, HR, Global audience, & ?. (Finance & data driven organization?)Possible Demo? E-Learning Modules?

Demo Call 9-7-23Scope of proposalTarget Audience? Brand & marketing people. Creative team. Number to be determined, 40 <URL> many people would be involved in the training?Timeline? Within a weekBudget? Break out rooms. Wanting to come out of a workshop, with some type of action plan or governance. Ensure voices are heard from different groups of <URL><PERSON> asked for expectations for a deliverable after the session. Requiring action.
Referral came from Cartier

activities.subject: XYZ Proposal for Rampart Bio
activities.body:
Hi <LOCATION>,

Hope you’re having a great week! We are excited to share our proposal for our two E-Learning sessions, Introduction to Managing Unconscious Bias as well as Culture & Identity. Here is the link to access the proposal:  eLearnings: Introduction to Managing Unconscious Bias / Culture & Identity<<URL>>.

During your meeting with <PERSON> and <PERSON> I know an important part of next steps was also to share information on other learning interventions that you might engage with in the future, to continue building a sustainable culture of inclusion. Here is a link that highlights some of our other facilitated trainings as well as our spotlights on different communities: Future Considerations for a Sustainable Culture of Inclusion<<URL>>.

We hope you find our proposals to be insightful and we look forward to your feedback! If you have any questions or would like more information on anything in specific, I’m happy to help.

activities.subject: XYZ E-Learning Links
activities.body:
Hi Virginia,



My name is <PERSON>, I'm a business development associate here at XYZ. I'm on <PERSON> team. I wanted to take this opportunity to follow up with you since you had expressed interest in our E-Learnings. Below are a series of links that I would like to share with you. Each of the links below will request your name and email address. After you enter that information, you will be taken directly into the course.


Introduction to Managing Unconscious Bias<<URL>>
Culture & Identity<<URL>>



The links are active for the next 17 days (9/08) and you have access to 2 registration seats. Our learnings are provided by seat licenses and can be purchased in bulk quantities over annual subscriptions. All our courses can be shared on your LMS or hosted through XYZ, based on your needs.



Looking forward to hearing about your experience with the learning links above. I'll also be following up this week to provide you with a proposal based on your discussion with <PERSON> and <PERSON>.



Have a great day and talk to you soon!
