activities.note_body: 8/21/23 Call NotesClient participant: <PERSON>, DirectorXYZ participants: RP, AlisaPre-call <PERSON> (requests from emails, other knowledge)We are a small biotech company and are interested in an eLearning course (no more than 45 min, on demand) on cultural competency for our staff, i.e. on how to engage with people with different backgrounds, help decrease biased communication and behavioral practices, and help avoid the use of cultural generalizations and stereotypes in interactions with people. We are also interested in cultural competency in the context of healthcare: i.e., the ability of health care professionals to understand and appreciate the unique cultural values, beliefs, and practices of their <URL>LL NOTES:Labs in <LOCATION>, but <LOCATION> is in <URL>rm has about 35 ppl and was only created 3 years ago.We are recruiting a Director of HR. Raising money to grow the <URL>anted an award by state of CA to create gene therapy for a rare disease – we’re still in ‘stealth mode’ (confidential) but will open up soon.A part of the award funding requirement is to develop DEI <URL>ernal DEI needs currently – not outward facing yet.We gave an overview of C&I and IMUB eLearnings. Will send them links. CEO needs to see them too. Talked to her about our subscription pricing <URL>e asked for examples of how we could customize these. RP mentioned we could change the examples to health care ones, onscreen text, images, and that altering the narration script would be the most costly. Mentioned that our examples cross industries.Budget? We are flexible. Not same budget as big <URL> you have LMS? (she didn’t know what an LMS was so probably not). We have an onboarding system – LabTraining. Are there additional costs for us reporting completion rates to them if we host the eLearnings? (Not sure, we’ll ask <PERSON> about that).In our follow-up, please include additional courses in our library with prices just for their info so they can see what they can do in the future (RP note: BCI for everyone is a good one, include other options like <PERSON>, MBML for managers, and the Spotlights…)They would like to make a decision within the next two weeks.RP notes:I highly recommend lowering per seat subscription <URL>acticing Conscious Inclusion microlearning, Foundations of DEI microlearning series – both would be great here – but not ready yet. <PERSON> working <URL>xt steps:<PERSON> will send them links <URL>W to follow up with info and pricing.

activities.task_body: You have an assigned web lead that needs to be contacted as soon as possible.

activities.subject: DEI Services Proposal for GXO Logistics from XYZ
activities.body:
[cid:<URL>g@01D9F7AF.C1EC5A10]
<PERSON>, <PERSON>, and <PERSON> –

We so appreciate your reaching out to us, and are certainly grateful for the time you all took to give us an overview of your DEI accomplishments and goals. Examples of DEI initiatives you shared with us include education around unconscious bias and  microaggressions, the large number of inclusion-minded volunteers at <PERSON>, as well as an upcoming guest speaker series for your C-suite and director level and above leaders. We also admire the creativity, collaboration and generosity underpinning how your relatively new DEI Team is coming together and driving momentum throughout the organization. We felt your ‘family approach’ – interdependent, got each other’s backs, ‘all for one’ scrappiness in embedding DEI within <PERSON>’s culture and businesses.
We’d be delighted and proud to partner with you, starting with administrating the Intercultural Development Inventory® (IDI) for your division Presidents and their teams, as well as for <PERSON>’s HR professionals. I’ve personally found the IDI to be an incredibly effective, compelling and galvanizing tool when it comes to talking about and advancing inclusion, equity, and belonging - especially for people leaders. And it’s great that you have a champion for it in <PERSON>, who has taken it in the past.
Our approach would be framing the IDI initiative around <PERSON>'s specific DEI objective/s and context, and guiding intercultural competence development and momentum towards achieving those goals – always being as specific and action-oriented as possible. We’ll work with you to determine the communication plan and ‘onboarding’ into this project for your constituents, and thoroughly prepare all IDI coaches on our end before each leader’s debrief as well as the Group Debriefs.
Please find our proposal for IDIs for <LOCATION>-based leaders here --> <URL><<URL>>
In addition, below we’ve included information and costs for additional learning interventions by constituent group (both workshops and digital tools) that may fit into your plans in the future.
We can of course work with you on cost for packages of multiple workshops.

<PERSON>, <PERSON>, and <PERSON> - if the above and below are only almost right for your needs, then we look forward to hearing from you so that we can respond swiftly, make adjustments, and get you what you need to ensure alignment.

Have a good rest of your week and we’ll touch base next week if we don’t hear from you first!

activities.subject: [EXTERNAL]: Follow-up from XYZ Inclusion
activities.body:
CAUTION: This email originated from outside the <PERSON> organization. Do not click links or open attachments unless you recognize the sender and know the content is safe.


[cid:<URL>g@01DA1234.4B0F8A80]

Hello <PERSON> and <PERSON> -

Thank you so much for reaching out to us, and for the time you took to give us an overview of your wonderful organization and your people-related/DEI goals.
We'd be delighted and proud to partner with you!
I see a great fit with regards to the second and third goals you outlined for us:

  1.  Helping you develop and implement a restorative practice within your HR employee issue-resolution process and
  2.  Increasing intercultural competency and inclusive leadership skills as well as broadening the diversity of your leadership team.
Guide for Restorative HR Conversations
As you know, the restorative process/practice is aimed at repairing and fostering relationships, in a way that benefits the employees as well as the organization. It works to understand what each employes needs to be 'restored' in the relationship, and return to healing and working effectively with one another.
The restorative practice takes the focus away from guilt and punishment, and would seek to repair harm by:

  1.  Agreeing on the facts of what happened (the facts on what was said, done)
  2.  Providing an opportunity for the aggrieved employee/s to talk about their perception of what happened, and the impact it had on them
  3.  Providing and opportunity for the employee/s who perpetrated the harm to talk about their perception of what happened, distinguish between intent and impact, and take responsibility for the harm
  4.  Addressing the needs of all employees impacted by the conflict/disagreement/incident/dispute, and
  5.  Providing an opportunity for all parties to come up with a path forward that makes them feel heard and whole (however many meetings or conversations it takes).
We recommend that <PERSON> leverage XYZ's Describe-Interepret-Navigate, or DIN, model within the process (please see attached).
This process will require careful change management, co-development of the restorative HR process at <PERSON>, training on the restorative process for HR, and development of an onboarding/comms process for <PERSON> employees.
The process itself should have ground rules for conversation that all parties agree to at the outset, to encourage brave conversations and establish a psychologically safe 'container' - an environment that promotes trust, mutual respect, and safety around interpersonal risk-taking, where people don't feel afraid to speak up for fear of being embarrassed, rejected or dismissed. Ground rules would include things like: being open to resolving the issue, assuming positive intent/good faith from the other person (foundational rule, without this the process will not work), mindful listening, limited or managed interjections/interruptions, acknowledging relative levels of power and privilege in the room (both formal titles and informal relationships/relational privilege, and ensuring that any judgments and evaluations are backed up by specific behaviors and examples.
We propose co-developing a Guide for Restorative HR Conversations, where we can do some more listening around your needs and preferences, build a first draft for you, then have you review it and provide us with feedback. This would be a consulting project for us, and we are estimating about 16 hours (two days) of work and 2 review cycles, which is what the project fee reflects.
Intercultural Development Inventory(r)
We recommend that you start with administrating the Intercultural Development Inventory(r) (IDI) for your leadership team, future HR Manager, and HR Assistant. I've personally found the IDI to be an incredibly effective, compelling and galvanizing tool when it comes to talking about and advancing inclusion, equity, and belonging - and hearing and understanding each other better. Its focus is on mindsets - and engaging in restorative HR takes a shift in mindset. Most conflict stems from 'cultural' differences - meaning differences around how we've been taught to interact, communicate, work, and 'be' - by our families, contexts and experiences growing up and beyond, our experiences belonging to our ethnicity/race, nationality, gender, socioeconomic & educational background, religion, previous jobs and schools, etc. Misinterpretations and differences in interpretations caused by these cultural differences account for the vast majority of conflicts that we find ourselves in! And we can provide language for you to talk about these differences too - confidently and knowledgeably.
Each person would take the 50-item IDI assessment. Then, they could each receive either:

  *   A one-hour virtual individual debrief, where an IDI Qualified Administrator (QA) would walk them through their results, unpack what they mean, and get them to articulate an action plan, and/ or
  *   A Group Debrief of collective results, a 2-hour workshop facilitated by us, where the group has space to dialogue about the IDI experience, the meaning of inclusive leadership, unpack the implications of their group result, and learn about additional strategies they can take to live into the intercultural/inclusive mindsets of the IDI. (Individual profiles are not available if you choose only this option).
Our approach would be framing the IDI initiative around <PERSON>'s specific objectives around restorative HR (and also around inclusion, diversity, and equity generally at <PERSON>).  We'll work with you to determine the communication plan and 'onboarding' into this project for your folks, and prepare our IDI coaches on our end before each leader's debrief as well as the Group Debriefs.
Our proposal reflects both individual debriefs and a Group Debrief.

Please find our proposal for the above here --> XYZ's Proposal for <PERSON><<URL>>  Please note at the bottom we've applied a 20% non-profit discount.
In addition, below we've included information and costs for additional learning interventions (both workshops and digital tools), most of which we mentioned during our meeting, which may fit into your plans in the future.
We can of course work with you on cost for packages of multiple workshops.

<PERSON> and <PERSON> - if the above and below are only almost right for your needs, then we look forward to hearing from you so that we can respond swiftly, make adjustments, and get you what you need to ensure alignment.

Have a good Thursday and we'll touch base next week if we don't hear from you first!

  2.  Providing an opportunity for the aggrieved employee/s to talk about their perception of what happened, and the impact it had on them
  3.  Providing and opportunity for the employee/s who perpetrated the harm to talk about their perception of what happened, distinguish between intent and impact, and take responsibility for the harm
  4.  Addressing the needs of all employees impacted by the conflict/disagreement/incident/dispute, and
  5.  Providing an opportunity for all parties to come up with a path forward that makes them feel heard and whole (however many meetings or conversations it takes).
We recommend that <PERSON> leverage XYZ's Describe-Interepret-Navigate, or DIN, model within the process (please see attached).
This process will require careful change management, co-development of the restorative HR process at <PERSON>, training on the restorative process for HR, and development of an onboarding/comms process for <PERSON> employees.
The process itself should have ground rules for conversation that all parties agree to at the outset, to encourage brave conversations and establish a psychologically safe 'container' - an environment that promotes trust, mutual respect, and safety around interpersonal risk-taking, where people don't feel afraid to speak up for fear of being embarrassed, rejected or dismissed. Ground rules would include things like: being open to resolving the issue, assuming positive intent/good faith from the other person (foundational rule, without this the process will not work), mindful listening, limited or managed interjections/interruptions, acknowledging relative levels of power and privilege in the room (both formal titles and informal relationships/relational privilege, and ensuring that any judgments and evaluations are backed up by specific behaviors and examples.
We propose co-developing a Guide for Restorative HR Conversations, where we can do some more listening around your needs and preferences, build a first draft for you, then have you review it and provide us with feedback. This would be a consulting project for us, and we are estimating about 16 hours (two days) of work and 2 review cycles, which is what the project fee reflects.
Intercultural Development Inventory(r)
We recommend that you start with administrating the Intercultural Development Inventory(r) (IDI) for your leadership team, future HR Manager, and HR Assistant. I've personally found the IDI to be an incredibly effective, compelling and galvanizing tool when it comes to talking about and advancing inclusion, equity, and belonging - and hearing and understanding each other better. Its focus is on mindsets - and engaging in restorative HR takes a shift in mindset. Most conflict stems from 'cultural' differences - meaning differences around how we've been taught to interact, communicate, work, and 'be' - by our families, contexts and experiences growing up and beyond, our experiences belonging to our ethnicity/race, nationality, gender, socioeconomic & educational background, religion, previous jobs and schools, etc. Misinterpretations and differences in interpretations caused by these cultural differences account for the vast majority of conflicts that we find ourselves in! And we can provide language for you to talk about these differences too - confidently and knowledgeably.
Each person would take the 50-item IDI assessment. Then, they could each receive either:

  *   A one-hour virtual individual debrief, where an IDI Qualified Administrator (QA) would walk them through their results, unpack what they mean, and get them to articulate an action plan, and/ or
  *   A Group Debrief of collective results, a 2-hour workshop facilitated by us, where the group has space to dialogue about the IDI experience, the meaning of inclusive leadership, unpack the implications of their group result, and learn about additional strategies they can take to live into the intercultural/inclusive mindsets of the IDI. (Individual profiles are not available if you choose only this option).
Our approach would be framing the IDI initiative around <PERSON>'s specific objectives around restorative HR (and also around inclusion, diversity, and equity generally at <PERSON>).  We'll work with you to determine the communication plan and 'onboarding' into this project for your folks, and prepare our IDI coaches on our end before each leader's debrief as well as the Group Debriefs.
Our proposal reflects both individual debriefs and a Group Debrief.

Please find our proposal for the above here --> XYZ's Proposal for <PERSON><<URL>>  Please note at the bottom we've applied a 20% non-profit discount.
In addition, below we've included information and costs for additional learning interventions (both workshops and digital tools), most of which we mentioned during our meeting, which may fit into your plans in the future.
We can of course work with you on cost for packages of multiple workshops.

<PERSON> and <PERSON> - if the above and below are only almost right for your needs, then we look forward to hearing from you so that we can respond swiftly, make adjustments, and get you what you need to ensure alignment.

Have a good Thursday and we'll touch base next week if we don't hear from you first!

activities.subject: Do you know of a team struggling with alignment or interpersonal issues?
activities.body:
Dear Emily,​

Hope you’re having a productive <US_DRIVER_LICENSE> – I can’t believe it’s almost over already!

Reaching out to see if we could help you solve a problem you or others in your org may be having. 
Is your or another team you know of, struggling with alignment, communication, interpersonal dynamics, trust, or collaboration? Are cultural issues holding this team back? <PERSON> said that “culture eats strategy for breakfast” – and we continue to see examples that prove him right. 

We’ve developed an intensive program where we help team members create the team culture they need and crave to succeed. 

This workshop is for intact teams who are struggling with issues that are interfering with their performance due to ineffective communication and/or working relationships, for example:
- Interpersonal issues
- Issues with the leader/manager 
- Poor group dynamics
- Harmful microbehaviors
The workshop content has its strong foundation, but we tailor it based on interviews, focus groups, or surveys of all team members. This is key. During the program itself, facilitators and your stakeholder together, create a “brave” space for all participants to feel heard and be engaged During the program, participants co-create a Team Charter: five to seven concrete behaviors that all team members will commit to going forward The workshop is facilitated by 2 highly skilled professionals who coach participants to arrive at solutions The workshop is designed for intact teams of up to 20 participants, conducive to deep attention to key issues that are getting in their way If this intervention sounds like something that would help remove an obstacle for your team (or another team in your org), we’d love to hear more and see if/how we could help. 

Simply reply to this email and we can send a few available timeslots for you to choose from, or you could send us your availability if you prefer.

activities.subject: WSJ article "Corporate America Tweaks Diversity Initiatives" & my analysis
activities.body:
Hi <PERSON> and <PERSON>,

As you continue to be SMEs for <PERSON>, I wanted to send you this article which you may have already seen. It’s pretty short, and gives language about the current challenges in corporate <LOCATION>. You can help your stakeholders make sense of it.

Here are my thoughts. It seems to me the two main points that are being pushed back against are:

  1.  Hiring or promotion ‘quotas’ (which is something that XYZ or any other DEI professional I know or have worked with has ever recommended) and
  2.  ‘Blaming’ white populations by, for example, calling people ‘white supremacists’ or stating something ridiculous like all white people are racist.

Neither of the points above are part of what achieving DEI is all about. Inclusive practices are alive and well, and I think that most organizations understand that there’s no going back.

<URL><<URL>>

  5.  Providing an opportunity for all parties to come up with a path forward that makes them feel heard and whole (however many meetings or conversations it takes).
We recommend that <PERSON> leverage XYZ’s Describe-Interepret-Navigate, or DIN, model within the process (please see attached).
This process will require careful change management, co-development of the restorative HR process at <PERSON>, training on the restorative process for HR, and development of an onboarding/comms process for <PERSON> employees.
The process itself should have ground rules for conversation that all parties agree to at the outset, to encourage brave conversations and establish a psychologically safe ‘container’ – an environment that promotes trust, mutual respect, and safety around interpersonal risk-taking, where people don’t feel afraid to speak up for fear of being embarrassed, rejected or dismissed. Ground rules would include things like: being open to resolving the issue, assuming positive intent/good faith from the other person (foundational rule, without this the process will not work), mindful listening, limited or managed interjections/interruptions, acknowledging relative levels of power and privilege in the room (both formal titles and informal relationships/relational privilege, and ensuring that any judgments and evaluations are backed up by specific behaviors and examples.
We propose co-developing a Guide for Restorative HR Conversations, where we can do some more listening around your needs and preferences, build a first draft for you, then have you review it and provide us with feedback. This would be a consulting project for us, and we are estimating about 16 hours (two days) of work and 2 review cycles, which is what the project fee reflects.
Intercultural Development Inventory®
We recommend that you start with administrating the Intercultural Development Inventory® (IDI) for your leadership team, future HR Manager, and HR Assistant. I’ve personally found the IDI to be an incredibly effective, compelling and galvanizing tool when it comes to talking about and advancing inclusion, equity, and belonging – and hearing and understanding each other better. Its focus is on mindsets – and engaging in restorative HR takes a shift in mindset. Most conflict stems from ‘cultural’ differences – meaning differences around how we’ve been taught to interact, communicate, work, and ‘be’ – by our families, contexts and experiences growing up and beyond, our experiences belonging to our ethnicity/race, nationality, gender, socioeconomic & educational background, religion, previous jobs and schools, etc. Misinterpretations and differences in interpretations caused by these cultural differences account for the vast majority of conflicts that we find ourselves in! And we can provide language for you to talk about these differences too – confidently and knowledgeably.
Each person would take the 50-item IDI assessment. Then, they could each receive either:

  *   A one-hour virtual individual debrief, where an IDI Qualified Administrator (QA) would walk them through their results, unpack what they mean, and get them to articulate an action plan, and/ or
  *   A Group Debrief of collective results, a 2-hour workshop facilitated by us, where the group has space to dialogue about the IDI experience, the meaning of inclusive leadership, unpack the implications of their group result, and learn about additional strategies they can take to live into the intercultural/inclusive mindsets of the IDI. (Individual profiles are not available if you choose only this option).
Our approach would be framing the IDI initiative around <PERSON>'s specific objectives around restorative HR (and also around inclusion, diversity, and equity generally at <PERSON>).  We’ll work with you to determine the communication plan and ‘onboarding’ into this project for your folks, and prepare our IDI coaches on our end before each leader’s debrief as well as the Group Debriefs.
Our proposal reflects both individual debriefs and a Group Debrief.

Please find our proposal for the above here --> XYZ’s Proposal for <PERSON><<URL>>  Please note at the bottom we’ve applied a 20% non-profit discount.
In addition, below we’ve included information and costs for additional learning interventions (both workshops and digital tools), most of which we mentioned during our meeting, which may fit into your plans in the future.
We can of course work with you on cost for packages of multiple workshops.

<PERSON> and <PERSON> - if the above and below are only almost right for your needs, then we look forward to hearing from you so that we can respond swiftly, make adjustments, and get you what you need to ensure alignment.

Have a good Thursday and we’ll touch base next week if we don’t hear from you first!

activities.subject: [EXTERNAL]: Follow-up from XYZ Inclusion
activities.body:
CAUTION: This email originated from outside the <PERSON> organization. Do not click links or open attachments unless you recognize the sender and know the content is safe.


[cid:<URL>g@<URL>FEEC10]

Hello <PERSON> and <PERSON> -

Thank you so much for reaching out to us, and for the time you took to give us an overview of your wonderful organization and your people-related/DEI goals.
We'd be delighted and proud to partner with you!
I see a great fit with regards to the second and third goals you outlined for us:

  1.  Helping you develop and implement a restorative practice within your HR employee issue-resolution process and
  2.  Increasing intercultural competency and inclusive leadership skills as well as broadening the diversity of your leadership team.
Guide for Restorative HR Conversations
As you know, the restorative process/practice is aimed at repairing and fostering relationships, in a way that benefits the employees as well as the organization. It works to understand what each employes needs to be 'restored' in the relationship, and return to healing and working effectively with one another.
The restorative practice takes the focus away from guilt and punishment, and would seek to repair harm by:

  1.  Agreeing on the facts of what happened (the facts on what was said, done)
  2.  Providing an opportunity for the aggrieved employee/s to talk about their perception of what happened, and the impact it had on them
  3.  Providing and opportunity for the employee/s who perpetrated the harm to talk about their perception of what happened, distinguish between intent and impact, and take responsibility for the harm
  4.  Addressing the needs of all employees impacted by the conflict/disagreement/incident/dispute, and
  5.  Providing an opportunity for all parties to come up with a path forward that makes them feel heard and whole (however many meetings or conversations it takes).
We recommend that <PERSON> leverage XYZ's Describe-Interepret-Navigate, or DIN, model within the process (please see attached).
This process will require careful change management, co-development of the restorative HR process at <PERSON>, training on the restorative process for HR, and development of an onboarding/comms process for <PERSON> employees.
The process itself should have ground rules for conversation that all parties agree to at the outset, to encourage brave conversations and establish a psychologically safe 'container' - an environment that promotes trust, mutual respect, and safety around interpersonal risk-taking, where people don't feel afraid to speak up for fear of being embarrassed, rejected or dismissed. Ground rules would include things like: being open to resolving the issue, assuming positive intent/good faith from the other person (foundational rule, without this the process will not work), mindful listening, limited or managed interjections/interruptions, acknowledging relative levels of power and privilege in the room (both formal titles and informal relationships/relational privilege, and ensuring that any judgments and evaluations are backed up by specific behaviors and examples.
We propose co-developing a Guide for Restorative HR Conversations, where we can do some more listening around your needs and preferences, build a first draft for you, then have you review it and provide us with feedback. This would be a consulting project for us, and we are estimating about 16 hours (two days) of work and 2 review cycles, which is what the project fee reflects.
Intercultural Development Inventory(r)
We recommend that you start with administrating the Intercultural Development Inventory(r) (IDI) for your leadership team, future HR Manager, and HR Assistant. I've personally found the IDI to be an incredibly effective, compelling and galvanizing tool when it comes to talking about and advancing inclusion, equity, and belonging - and hearing and understanding each other better. Its focus is on mindsets - and engaging in restorative HR takes a shift in mindset. Most conflict stems from 'cultural' differences - meaning differences around how we've been taught to interact, communicate, work, and 'be' - by our families, contexts and experiences growing up and beyond, our experiences belonging to our ethnicity/race, nationality, gender, socioeconomic & educational background, religion, previous jobs and schools, etc. Misinterpretations and differences in interpretations caused by these cultural differences account for the vast majority of conflicts that we find ourselves in! And we can provide language for you to talk about these differences too - confidently and knowledgeably.
Each person would take the 50-item IDI assessment. Then, they could each receive either:

  *   A one-hour virtual individual debrief, where an IDI Qualified Administrator (QA) would walk them through their results, unpack what they mean, and get them to articulate an action plan, and/ or
  *   A Group Debrief of collective results, a 2-hour workshop facilitated by us, where the group has space to dialogue about the IDI experience, the meaning of inclusive leadership, unpack the implications of their group result, and learn about additional strategies they can take to live into the intercultural/inclusive mindsets of the IDI. (Individual profiles are not available if you choose only this option).
Our approach would be framing the IDI initiative around <PERSON>'s specific objectives around restorative HR (and also around inclusion, diversity, and equity generally at <PERSON>).  We'll work with you to determine the communication plan and 'onboarding' into this project for your folks, and prepare our IDI coaches on our end before each leader's debrief as well as the Group Debriefs.
Our proposal reflects both individual debriefs and a Group Debrief.

Please find our proposal for the above here --> XYZ's Proposal for <PERSON><<URL>>  Please note at the bottom we've applied a 20% non-profit discount.
In addition, below we've included information and costs for additional learning interventions (both workshops and digital tools), most of which we mentioned during our meeting, which may fit into your plans in the future.
We can of course work with you on cost for packages of multiple workshops.

<PERSON> and <PERSON> - if the above and below are only almost right for your needs, then we look forward to hearing from you so that we can respond swiftly, make adjustments, and get you what you need to ensure alignment.

Have a good Thursday and we'll touch base next week if we don't hear from you first!

Hi <PERSON>Thanks so much.


  1.  UB 101 - confirming you're referring to our "Intro to Managing UB" eLearning module, yes? Which by the way was updated and it looks even better now. So, 9,000 seats. What might be your budget for this type of subscription? I'd like to meet it if I can.
  2.  Then for the plants, sounds good. Topics include: Identifying <PERSON>, Microinequities/Microaggressions, and Unstereotyping.
  3.  Two microlearning modules: Managing <PERSON> in Interviews and Managing Bias in Talent Review. As you saw in the demo link, our microlearnings now come as a single digital module with video/job aid embedded (no longer two separate things). What might be your budget for this type of subscription? I'd like to meet it if I can. About how many seats would y'all need for each one?

Re: allyship, we do have this 1.5 hour virtual facilitated session:

Power of Allyship (1.5 hours, $6k/workshop)
This session explores the meaning of allyship - what it is, what it's not, and how allyship can have a tremendous impact on the workplace.  Through examples, discussion, and self-exploration, participants will discover the difference between an ally and an advocate, learn tips and skills for becoming a better ally, and consider actions they can take right away - and every day - to advocate for underrepresented or marginalized people and communities.
Other topics covered include:

  *   Why allies matter
  *   How to turn your insights into action
  *   How to "call in" and challenge microaggressions
  *   Six roles you can play as an ally
  *   <NRP> allyship
  *   Responsibilities of an ally

Please lmk when/if you'd like to move forward, and we can get an SOW started for you

Thanks, JG! <PERSON><PERSON>

XYZ

I've put together a proposal for you that reflects:

  1.  Annual subscription to "Introduction to Managing Unconscious Bias" eLearning
  2.  Annual subscription to "Managing Bias in Interviewing" and "Managing Bias in Talent Review" MicroLearnings,

What might be your budget for this type of subscription? I’d like to meet it if I can. About how many seats would y’all need for each one?

Re: allyship, we do have this 1.5 hour virtual facilitated session:

Power of Allyship (1.5 hours, $6k/workshop)
This session explores the meaning of allyship – what it is, what it’s not, and how allyship can have a tremendous impact on the workplace.  Through examples, discussion, and self-exploration, participants will discover the difference between an ally and an advocate, learn tips and skills for becoming a better ally, and consider actions they can take right away – and every day – to advocate for underrepresented or marginalized people and communities.
Other topics covered include:

  *   Why allies matter
  *   How to turn your insights into action
  *   How to “call in” and challenge microaggressions
  *   Six roles you can play as an ally
  *   <NRP> allyship
  *   Responsibilities of an ally

Please lmk when/if you’d like to move forward, and we can get an SOW started for you

Thanks, JG! <PERSON><PERSON>

activities.subject: RE: XYZ Follow Up: Immersions & Spotlights
activities.body:
Hi <PERSON>,



Thanks for the questions.



Re: Train the Trainer –

The half day cultural immersions require 2 facilitators (one member of the culture and one nonmember/ally) and the material requires highly specialized skillsets from both.

The identity-specific Spotlights also require facilitation by a member of the community, who is leveraging their identity to facilitate. These programs also require deep intercultural competence skillsets.

Finally, content for both the <PERSON> and Spotlights are updated regularly, at least annually, to recognize the current times.

Thus for the reasons stated above, immersions and Spotlights we typically do not offer TTT options.



Re: baseline on culture/ethnicity--

Yes, we do have a one-hour session we call Foundations of Diversity and Inclusion, which introduces the concepts of diversity, inclusion, and culture. It differentiates between diversity and inclusion, touches on the powerful role that culture plays in driving behavior and expectations in the workplace (ethnicity being one of those cultures), and offers examples of day-to-day actions which could contribute towards a sense of disengagement or lack of belonging. Examples of inclusive everyday behaviors are also provided, and an opportunity to brainstorm what you would do to practice inclusion through short scenarios. For this one we could certainly conduct a TTT.



We also offer a program called “Building a Culture of Inclusion”, which goes deeper into intercultural competence.



Please let me know what else we can clarify for you.

activities.subject: DEI Services Proposals from XYZ
activities.body:
[cid:<URL>g@01DA239D.70B74EB0]
Hi, <PERSON> –

Thaks for reaching out to us and for taking the time to describe your inclusion needs with my colleagues <PERSON> and <PERSON>. I’m sorry I wasn’t able to attend, I was in the midst of facilitating a session during that time. I’m looking forward to meeting you soon.
We’ve put together two proposal options based on our understanding of your needs:
Choice Hotels seeks a partner to help upskill their leaders around driving a culture of inclusion in their teams and throughout the company. A culture of inclusion is one that engenders trust and mutual respect, where leaders actively listen and develop authentic relationships with their team members, and where employees aren't afraid to speak up and are comfortable bringing their full selves (and their ideas) to their roles at Choice Hotels - whether people are working onsite or virtually.
Below is a quick overview of the learning journey we envision for Choice Hotels' leaders:

  *   Phase 1: Keynote delivery during December's Diversity Council gathering (with prework).
  *   Phase 2:  "Building a Culture of Inclusion for Leaders" pilot (2-hr session, virtual, with prework).  Pilot attendees to be a diverse (function, tenure, age, gender, race/ethnicity, abilities, etc.) group of leaders, who can provide feedback on the session.
  *   Phase 3, option 1: Train-the-Trainer for internal facilitators. Includes site license to program, facilitator notes, and PPT.
  *   Phase 3, option 2: XYZ facilitates workshop for Choice Hotels leaders.We so appreciate your coming back to us after your prior experiences with XYZ, and are certainly grateful for the time you took to give us an overview of your Diversity, Equity, and Inclusion goals.
Further detail is included within the proposals. We send you two options:
Proposal #1 includes Phases 1 and 2 above, plus Phase 3, option 1 (Train-the-Trainer option)
Proposal #2 also includes Phases 1 and 2, and Phase 3, option 2 (XYZ facilitates workshops).
Corinne, we look forward to meeting with you on Tuesday to walk you through these, and we are of course open to other options and can get creative if necessary. Our goal is to respond swiftly, make adjustments, and get you what you need to ensure alignment and move forward.

Have a good weekend and we’ll touch base next week.

  *   Phase 2:  "Building a Culture of Inclusion for Leaders" pilot (2-hr session, virtual, with prework).  Pilot attendees to be a diverse (function, tenure, age, gender, race/ethnicity, abilities, etc.) group of leaders, who can provide feedback on the session.
  *   Phase 3, option 1: Train-the-Trainer for internal facilitators. Includes site license to program, facilitator notes, and PPT.
  *   Phase 3, option 2: XYZ facilitates workshop for Choice Hotels leaders.We so appreciate your coming back to us after your prior experiences with XYZ, and are certainly grateful for the time you took to give us an overview of your Diversity, Equity, and Inclusion goals.
Further detail is included within the proposals. We send you two options:
Proposal #1<<URL>> includes Phases 1 and 2 above, plus Phase 3, option 1 (Train-the-Trainer option)
Proposal #2<<URL>> also includes Phases 1 and 2, and Phase 3, option 2 (XYZ facilitates workshops).
Corinne, we look forward to meeting with you on Tuesday to walk you through these, and we are of course open to other options and can get creative if necessary. Our goal is to respond swiftly, make adjustments, and get you what you need to ensure alignment and move forward.

Have a good weekend and we'll touch base next week.

  *   Phase 1: Keynote delivery during December's Diversity Council gathering (with prework).
  *   Phase 2:  "Building a Culture of Inclusion for Leaders" pilot (2-hr session, virtual, with prework).  Pilot attendees to be a diverse (function, tenure, age, gender, race/ethnicity, abilities, etc.) group of leaders, who can provide feedback on the session.
  *   Phase 3, option 1: Train-the-Trainer for internal facilitators. Includes site license to program, facilitator notes, and PPT.
  *   Phase 3, option 2: XYZ facilitates workshop for Choice Hotels leaders.We so appreciate your coming back to us after your prior experiences with XYZ, and are certainly grateful for the time you took to give us an overview of your Diversity, Equity, and Inclusion goals.
Further detail is included within the proposals. We send you two options:
Proposal #1<<URL>> includes Phases 1 and 2 above, plus Phase 3, option 1 (Train-the-Trainer option)
Proposal #2<<URL>> also includes Phases 1 and 2, and Phase 3, option 2 (XYZ facilitates workshops).
Corinne, we look forward to meeting with you on Tuesday to walk you through these, and we are of course open to other options and can get creative if necessary. Our goal is to respond swiftly, make adjustments, and get you what you need to ensure alignment and move forward.

Have a good weekend and we'll touch base next week.

activities.note_body: Follow up call 10-10-23Attendees: CorinneXYZ Attendees: RP, Alisa & PedroCorinne 7 years in this roleRP gave overview of our proposals"I want this to be the way we work", type of trainingCEO is also the Chief of Diversity. He's involved in these initiativesQuarterly reviewsThey've done bias auditsMature culture when it comes to DEIWhy now? For the workshops for the leaders? <PERSON>'s answer: They are busy at the moment, coming out of the pandemic. Embedding the learning. Role out for leadership, creating a pilot.<PERSON> explained how XYZ has always been culture first.RP overview of BCI for Leaders. What the session looks <URL><PERSON> went over how XYZ provides a partnership. Consulting and opportunities to engage our clients. Corinne ask if she can see the session? Or one that's been done in the past? She's never worked with us before. (Referral based)Contemplating a 2 hour session, TTT (maybe, brought up by Corinne)Corinne asked about the assessment for the facilitators. The assessment helps with navigating differences 90% of the time, IDI with TTT. (RP mentioned)Corinne will now present this proposal to her <URL>rinne will get back to us for next steps. Doesn't want to set a follow up until she's shared our proposal with her diversity council.
AK & PS met with <PERSON> on 10/3/23 (notes in Dropbox Prospect folder)AK, PS, & RP met with Corinne again on 10/10/23

10/10/23 Call NotesRP, PS, AKMet with Corinne today, walked her through proposal, got more clarity regarding December session. 30 member Diversity Advisory Council, 3-year terms, diverse group of Choice <URL>nt her DIN model info, asked <PERSON> about Corinne observing BSC Leading Inclusively. <PERSON> said she’d <URL>rinne to socialize internally and get back to us.

Follow Up Call 10-26-23Attendees: CorinneXYZ Attendees: RP, Alisa & PedroCorinne, thankful to be able to sit in on the session. (upcoming)Budget? unspent money, trying to <URL>ed us to resize <URL>T model is most sustainable approach. (she's most interested in)Thoughts on Keynote opportunity. 30 people, business owners, volunteers. 3 hour long session. Look at what's coming, to build excitement. Not so much interested in a full on Keynote.Budget: 50 to 60k (trying to get this to work)Main goal for December meeting: Drive excitement towards DEI Initiatives in 2024.RP went over options to replace the keynote in the <URL>rinne would like to drop the keynote event from our <URL><PERSON> suggested replacing keynote for possibly consulting <URL>oader than inclusive training. (suggested by Corinne)RP showed some of our content and how it can relate to what they are looking <URL>xt steps: Revisit the proposal. Remove Keynote opportunity. Keep TTT section. Find content we can use for them, it sounds like it would require some custom <URL><PERSON> info for facilitated session coming up.RP's notes from same call:NDA to be signed by <PERSON> and returned to Corinne todayPricing is a bit higher than I expected, trying to make it fit leftover budget for 2023 – can we rightsize?TTT option is preferred – more sustainableKeynote – I may have oversold my vision by calling it a keynote. DAC – 30 ppl from different functional areas, not div professionals just business owners who’ve volunteered into this committee. Total 3-hr meeting. “Look at what’s coming, this is exciting”. Maybe provide them with an outline of the project/workshop and <PERSON> can present herself. <PERSON> thinks taking this off the table is sth she wants to do. <PERSON> mentioned we can bring someone in to help create buy-in.$50-$60k was more what we were thinking# of participants in the pilot? 20-25Something beyond inclusive leadership – people-centric leadership <URL>reenshots from Corinne’s screen-share - these are some things she'd like to align with / incorporate:I walked her through BCI for leaders (4-hr version) to give her a taste of our approachMentioned that we could weave in the human-centric leadership competencies from her pie chart into our contentChoice Hotels uses <LOCATION> leadership competenciesHave corporate valuesIf we remove the 'keynote' and IDI's we are down to $45k but we'd need to add some customization - maybe $10K = $55k

10/3/23 Call NotesClient Participants & roles:	Corinne (pronounced with a short ‘i’) <PERSON>, Head, Diversity, Equity and BelongingXYZ <PERSON>	<PERSON>, PedroTopic/Purpose	DiscoveryPre-call <PERSON> (requests from emails, other knowledge)Website lead: I am interested in learning more about your training solutions and cost.  Time is somewhat precarious and I am interested in connecting soon v. later.  Contacting me by email to set up is fine, in general, but if someone has time to talk today, I am available.  Please text <PHONE_NUMBER> to set <URL>oice Hotels is based in <LOCATION>, <LOCATION>. In 2022, Choice Hotels acquired Radisson Hotel Group Americas. The deal was worth around $675 million, and with this, Choice Hotels acquired nine new brands, 624 hotels, and over 67,000 rooms. The company, which is one of the largest hotel chains in the world, owns several hotel brands ranging from upscale to economy:Upscale: Ascend Hotel Collection, <LOCATION>, <LOCATION> by <LOCATION>, <LOCATION>, Radisson Blu/Collection/IndividualsMidscale: Comfort (Economy in <LOCATION>, <LOCATION>, and <LOCATION>), <LOCATION>, <LOCATION> (upscale in <LOCATION>, <LOCATION>, <LOCATION>, <LOCATION>, and <LOCATION>), Quality Inn, <LOCATION>, <LOCATION> by <LOCATION>, Radisson Inn & Suites, Radisson RedExtended stay: <LOCATION>, <PERSON>, Suburban Extended Stay Hotel, <PERSON> Econo Lodge, <LOCATION>, <LOCATION> Red<URL> their website:·         DEI Board Committee: This is a Diversity Committee at the Board of Directors’ level which assists and oversees management in developing a culture that values diversity and inclusion. The committee reviews the company’s inclusion and diversity initiatives and oversees management in furthering efforts to develop a workforce, franchise and vendor base that is reflective of the community in which Choice does business.·         Diversity Advisory Council: This Council was formed to provide Choice a formal means to gather input and insights from leaders across the organization. Headed by the CEO, the council supports Choice with the development and implementation of its diversity and inclusion initiatives and <URL>LL NOTES - Alisa and <PERSON> met with <PERSON> on 10/3/23.·         We came highly recommended by Stanley Black & Decker (looking at SOW’s they came from DBP and did an UB in Talent Mgmt session for a pilot group, site license and TTT for the session in 2018, translation of deck into <NRP> CAN, French FR, <NRP>, <NRP>, Spanish, <NRP>, and <NRP>, and IMUB into Spanish, TTT on MUBW and IMUB Debrief Toolkit in 2019 including IDIs, Translation of deck into CHS ).Looking for inclusive leadership skills for leaders at Choice. They want to have people centric training for their <URL> that addresses how people want to be treated in the workplace (RP with respect, active listening, and value).Choice Hotels is HQ in <LOCATION>, <LOCATION>. Corinne is in <LOCATION> area. Also in <LOCATION>, <LOCATION>, <LOCATION> (acquisition), <LOCATION> (acquisition)Use a franchise model with their <URL>W able to support multiple languagesCorinne working on <LOCATION> initiatives2/3 of the org work remote.2,000 people work in corporate and over 1,000 people work in 11 hotel brands (not included in this scope).Founder created this brand 80 years ago. Corinne wants to support a culture of respect and inclusion.Just went through an acquisition (<LOCATION>) and are now balancing hybrid work (4 days a week in the office in <LOCATION> and 3 days a week in AZ).Wants to ensure culture is maintained post-merger. Don’t want to see the organization revert back to old ways vs being people centric <URL>ey have recently hired a lot of new people so they feel the timing is rightThey went through well being training. Completed a <URL>ed i4cp before to support some development. RP:  I4cp is “the leading research firm that discovers and advances next practices in human capital.”Leadership and supporting people of diverse backgrounds.**Where does leadership stand now?Around DEI when the supreme court came out with affirmative action, it didn't affect <URL> and CHRO support CDO role. Current COO is sponsoring Corrine's DEI department.Have a quarterly review.**GoalsAspire to emulate the territories they service. 5 year representation goals – limited on what they can <URL>rrently are limited by data (racial ethnicities and gender) – Initiated a self-ID campaign right before the <URL>ing with HBCU’s to bring more folks into hotels and support in moving faster into leadership <URL>ying to support women into ownership of hotels and a Black owners council.**Why now?Has a quarterly review on 10/16 and is reviewing current issues. There are 13 ERG's and there is a need to support over the communities. It is budget season <URL>s you <URL> person Keynote Delivery in Dec:·         <PERSON> is during when their Diversity Council is meeting (how many people?) and the goal is to get the leaders attending excited about the workshops in <LOCATION>, as well as, starting to see and use similar language when conversing with one another and their employees·         Keynote about ‘culture and identity’. One hour, in person in <LOCATION>.·         Would like some prework. RP: Design prework around their business priorities and DEI/culture <URL> rollout in <US_DRIVER_LICENSE> 2024:·         <US_DRIVER_LICENSE> training rollout - 200 from the leadership team. Virtual training. Some leaders are remote some are hybrid.·         Interested in a TTT <URL> deliveries, virtual, groups of about 8-20.1-2 hour <URL>ended to get leaders refocused on supporting and understanding all of their people. Corinne got a sense that during the pandemic leaders were focused on relating to all the people within the organization and the past year that has changed. With the acquisition and return back to work leaders are not focusing on their people and how to create a sustainable culture of inclusion but on <URL>e needs leaders to be skilled in supporting people across cultures and creating an environment where folks feel supported and are hearing similar messaging. They have 5 year goals around representation within their organization and are focused on doing a better job of attracting and retaining talent that represents the communities they <URL><PERSON> talked about the importance of us being able to bring in examples that are relevant to the organization by performing an audit and leading case studies to show leaders what we can support them in solving for and she seemed interested in that.RP: Compressed version of BCI for leaders? Are they open to IDIs with Group Debrief only (as the prework?). Otherwise we can come up with a carefully selected pre-read + activity (e.g, come prepared with a particular DEI related goal )Deb’s thoughts:1) leadership should be grounded in their role in championing DEI as a foundation- they aren’t on same page and likely won’t be, but new expectation setting is necessary (especially in current climate)2) biz case for DEI in the service and hospitality industry should be clearly articulated and shared by leadership (they should all be clear in ability to communicate and tell this story)3) they are franchisee model so their ability to directly influence the individual hotels is bounded/limited. this should be acknowledged and the DEI strategy should be one that addresses this model...  ie what is in scope and realistic to impact? 4) ERGs can use refresher - next level training to move from employee, social network to business impact groups  Next steps:·         <PERSON> scheduled with us on Tues Oct 10 – she’d like to see a midsize budget vs. a cheaper option

Hi <PERSON>Thanks so much.


  1.  UB 101 - confirming you're referring to our "Intro to Managing UB" eLearning module, yes? Which by the way was updated and it looks even better now. So, 9,000 seats. What might be your budget for this type of subscription? I'd like to meet it if I can.
  2.  Then for the plants, sounds good. Topics include: Identifying <PERSON>, Microinequities/Microaggressions, and Unstereotyping.
  3.  Two microlearning modules: Managing <PERSON> in Interviews and Managing Bias in Talent Review. As you saw in the demo link, our microlearnings now come as a single digital module with video/job aid embedded (no longer two separate things). What might be your budget for this type of subscription? I'd like to meet it if I can. About how many seats would y'all need for each one?

Re: allyship, we do have this 1.5 hour virtual facilitated session:

Power of Allyship (1.5 hours, $6k/workshop)
This session explores the meaning of allyship - what it is, what it's not, and how allyship can have a tremendous impact on the workplace.  Through examples, discussion, and self-exploration, participants will discover the difference between an ally and an advocate, learn tips and skills for becoming a better ally, and consider actions they can take right away - and every day - to advocate for underrepresented or marginalized people and communities.
Other topics covered include:

  *   Why allies matter
  *   How to turn your insights into action
  *   How to "call in" and challenge microaggressions
  *   Six roles you can play as an ally
  *   <NRP> allyship
  *   Responsibilities of an ally

Please lmk when/if you'd like to move forward, and we can get an SOW started for you

Thanks, JG! <PERSON><PERSON>
(she/her)
Head of Business Development
XYZ

RE: Boost cultural literacy at ZNA in 2024
activities.body:
No worries, <PERSON>.
Below is a unit breakdown and total cost of the promotional bundle.


  *   8 Spotlights (1 hr, 1 facilitator) regularly $3,000 each ($24,000) - 20% = $19,200
  *   1 Spotlight (Indigenous People, 1 hr, 2 facilitators) regularly $4,500 - 20% = $3,600

Promotional total = $19,200 + $3600 = $22,800 if paid in 2023 - a savings of $5,700 under the regular pricing. It's almost like getting two sessions for free and your DEI culture-specific programming for 2024 is well on its way to be fleshed out.

Keep in mind that this price covers one session of each topic, but we can talk more if you find that you need multiple sessions of specific topics.

Let me know if you need additional information. We would love to earn your business. I look forward to hearing from you.

activities.subject: "Examining the Talent life Cycle Through an Intercultural Competence lens" presentation
activities.body:
HI <PERSON>,

Here is the description for the session, and its duration. Have a good weekend! <PERSON> and <PERSON>

Let’s Talk Talent: Examining the Talent Lifecycle Through an Intercultural Competence Lens (75 min: 1-hr presentation & 15 min Q&A)
Join us for a session that will give you an overview of what it takes to build and maintain a sustainable culture of inclusion throughout your Talent Processes. XYZ’s Sustainable Culture of Inclusion (SCI) Model is a framework for understanding what “success across cultures” looks like as well as a roadmap for creating it. Its grounding premise is that a sustainable, inclusive culture exists when there is: (a) a critical mass of people (especially leaders) with mindsets that are proficient in intercultural competence, as well as (b) optimized, inclusive talent & people management systems. Success across both of these dimensions produces both a positive working experience and equitable outcomes for all.

In this session, we’ll share strategies and characteristics of organizations that fall under one of three SCI Talent Systems stages: “Unstructured/Defining”, “Implementing” or “Optimizing” – around the following:

  1.  Capability / Training Infrastructure
  2.  Attracting & Recruiting Talent
  3.  Interviewing & Hiring Talent
  4.  Engaging & Retaining Talent
  5.  Managing Performance & Career Advancement
  6.  Pipeline Development & Talent Review
  7.  Measurement & Accountability

We can’t do everything, all at once, right now – but this session will provide you with a structure that you can utilize to prioritize and plan for your organization. We hope you can join us for this valuable session.


<PERSON>
(she/her)
Head of Business Development
XYZ

The workshop structure will be very similar to what you’ve seen, except we’re using a different measuring stick (the Sustainable Model of Inclusion Model), we’re using polls for each area of talent management (“Where do you think your organization is, when it comes to Attracting and Recruiting? Optimizing), and we’re collapsing some slides into a single slide for conciseness and flow (for example, embedding best-thinking topics from the ‘underrepresented groups’ advancement’ and ‘sponsorship/mentoring/hipo’ slides into a single ‘inclusive Performance Management & career advancement’ slide).

activities.subject: RE: XYZ Training Inquiry - Relationship-Building for Managers
activities.body:
Hello <PERSON>.
It’s so nice to meet you.

I see that we’ve delivered a couple of our cultural immersions, “Understanding the Black Experience in America” and “Understanding the Hispanic/Latinx Experience in the <LOCATION>” in the last couple of years.

We can certainly help with learning interventions targeted towards your senior leaders, emphasizing the importance of building relationships and trust with their team to drive inclusion and belonging.

FOR SENIOR LEADERS
Among other things, we have an excellent, accountability-oriented 2.5-hour session called “Leading with Conscious Inclusion,” which was designed for senior leaders in mind and we could tailor for SMBC. It’s a dynamic, action-oriented course that helps leaders close the gap between awareness and behavior when it comes to driving inclusion and equity in their organizations.  The session outlines three areas of development toward leading with conscious inclusion:

  1.  starting with yourself and owning it,
  2.  leading inclusive change around attracting talent, developing & advancing talent, and sustaining a culture of inclusion, and
  3.  being accountable.
Participants are given an Action Plan template in advance, and as the workshop dives into each of the three areas, they take the time to document what are actions they will take to lead with conscious inclusion - at the individual, direct report, and organization level. Videos, case studies, and breakouts make this workshop practical and relevant, where each participant walks away with a concrete Action Plan.  The workshop also includes a set of 12 Behavior Boosts that would be sent to participants once a week immediately following the workshop, as reminders and reinforcers. All of our workshops are available in person or virtually.

I also attach our Sustainable Culture of Inclusion™ model and methodology for measuring organizational mindsets and systems, then using those insights to collaborate with senior leadership to co-create a DEI roadmap and actions plans.

CULTURAL LITERACY RE: LGBTQ COMMUNITY
In terms of inclusion content focused on the <NRP> community, we do offer a cultural immersion about the LGBTQ+ community in the <LOCATION>, as well as 1- and 1.5-hour Spotlights.

Would it be okay if we set up a short meeting to hear more about what you’re thinking so we can devise best-fit recommendations? I’d like to bring in Tamara into the conversation, if she’s available, as she may be able to bring additional insights.

We’re available on the following times for a 30-min meeting (ALL TIMES ET):

Tues Dec 12 noon-1pm
Dec 13 10-11am, 2-2:30pm
Dec 14 10-noon or 2-3pm
Dec 15 noon-3pm

Best - Rebecca


<PERSON>
(she/her)
Head of Client Solutions
XYZ

activities.subject: Exclusive Invitation to Participate in XYZ's climate Interview
activities.body:
Dear Lagarette,​

Over the past 24 years of working with organizations like yours, we have learned the impact internal and external climates have on our clients doing the work to support inclusion within their organizations. These past few years have truly been filled with change, directional shifts, and future uncertainty. We understand the importance of being a true partner and are excited to announce our exclusive initiative to support our stakeholders by conducting a comprehensive climate interview and survey. The goal of the survey will be to assess how the mindsets and systems within organizations have influenced organizational climate over the past few years and impacted inclusive workplaces. The information we collect from the interview and survey will be treated with utmost confidentiality and the key takeaways will be shared with all selected participants. Based on the key takeaways, we will be sharing relevant resources, developing new content, providing action steps, and offering opportunities to learn and collaborate with peers. 

Please select the time that works best for a 30-minute interview: <URL>

Thank you for considering this opportunity. We look forward to your participation and serving as a continued resource to you and your organization.

activities.subject: Do you know of a team struggling with alignment or interpersonal issues?
activities.body:
<PERSON>

Hope you’re having a productive <US_DRIVER_LICENSE> – I can’t believe it’s almost over already!

Reaching out to see if we could help you solve a problem you or others in your org may be having. 
Is your or another team you know of, struggling with alignment, communication, interpersonal dynamics, trust, or collaboration? Are cultural issues holding this team back? <PERSON> said that “culture eats strategy for breakfast” – and we continue to see examples that prove him right. 

We’ve developed an intensive program where we help team members create the team culture they need and crave to succeed. 

This workshop is for intact teams who are struggling with issues that are interfering with their performance due to ineffective communication and/or working relationships, for example:
- Interpersonal issues
- Issues with the leader/manager 
- Poor group dynamics
- Harmful microbehaviors
The workshop content has its strong foundation, but we tailor it based on interviews, focus groups, or surveys of all team members. This is key. During the program itself, facilitators and your stakeholder together, create a “brave” space for all participants to feel heard and be engaged During the program, participants co-create a Team Charter: five to seven concrete behaviors that all team members will commit to going forward The workshop is facilitated by 2 highly skilled professionals who coach participants to arrive at solutions The workshop is designed for intact teams of up to 20 participants, conducive to deep attention to key issues that are getting in their way If this intervention sounds like something that would help remove an obstacle for your team (or another team in your org), we’d love to hear more and see if/how we could help. 

Simply reply to this email and we can send a few available timeslots for you to choose from, or you could send us your availability if you prefer.

activities.subject: Hi <PERSON> and <PERSON>! Continuing the Conversation on Inclusive Leadership at SMBC
activities.body:
Hi <PERSON> and <PERSON>,

I hope you're both doing well as we navigate this evolving DEI landscape together. I also hope your new fiscal year is off to a strong start.

I've been thinking about our conversations last year regarding senior leadership development at SMBC, particularly around building intentional development and sponsorship practices and expanding leadership definitions beyond traditional profiles. Given the continued importance of inclusive leadership-especially as organizations face increased scrutiny and need to demonstrate real impact-I'm curious how your senior leader development initiatives have progressed since we last connected.

I also noticed the recent news about SMBC's potential investment in Yes Bank in <LOCATION>, which made me think about the intercultural competence opportunities that could emerge from such cross-border partnerships.

Whether it's deepening work with your current senior leaders or exploring new intercultural development needs, I'd love to hear where your thinking has evolved. Would you be open to a brief conversation to catch up on your current priorities?

Warmly and genuinely,
<PERSON><PERSON><

activities.subject: Ideas for SMBC from XYZ
activities.body:
Hi <PERSON>, <PERSON>, and team -
How are you today?
I wanted to follow up on our discussions in the past few months about training for SMBC's senior leadership  - in particular focusing on owning their biases and automatic associations around leadership and impact, driving equity strategically around who they advocate for, develop, assign 'leadership potential' to, give access and opportunities to, see, hear, and value.
I know we also talked about the Intercultural Development Inventory (IDI) assessment as a practical tool for guided development for your leaders. Finally, you had also mentioned a need for learning around LGBTQ+ cultures.

I saw that <PERSON> has provided you with some info and cost points. In case this is useful for you too, I've compiled a few slides with workshop summaries and learning objectives, to help you communicate and socialize internally - see attached.

Please let us know if there's any other ways we can help you with your upskilling roadmap for 2024 and beyond!
<PERSON> (and <PERSON>)

<PERSON><

activities.subject: Short, high-impact sessions on the <NRP> and the <NRP> Experiences in the <LOCATION>
activities.body:
Hi Amberley,​

We’re thrilled to shared that we’re launching two brand new Spotlight sessions aimed at highlighting the experiences, influences, values and rich cultures of the <NRP> and <NRP> communities in the <LOCATION>

Our Spotlights are one-hour, interactive, deep-dive workshops are focused on the experience of being a member of these communities, and contribute to building cultural competence, inclusion skills, and a culture of belonging throughout your organization. 

☪️Spotlight on the Muslim Community (1-hr)
This session explores the complexities of being <NRP> in <LOCATION> and the simultaneously varied and shared experiences and worldviews of <LOCATION>’s <NRP> community. In this session, we unpack the concepts of culture versus religion and discuss current issues and events impacting the <NRP> experience and perspectives. Best practices for allyship and countering bias in the workplace will be shared. Session objectives:
Explore factors that have shaped the lived experiences and cultural values of the <NRP> community, including shared experiences and common influences Recognize the depth and diversity of the <NRP> community in the <LOCATION> Discuss <NRP> sentiment (especially since 9/11) and its impact on the <NRP> community Explore strategies to support and be an ally to your <NRP> colleagues and the community at large 
🔯Spotlight on the Jewish Community (1-hr)
This session introduces participants to key historical and social/cultural events that shape this community, as well as the cultural values and practices that influence the <NRP> experience. The session will also unpack stereotypes, debunk myths, and address antisemitism and its impact in the workplace today. We share best practices for supporting and providing allyship to our colleagues with the community, and how to counter antisemitic bias and microaggressions. Session objectives:
Explore factors that have shaped the lived experiences and cultural values of the <NRP> community, including shared experiences and common influences. Recognize the depth and diversity of the <NRP> community in the <LOCATION> Discuss the current state of Antisemitism and its impact on the <NRP> community. Explore strategies to support and be an ally to your <NRP> colleagues and the community at large. Below are one-pagers for each session, that you may share with your stakeholders. 

Other Spotlights that you may consider for 2024:
Being an Ally for the Asian American Community (May, AAPI Heritage Month) Spotlight on the LGBTQ+ Community (June, LGBTQ+ Pride Month) Spotlight on Persons with Disabilities (July, Disability Pride Month) Spotlight on U.S. Generations (April, August, December, anytime) Spotlight on the <NRP>/Latinx/e Community (September, Hispanic Heritage Month 9/15-10/15) Spotlight on Indigenous People in <LOCATION> (October, Indigenous Peoples’ Day or November, Native American Heritage Month) Spotlight on the U.S. Veterans Community (November, Veterans’ Day) If you have any questions and would like to connect, please let me what days work best and I’ll send over some times.

activities.subject: FW: Training Pricing Request
Training Pricing Request
activities.body:
Hi <PERSON>,
Checking in on a Monday morning.  Can we touch base this week?  I wanted to follow up on the NDA.  And I believe I owe you pricing information.  My apologies, I thought it had gone out.  Keep in mind, we work with clients and have flexibility to customize as needed.
You asked about:

  *   Building a Culture of Inclusion (BCI) for Leaders- This is a 4-hour session and includes the IDI Group Debrief- $16,500
  *   BCI without the IDI- is typically a 3-hour session and costs $10,000
  *   Developing Inclusively- Black Talent is a 3-hour session and costs $10,000.
  *   IDI, Individual is $500/pp.
  *   All IDIs have an individual $125 Administration fee for the tool to be administered.

This week I am available Wednesday and most afternoons.  Look forward to speaking with you soon.

Cheers~

<PERSON>
(She/Her/Hers)
Senior Consultant
XYZ

activities.note_body: Feb 1, 2024 CALL NOTESClient participants:<PERSON>, D&I Program Lead. VP of DEI. Since 2020, orig from <LOCATION>, in <LOCATION> for 13 years, we used XYZ during my first year here. Experienced UTBE in 2020, me and <PERSON> are cool, big fan of XYZ. Didn’t move fwd with UTHE, were a pilot for UTBE part <URL>ndra <PERSON>, <PERSON> and Head of D&I for <LOCATION> (includes <LOCATION>), started in <URL><PERSON> ("LG"), Director and Diversity Program Manager, since 2020, prev at Morgan Stanley and Lehman, JP Morgan, Talent Acq and DEI. ERGs, campus teams.<PERSON>, Associate – D&I, new, prev at Georgia Bank, based in <LOCATION> but live in <LOCATION>, background is <LOCATION> and BOS is <URL>W part: AWB, <PERSON>, <PERSON>-call background:This used to be <PERSON>’s and <PERSON>’s client12/1/23: <PERSON> (D&I Program Lead) wrote to <PERSON> (& Emani): “We want to start exploring more trainings that are targeted towards our senior leaders. What kind of offerings does XYZ have for that? We’d like to look into offering something that can emphasize the importance of building relationships and trust with their team to create more inclusion. We’d also like to get more information on <NRP> trainings.”  <PERSON> (Exec Dir & Head of Inclusion & Diversity) and Lagarette Gamble (Director & Diversity Program Mgr) were copied on this emailChuck copied me on his reply to them and introduced me and TamaraI replied, acknowledging they’d bought UTBE and UTH/LE from us in the past, let them know have an immersion and a spotlight on the <NRP> community. Also sent a description of our “Leading with Conscious Inclusion” workshop and info on our SCI approach (see attached).12/8/23: I sent them a locked pdf of the LCI content, and described the prework for them, and also I expanded on the SCI discovery process.<PERSON> been trying to set up a meeting – at first it was scheduled for Jan 17 but they rescheduled.Leadership trainingOur new fiscal year starts April 1, 2024·         <PERSON> and below are done (training on this).  We want to hit the top – sponsorship – women of color, POC, women of other races, as a sponsor I have to build trust, the power of speaking about you when you’re not in the room. How do you develop trust? I’m going to put my social capital on them, will they listen to me.·         We’re a <NRP> bank, don’t have a lot of Black people here. We have one Black woman in <LOCATION>.·         AWB: What are you hoping to influence? What are you hoping to improve and influence, using sponsorship?·         <PERSON>: It’s beyond sponsorship, it’s ppl who make decisions that leave out people who are ‘different’. They tend to be white or <NRP> males. We have <NRP> leaders who are not <NRP> who are also overlooked.  Black and <NRP> talent too. Not that many. And how do we get these leaders to make different decisions when it comes to getting these folks in the door, hiring, through campuses. Judging people as ‘not taking the initiative’ – not realizing it’s cultural. Not making assumptions about talent. They say, ‘Managers don’t have time to develop this talent’·         <PERSON>: can’t find the talent, don’t have time to develop. That should never be an excuse. You need to coach, develop, and give feedback to talent.·         AWB: are there any structural markers that define success or DEI strategy?·         <PERSON>: help them find a way to develop their talent strategically, as they do to develop their business. Do your direct reports feel comfortable coming to you? Are you listening? Are they providing actionable feedback? Are they providing development opptys, key visible assignments? (RP note: ‘Developing Talent Inclusively’, tweak it to apply to any cultural group?)  ·         Our L&D dept offers cultural training, eg dimensions of culture·         <PERSON> talked about the IDI and how it’s often used with senior leaders, also brought up BCI·         <LOCATION> – looking for a mindset change. They’re using proxies – like Harvard, elite schools. What an SMBC employee ‘should’ look like. That perpetuates bias. Open conversations, building trust, intentional development opptys, setting people up for success, expanding what ‘leader’ is.·         RP: Start with outcomes – how will be measure success? Tie that to the initiative. Have each leader come up with a SMART goal for themselves (with your guidance). Action planning.·         AWB: what would you guys like us to do next?·         <PERSON> – send us more information on what we talked about today. We need to talk about the timeline.·         RP note: do you have data (engagement surveys, heading particular project or clients, data on variations in promotions or hiring, time it takes to promote).·         <PERSON>: Creating social value – empowerment, inequity, integrity…. AWB asked how it’s being presented. Needs to be positioned as how it’s creating social value. That is of business value.·         Who should we email? <PERSON> says emails can include everyone.·         Ideas: Developing Inclusively, Leading with Conscious Inclusion – reminded them I’d sent them a sample of it, encourage to review.·         <NRP> immersion, Spotlight. List of Spotlights!Next steps:·        Info on IDI·        Info on <NRP> immersion, all Spotlights·        BCI, Developing Inclusively

activities.subject: RE: Temporary reduced prices: XYZ & Hexagon digital courses
activities.body:
Hi Isabelle,

Thank you for meeting with us last week. I wanted to provide you with some updates to some questions you had asked.

First, yes we are able to shorten the e-learnings  (e.g., split them in half), and we are also able to work on harmonizing the "look and feel". This would involve additional costs as you can imagine, and we're working on seeing what would be.

Regarding the length of the e-learnings, I also wanted to remind you that the self-paced option allows the learner to pause at any point during the session, then re-enter at a later time exactly where they left off, which provides some nice flexibility depending on the learner’s pace and bandwidth.

We’ll get back to you soon with the additional costs of the above. If you have any other questions in the meantime, feel free to reach out!

activities.subject: WSJ article "Corporate America Tweaks Diversity Initiatives" & my analysis
activities.body:
Hi Isabelle,

As you continue to be an SME for Hexagon’s top leaders, I wanted to send you this article which you may have already seen. It’s pretty short, and gives language about the current challenges in corporate <LOCATION> (which have spread to many other parts of the world, unfortunately). You can help your stakeholders make sense of it.

Here are my thoughts. It seems to me the two main points that are being pushed back against are:

  1.  Hiring or promotion ‘quotas’ (which is something that XYZ or any other DEI professional I know or have worked with has ever recommended) and
  2.  ‘Blaming’ white populations by, for example, calling people ‘white supremacists’ or stating something ridiculous like all white people are racist.

Neither of the points above are part of what achieving DEI is all about. Inclusive practices are alive and well, and I think that most organizations understand that there’s no going back.

<URL>
