activities.note_body: 2/28/23 Call notesIsabelle Welter, Global Talent & Learning Manager (sits in Munich)Pedro and RPBackground Refresher:Hexagon engages in sensor, software and autonomous solutions. It provides information technologies solutions that drive productivity and quality across geospatial and industrial enterprise applications.  24k employees worldwide, decentralized, five divisions operating on their own, even each unit is operating pretty <URL>n’t have a companywide DEI strategy, have statements but then it’s up to each area to <URL>ke to launch a series of eLearnings in 2024 to raise awareness – across the company.We’re clear it’s only for awareness, I would like more but at least it’s a starting point. Microaggressions, how to be an ally, cultural <URL>parate track for leaders, around inclusive <URL>portant that it works for a global workforce, not too one sided in <URL>anslation into 14 non English language – CHS, <NRP>, <NRP> <LOCATION>, <NRP>, <NRP>, PTB, <LOCATION>, <LOCATION>, <NRP>, <NRP>, <NRP>, <NRP>, <NRP>, <URL>ople are getting used to short things, so is it possible to cut them into pieces – or at least can come back to them?How often do you update content? We keep an eye on the content, and make updates when we feel examples are dated, new research has emerged, new examples are needed, etc.  About half of all employees (ab 12.5k) are people managers – team size varies - 3 or 25. On 12/21, we sent Isabelle this:OPTION 1: Full Digital Library Access (13 modules) Subscription*8 e-Learnings*Introduction to Managing Unconscious Bias (IMUB) – For everyoneCulture & Identity (C&I) – For everyonePracticing Inclusion (PI) – For everyoneFostering Collaboration (FC) – For managers & leadersManaging with Intercultural Competence (MIC) – For managers & leadersHiring & Promoting Top Talent (HPTT) – For managers & leadersEvaluating Talent <PERSON> (<PERSON>) – For managers & leadersEmbedding Inclusion (EI) – For managers & leaders*5 MicroLearnings: For managers & leaders*Managing Bias in Recruiting (MBR)Managing Bias in Hiring (MBH)Managing <PERSON> in Interviewing (MBI)Managing Bias in Performance Reviews (MBPR)Managing <PERSON> in Talent Reviews (MBTR)= $80,000 (annual, first year extended to 18 mos – unlimited; second year 15% off, third 20% off)Year 1 ($80K)   |  Year 2 (15% disc.): $68K  |  Year 3 (20% disc): $64K OPTION 2: Unlimited, Perpetual Site License (Outright Purchase)$40,000 each eLearning course (MicroLearnings are not delivered in a perpetual way)·         RP NOTE ON NEW PRICING SINCE THIS EMAIL WAS SENT:o   $30k per eLearning if using for all employees, $20k per eLearning if for ppl managers only. 5% discount when you buy 3; 10% discount when you buy 4; 15% discount when you buy 5 or more.  $4.5k per translation.o   Also, ML’s are $12k/module or $10k/module when buying all. $3k per translation (same as quoted below). OPTION 3: Al-a-Carte SubscriptionEx. formula=$25K for first eLearning and $15K each add’lIMUB eLearning for 24k employees = $25,000 per yearC&I eLearning for 24k employees = $15,000 per yearF&C for 24k employees = $15,000 per yearMIC for 4k people managers = $10,000 per yearHPTT for 4k people managers = $10,000 per yearETI for 4k people managers = $10,000 per yearMBR, MBH, MBI, MBPR, MBTR for 4k people managers = $15,000 per yearTOTAL PER YEAR = $100,000/yearMax size of files: If you are uploading separate courses into your LMS to host, each file would range from 1MB to 5MB in size. Note that in our full digital library you would receive 13 individual SCORM files (total size of all 13 combined would be 13MB – 65MB).Languages: Attached the of available eLearning and microlearning translated languages. Languages are considered a seat license and could be accounted in the total learner number above. eLearnings $5K/language and MicroLearnings are an additional $3K/language.  ========================================================================================2/28/24 CALL NOTES ·         Contentwise it resonated well. Two questions –o   Options to cut eLearnings into pieces into 10-15 min chunks, people complained about length of 20-25 minutes.o   The look and feel is different, can we harmonize? We have had plans to do this, and if it’s a dealbreaker or important to them, then we can <URL><PERSON> to reach out to <PERSON> and <PERSON> ab the two items above·         Two other vendors – LRN (coming from field of compliance) and Global Diversity Practice. Next steps:·         Need to present to HR leadership team, to present the options and see who to go with in a meeting the week of March 18th. The hope is that they will make a decision that week. They might have additional questions. ·         Offered to send her slides or anything that would help in her presentation.

activities.subject: DEI Services Proposals from XYZ
activities.body:
[cid:<URL>g@01DA239D.70B74EB0]
Hi, <PERSON> –

Thaks for reaching out to us and for taking the time to describe your inclusion needs with my colleagues <PERSON> and <PERSON>. I’m sorry I wasn’t able to attend, I was in the midst of facilitating a session during that time. I’m looking forward to meeting you soon.
We’ve put together two proposal options based on our understanding of your needs:
Choice Hotels seeks a partner to help upskill their leaders around driving a culture of inclusion in their teams and throughout the company. A culture of inclusion is one that engenders trust and mutual respect, where leaders actively listen and develop authentic relationships with their team members, and where employees aren't afraid to speak up and are comfortable bringing their full selves (and their ideas) to their roles at Choice Hotels - whether people are working onsite or virtually.
Below is a quick overview of the learning journey we envision for Choice Hotels' leaders:

  *   Phase 1: Keynote delivery during December's Diversity Council gathering (with prework).
  *   Phase 2:  "Building a Culture of Inclusion for Leaders" pilot (2-hr session, virtual, with prework).  Pilot attendees to be a diverse (function, tenure, age, gender, race/ethnicity, abilities, etc.) group of leaders, who can provide feedback on the session.
  *   Phase 3, option 1: Train-the-Trainer for internal facilitators. Includes site license to program, facilitator notes, and PPT.
  *   Phase 3, option 2: XYZ facilitates workshop for Choice Hotels leaders.We so appreciate your coming back to us after your prior experiences with XYZ, and are certainly grateful for the time you took to give us an overview of your Diversity, Equity, and Inclusion goals.
Further detail is included within the proposals. We send you two options:
Proposal #1 includes Phases 1 and 2 above, plus Phase 3, option 1 (Train-the-Trainer option)
Proposal #2 also includes Phases 1 and 2, and Phase 3, option 2 (XYZ facilitates workshops).
Corinne, we look forward to meeting with you on Tuesday to walk you through these, and we are of course open to other options and can get creative if necessary. Our goal is to respond swiftly, make adjustments, and get you what you need to ensure alignment and move forward.

Have a good weekend and we’ll touch base next week.

activities.subject: SAMPLE of Human-centric Leadership workshop
activities.body:
Hi Corinne,
Happy holiday season!
We put together the attached as just a sample of what the session could look like.

Please note that it has not been graphic-designed, so it’s not as ‘pretty’ as it would be for your leaders.

For each Human-Centric Leadership Behavior, we’d define it, have an activity that has them thinking/brainstorming about how they can demonstrate that Behavior in their roles (and why it’s important to them and to Choice). And we’ll of course have some suggestions for them, as well as a takeaway. Throughout the workshop we’ll use breakouts, polls, videos, and images to make points captivating and memorable.

We’ve grouped some of the Behaviors that are similar in theme, to make the program move a bit faster:

  *   (by itself and as the thing that acts as a foundation): Connects personal values with the organization’s for meaning and purpose
  *   Provides community and connection AND Leverages empathy and flexibility (two Behaviors grouped together)
  *   Enables & provides team with opportunities for accomplishment, growth, and career mobility AND Offers recognition, appreciation, and positivity (two Behaviors grouped together)
  *   Prioritizes psychological safety and well-being AND Facilitates a sense of belonging (two Behaviors grouped together)
Anyway, the above is just some initial brainstorming we did – the final product would of course be well thought out from an instructional design and content standpoint.

Looking forward to hearing from you in 2024.

Best!
<PERSON><PERSON>
(she/her)
Head of Client Solutions
XYZ
Please note XYZ will be closed for winter break between December 25th through January 1st.

activities.body:
>
>
>
>
>[cid:<URL>g@01DA0828.926222F0]
>Hi, Corinne -
>
>Thaks for reaching out to us and for taking the time to describe your inclusion needs with my colleagues <PERSON> and <PERSON>. I'm sorry I wasn't able to attend, I was in the midst of facilitating a session during that time. I'm looking forward to meeting you soon.
>We've put together two proposal options based on our understanding of your needs:
>Choice Hotels seeks a partner to help upskill their leaders around driving a culture of inclusion in their teams and throughout the company. A culture of inclusion is one that engenders trust and mutual respect, where leaders actively listen and develop authentic relationships with their team members, and where employees aren't afraid to speak up and are comfortable bringing their full selves (and their ideas) to their roles at Choice Hotels - whether people are working onsite or virtually.
>Below is a quick overview of the learning journey we envision for Choice Hotels' leaders:
>
>  *   Phase 1: Keynote delivery during December's Diversity Council gathering (with prework).
>  *   Phase 2:  "Building a Culture of Inclusion for Leaders" pilot (2-hr session, virtual, with prework).  Pilot attendees to be a diverse (function, tenure, age, gender, race/ethnicity, abilities, etc.) group of leaders, who can provide feedback on the session.
>  *   Phase 3, option 1: Train-the-Trainer for internal facilitators. Includes site license to program, facilitator notes, and PPT.
>  *   Phase 3, option 2: XYZ facilitates workshop for Choice Hotels leaders.We so appreciate your coming back to us after your prior experiences with XYZ, and are certainly grateful for the time you took to give us an overview of your Diversity, Equity, and Inclusion goals.
>Further detail is included within the proposals. We send you two options:
>Proposal #1 includes Phases 1 and 2 above, plus Phase 3, option 1 (Train-the-Trainer option)
>Proposal #2 also includes Phases 1 and 2, and Phase 3, option 2 (XYZ facilitates workshops).
>Corinne, we look forward to meeting with you on Tuesday to walk you through these, and we are of course open to other options and can get creative if necessary. Our goal is to respond swiftly, make adjustments, and get you what you need to ensure alignment and move forward.
>
>Have a good weekend and we'll touch base next week.
>
>All the best,
><PERSON>
>
>
>

activities.subject: Do you know of a team struggling with alignment or interpersonal issues?
activities.body:
Dear Corinne,​

Hope you’re having a productive <US_DRIVER_LICENSE> – I can’t believe it’s almost over already!

I know we're currently in communication, just wanted to let you know about a new XYZ offering.

<PERSON> said that “culture eats strategy for breakfast” – and we continue to see examples that prove him right. 

We’ve developed an intensive program where we help team members create the team culture they need and crave to succeed. 

This workshop is for intact teams who are struggling with issues that are interfering with their performance due to ineffective communication and/or working relationships, for example:
- Interpersonal issues
- Issues with the leader/manager 
- Poor group dynamics
- Harmful microbehaviors
The workshop content has its strong foundation, but we tailor it based on interviews, focus groups, or surveys of all team members. This is key. During the program itself, facilitators and your stakeholder together, create a “brave” space for all participants to feel heard and be engaged During the program, participants co-create a Team Charter: five to seven concrete behaviors that all team members will commit to going forward The workshop is facilitated by 2 highly skilled professionals who coach participants to arrive at solutions The workshop is designed for intact teams of up to 20 participants, conducive to deep attention to key issues that are getting in their way If this intervention sounds like something that would help remove an obstacle for your team (or another team in your org), we’d love to hear more and see if/how we could help. 

Simply reply to this email and we can send a few available timeslots for you to choose from, or you could send us your availability if you prefer.

<PERSON>

activities.subject: RE: SAMPLE of Human-centric Leadership workshop
activities.body:
Thank you so very much, <PERSON>. And congratulations to your team and your new hire! I'll wait to hear from you, after y'all have had a chance to catch up and strategize a bit. : )

In the meantime, I'm sure you have seen the NYT article below, which came out last weekend. We all know that people exist who have these views but it's still a little shocking to hear them out loud, see them written out in documents and emails!

My perspective is we must continue to ensure that everyone understands and feels included by cultural competence and DEI efforts (which of course includes straight, white, nondisabled white men and women). And we must continue to firmly stand for equity and for taking steps to proactively understand each other's culturally influenced work styles, so that we can not only accept and learn from each other, but also use that insight to continue to innovate and cultivate inclusive high performance in ourselves and in our teams.

Explore this gift article from The New York Times. You can read it for free without a subscription.
'<LOCATION> Is Under Attack': Inside the Anti-D.E.I. Crusade
The backlash against "wokeism" has led a growing number of states to ban D.E.I. programs at public universities. Thousands of emails and other documents reveal the playbook - and grievances - behind one strand of the anti-D.E.I. campaign.

activities.subject: Short, high-impact sessions on the <NRP> and the <NRP> Experiences in the <LOCATION>
activities.body:
Hi Corinne,​

We’re thrilled to shared that we’re launching two brand new Spotlight sessions aimed at highlighting the experiences, influences, values and rich cultures of the <NRP> and <NRP> communities in the <LOCATION>

Our Spotlights are one-hour, interactive, deep-dive workshops are focused on the experience of being a member of these communities, and contribute to building cultural competence, inclusion skills, and a culture of belonging throughout your organization. 

☪️Spotlight on the Muslim Community (1-hr)
This session explores the complexities of being <NRP> in <LOCATION> and the simultaneously varied and shared experiences and worldviews of <LOCATION>’s <NRP> community. In this session, we unpack the concepts of culture versus religion and discuss current issues and events impacting the <NRP> experience and perspectives. Best practices for allyship and countering bias in the workplace will be shared. Session objectives:
Explore factors that have shaped the lived experiences and cultural values of the <NRP> community, including shared experiences and common influences Recognize the depth and diversity of the <NRP> community in the <LOCATION> Discuss <NRP> sentiment (especially since 9/11) and its impact on the <NRP> community Explore strategies to support and be an ally to your <NRP> colleagues and the community at large 
🔯Spotlight on the Jewish Community (1-hr)
This session introduces participants to key historical and social/cultural events that shape this community, as well as the cultural values and practices that influence the <NRP> experience. The session will also unpack stereotypes, debunk myths, and address antisemitism and its impact in the workplace today. We share best practices for supporting and providing allyship to our colleagues with the community, and how to counter antisemitic bias and microaggressions. Session objectives:
Explore factors that have shaped the lived experiences and cultural values of the <NRP> community, including shared experiences and common influences. Recognize the depth and diversity of the <NRP> community in the <LOCATION> Discuss the current state of Antisemitism and its impact on the <NRP> community. Explore strategies to support and be an ally to your <NRP> colleagues and the community at large. Below are one-pagers for each session, that you may share with your stakeholders. 

Other Spotlights that you may consider for 2024:
Being an Ally for the Asian American Community (May, AAPI Heritage Month) Spotlight on the LGBTQ+ Community (June, LGBTQ+ Pride Month) Spotlight on Persons with Disabilities (July, Disability Pride Month) Spotlight on U.S. Generations (April, August, December, anytime) Spotlight on the <NRP>/Latinx/e Community (September, Hispanic Heritage Month 9/15-10/15) Spotlight on Indigenous People in <LOCATION> (October, Indigenous Peoples’ Day or November, Native American Heritage Month) Spotlight on the U.S. Veterans Community (November, Veterans’ Day) If you have any questions and would like to connect, please let me what days work best and I’ll send over some times.

activities.subject: Exclusive Invitation to Participate in XYZ's climate Interview
activities.body:
Dear Corinne,​

Over the past 24 years of working with organizations like yours, we have learned the impact internal and external climates have on our clients doing the work to support inclusion within their organizations. These past few years have truly been filled with change, directional shifts, and future uncertainty. We understand the importance of being a true partner and are excited to announce our exclusive initiative to support our stakeholders by conducting a comprehensive climate interview and survey. The goal of the survey will be to assess how the mindsets and systems within organizations have influenced organizational climate over the past few years and impacted inclusive workplaces. The information we collect from the interview and survey will be treated with utmost confidentiality and the key takeaways will be shared with all selected participants. Based on the key takeaways, we will be sharing relevant resources, developing new content, providing action steps, and offering opportunities to learn and collaborate with peers. 

Please select the time that works best for a 30-minute interview: <URL>

Thank you for considering this opportunity. We look forward to your participation and serving as a continued resource to you and your organization.

activities.subject: WSJ article "Corporate America Tweaks Diversity Initiatives" & my analysis
activities.body:
Hi Corinne, I hope all is well with you.

As you continue to be an SME for Choice Hotels' top leaders, I wanted to send you this article which you may have already seen. It's pretty short, and gives language about the current challenges in corporate <LOCATION>. You can help your stakeholders make sense of it.

Here are my thoughts. It seems to me the two main points that are being pushed back against are:

  1.  Hiring or promotion 'quotas' (which is something that XYZ or any other DEI professional I know or have worked with has ever recommended) and
  2.  'Blaming' white populations by, for example, calling people 'white supremacists' or stating something ridiculous like all white people are racist.

Neither of the points above are part of what achieving DEI is all about. Inclusive practices are alive and well, and I think that most organizations understand that there's no going back.

<URL>

[CAUTION] This email comes from an external organization. Do not click links or open attachments unless you recognize the sender and know the content is safe.
Hi <PERSON>. My name is <PERSON>, and I’m a longtime consultant, facilitator and content developer at XYZ.  <PERSON> is on my team.

We’d love to meet with you to discuss further, but yes we do offer workshops on intercultural competence (the ability to navigate your own and other people’s worldviews & interpretations to be more effective) for leaders.

We often use the Intercultural Development Inventory® to underpin skill development, especially with leaders.

About the Intercultural Development Inventory®
The Intercultural Development Inventory® is a 50-item psychometric assessment. It is arguably the most scientifically rigorous and statistically validated tool for assessing and building intercultural competence,  the capability to shift cultural perspective and appropriately adapt behavior to cultural differences and commonalities. The assessment and research behind the IDI explores why some people are more effective navigating and bridging cultures than others. The tool is unique in how it quantifies the subjective ‘experience’ of cultural differences and provides a snapshot of the developmental process involved in building intercultural competence (a vital skill that feeds equity and inclusion) over time. The IDI helps people see that there are different ways of processing cultural differences and commonalities that are not based on our character or who we are as a person but on our experiences, our contexts, and what we’ve been taught - and that there are things we can do to move further along the continuum.

We can certainly provide a 2-3 hour session on intercultural competence that connects with your objectives, in the context of your Emerging Leadership Programme.

Please let us know when would be a good day/time to meet. Both of us are located in <LOCATION> ET timezone.

Hope you have a wonderful holiday season!

activities.subject: WSJ article "Corporate America Tweaks Diversity Initiatives" & my analysis
activities.body:
Hi <PERSON>,

As you continue to be a SME for Superbet’s top leaders, I wanted to send you this article which you may have already seen. It’s pretty short, and gives language about the current challenges in corporate <LOCATION> (which are spreading to other parts of the world, unfortunately). You can help your stakeholders make sense of it.

Here are my thoughts. It seems to me the two main points that are being pushed back against are:

  1.  Hiring or promotion ‘quotas’ (which is something that XYZ or any other DEI professional I know or have worked with has ever recommended) and
  2.  ‘Blaming’ white populations by, for example, calling people ‘white supremacists’ or stating something ridiculous like all white people are racist.

Neither of the points above are part of what achieving DEI is all about. Inclusive practices are alive and well, and I think that most organizations understand that there’s no going back.

<URL><<URL>>

Have a terrific weekend,
<PERSON><PERSON>
(she/her) Why pronouns matter<

activities.note_body: 1/19/24 CALL NOTES-DISCOVERYClient participants: <PERSON>, DEI LeadXYZ participants: RP, PedroPre-call <PERSON> (requests from emails, other <LOCATION> webform on 12/13/23:  Hi, I'm from Superbet Group, Betting & Gambling company headquartered in <LOCATION>, and with offices in other 13 countries. As we're rolling out our Emerging Leadership Programme for a cohort of 26 leaders, we're interested in integrating a brief workshop (2-3 hours <PERSON>) focused on Cultural Intelligence. During my research, I came across your website, which I found impressive. I'd like to inquire if you provide solutions of this nature. Thank you, AlinaSuperbet the leading B2C online sports betting and gaming operator in <LOCATION>. Some of the categories provided by the platform include pre match and live sports betting, live casinos, lottery, slot games, table games, bingo, and more. They quickly grew in <LOCATION> (<LOCATION>) and launched <LOCATION> in 2023. They’re looking to expand internationally, especially into <NRP> markets. It offers 24/7 multilingual support to customers via chat. Their core offices are in <LOCATION> (HQ); <LOCATION>, <LOCATION>; <LOCATION>, <LOCATION>; <LOCATION>;  and <LOCATION>. They have satellite offices in <LOCATION>; <LOCATION>; <LOCATION>, <LOCATION>; <LOCATION>, <LOCATION>; <LOCATION>, <LOCATION>; <LOCATION>, <LOCATION>; and DublinCALL NOTES:Both retail and online in <LOCATION>, around 3,700 employees in <LOCATION>, mostly shop operators. We’re going to focus on the corporate folks, not the shop operators, they have their own development <URL>unched <LOCATION>, but new and not in our radar yet bec still in <URL>quired a company in <LOCATION> two years ago. Emerging <URL>talina a colleague created this ELP for 27 leaders Participants are C-3 (C minus 3), located almost in all these locations, mostly BE, <LOCATION>, <LOCATION> and PO. Managing teams of different diversity dimensions. Each leader can have anywhere from say 5 to 70 people reporting into <URL> in a hybrid environment, so manage via Zoom, etc.We have oppty to travel but it didn’t give us an oppty to get to know the cultures <URL>r example, offering feedback – I had a Brit very senior leader, he thought he delivered straightforward constructive feedback to one of his direct reports. The person who received the feedback came back and said the feedback was all good and didn’t ‘get the message’ about the critical feedback (<NRP> expect directness and <LOCATION> was too diplomatic – relative to one another). And it goes the other way too. With directness being experienced as <URL>, we thought a training ab this – we know that this is a neverending topic, but this will show that we’re all different, no right or wrong, but there’s a way to <URL>e ELP contains learning about different topics, e.g., leading self, leading others, etc. and would like to include 2-3 hr session on cultural intelligence.RP walked through BCI for everyone and talked about <LOCATION>: We’re hesitant about the assessment bc they’ve gone through a lot of change, plus many other assessments are being given. Not sure leaders would be open to the IDI right now, maybe later. I have mixed feelings.RP Note: I recommend substituting Truth/Peace with another one that better resonate with intl <URL>talina wanted to have a 3 hour session but they said ‘we don’t have enough time’. So it was decided they’ll sit in on a 2-hr on Tues, then a 1 hour of reflection on Friday. Give them thought questions on Tues, come in on Friday to discuss. Open <URL>s are 3/19 and 3/21.  Maybe starting 1pm <NRP> time. Will get back to us on <URL>xt steps:·        Put together a proposal with this framework. We’re focused on the model, the learnings, the objectives - without being too theoretical. Not so much focused on the $.·        Schedule a new meeting with Catalina, she’ll share with us more details about her expectations, ask questions. We have legal requirements.·        By end of next week or beg of following week we need to have a final decision. Because legal stuff will take us one month…·        No budget, not going to negotiate. We’re going to be honest.·        Send proposal by early next week.·        One of our colleagues recommended us, <PERSON> (she used to work at Ubisoft).

1st Call1/19/24Attendees: AlinaXYZ Attendees: Pedro & RebeccaHQ in <LOCATION> people at HQ.Learning opportunity for those at <LOCATION> locations she mentioned they have expanded too. <LOCATION>, <LOCATION> locations, <LOCATION>. 2 years ago, they acquired a company in <LOCATION>.Leadership programEmerging leadership program, 27 leaders. Among all these locations, <LOCATION>, <LOCATION>, <LOCATION> and <LOCATION>. (Croatia)Challenges, they work in hybrid environmentCritical conversations can be misunderstood. Important to deliver those the right <URL>o straight forward, rising voice, no sense of humor, these are the type of things that she's heard in her org. # for targeted audience? Virtual facilitated trainings? Budget? No budget in mind.Timeline? March to be delivered.RP goes over the DIN model. How this can apply to their <URL>ing a culture of inclusion, 2 hour course. RP recommended. Catalina is there learning architect 3 hour session on a weekly basis, takes them away from work.2 hours on Tuesday, 1 hour to reflect on Friday. One session on Tuesday, another on Friday. 2 in total. 19th of March, and 21st of <URL>xt steps: Send proposal for DIN Model and Culture of Inclusion facilitated training <URL>llow up meeting with Catalina. How did you hear about us? One of their colleagues recommended us. They worked with us in the past. (Anca Lazaroiu)26 or 27 people leaders. activities.subject: Anti-bias Interventions: Proposals from XYZ
activities.body:
[cid:ii_18e0c15f6df4cff312]
<PERSON>, <PERSON>, <PERSON>, and <PERSON> –

It was a pleasure meeting with you last week.
We appreciate your taking the time to give us an overview of your plans to deepen your inclusive hiring practices.
We send you two proposals: one that covers the hiring anti-bias learning interventions, and a separate one with the performance review/evaluation anti-bias tools (since <PERSON>, you had asked about those too). Thought keeping them separate might be helpful as you socialize internally:

  1.  Proposal: Anti-Bias Interventions (Hiring)<<URL>>
  2.  Proposal: Anti-Bias Interventions (Performance Evaluation)<<URL>>

There is no need to sign anything, these are simply proposals for your review. If/when you decide to engage us, we will write up a formal Statement of Work containing the scope of work for your signature.

Uber team, if the above is only almost right for your needs, then we look forward to hearing from you that we can respond swiftly, make adjustments, and get you what you need to ensure alignment!

We’d also be proud to have you as a client! We’ll check back with you next week.

activities.subject: Digital course demo links from XYZ
activities.body:
Hi <PERSON>, <PERSON>, and <PERSON> (and I’m sorry we didn’t get to meet you on Friday, <PERSON>, looking forward to that in the future!),

It was great to meet you on Friday and thanks for walking us through your needs. We’re working on a proposal for you but in the meantime I wanted to provide you with the links to the digital courses and microlearnings that we talked about so you can start reviewing them. Please ensure that only members of your decision making team review these.

The links will ask for your email addresses.

ANTI-BIAS LEARNING INTERVENTIONS: HIRING

eLearnings: Self-paced scalable programs which include narration, onscreen and downloadable content, quizzes, short writing activities, and other exercises that allow learners to pause, reflect and apply. Our eLearnings have been designed such that learners can’t skip sections or leave the program running in the background. Each module requires active participation and full completion


  *   “Hiring & Promoting Top Talent”<<URL>>: This course explores the hidden bias in talent acquisition and development. It includes insights into how assessing for ‘cultural fit’ impacts the organization’s ability to attract and hire culturally diverse top talent, and build and support a robust and diverse talent pipeline. Participants also explore how mentoring, staffing teams, key assignments, and coaching across cultures drive the readiness of top talent for their next opportunity.

<PERSON>: Short, digital, impactful learning tools offer reinforcements for participants to access at the point of decision or needed action. Such "in the moment" nudges help sustain behavioral change, facilitating systemic transformation.


  *   “Managing <PERSON> in Hiring<<URL>>”: Unconscious biases can derail our best efforts to be objective and accurate when it comes to hiring the best person for the job. Is bias at play when we hire for ‘cultural fit’? Are we interpreting similarities with candidates as evidence that they will be successful in this role? Are groupthink or expectations about people of certain backgrounds limiting our ability to find the best candidates? This course allows us to become aware of our biases so that we can attend to them and interrupt them while evaluating and selecting diverse top talent.


  *   “Managing <PERSON> in <NRP>>>”: Unconscious biases can derail our best efforts to interview candidates of all backgrounds objectively and accurately. Are we letting our commonalities with a candidate influence our perception of their skills or their ‘fit’? Are our perceptions of a candidate being unconsciously skewed based on preconceived judgments we formed from information on their résumé? Are we unconsciously changing the questions we ask to certain candidates? This course invites you to look for and mitigate unconscious bias that may be hampering your best intentions when interviewing diverse job candidates.


ANTI-BIAS LEARNING INTERVENTIONS: PERFORMANCE EVALUATION


  *   eLearning: “Evaluating Talent Inclusively<<URL>>”: This program provides managers powerful examples of how bias can impact performance evaluation. Activities highlight meaningful examples of how to challenge bias in ourselves and one another and ensure that talent is evaluated objectively rather than by relying on mental models or shortcuts. Participants are given the opportunity to recognize and interrupt bias when evaluating performance, as well as when making promotion decisions based on that evaluation.


  *   Microlearning: “Managing Bias in Performance Reviews<<URL>>”: Unconscious biases can derail our best efforts to be objective and accurate when it comes to evaluating performance. Are we inadvertently giving higher ratings to employees who are more ‘like us’? What are we doing to ensure our evaluation process is consistent across our entire team? Are we sure we’re aware of the variety of work or projects each team member has worked on, or are we basing our evaluation only on those projects we know about? Are our expectations about a person skewing how we see them? Managing Unconscious Bias in Performance Reviews invites you to look for and mitigate biases in evaluating performance.


You’ll hear back from us by the end of the week!

Please ensure that only members of your decision making team review these.

The links will ask for your email addresses.

ANTI-BIAS LEARNING INTERVENTIONS: HIRING

eLearnings: Self-paced scalable programs which include narration, onscreen and downloadable content, quizzes, short writing activities, and other exercises that allow learners to pause, reflect and apply. Our eLearnings have been designed such that learners can't skip sections or leave the program running in the background. Each module requires active participation and full completion


  *   "Hiring & Promoting Top Talent"<<URL>>: This course explores the hidden bias in talent acquisition and development. It includes insights into how assessing for 'cultural fit' impacts the organization's ability to attract and hire culturally diverse top talent, and build and support a robust and diverse talent pipeline. Participants also explore how mentoring, staffing teams, key assignments, and coaching across cultures drive the readiness of top talent for their next opportunity.

<PERSON>: Short, digital, impactful learning tools offer reinforcements for participants to access at the point of decision or needed action. Such "in the moment" nudges help sustain behavioral change, facilitating systemic transformation.


  *   "Managing <PERSON> in Hiring<<URL>>": Unconscious biases can derail our best efforts to be objective and accurate when it comes to hiring the best person for the job. Is bias at play when we hire for 'cultural fit'? Are we interpreting similarities with candidates as evidence that they will be successful in this role? Are groupthink or expectations about people of certain backgrounds limiting our ability to find the best candidates? This course allows us to become aware of our biases so that we can attend to them and interrupt them while evaluating and selecting diverse top talent.


  *   "Managing <PERSON> in <NRP>>>": Unconscious biases can derail our best efforts to interview candidates of all backgrounds objectively and accurately. Are we letting our commonalities with a candidate influence our perception of their skills or their 'fit'? Are our perceptions of a candidate being unconsciously skewed based on preconceived judgments we formed from information on their résumé? Are we unconsciously changing the questions we ask to certain candidates? This course invites you to look for and mitigate unconscious bias that may be hampering your best intentions when interviewing diverse job candidates.


ANTI-BIAS LEARNING INTERVENTIONS: PERFORMANCE EVALUATION


  *   eLearning: "Evaluating Talent Inclusively<<URL>>": This program provides managers powerful examples of how bias can impact performance evaluation. Activities highlight meaningful examples of how to challenge bias in ourselves and one another and ensure that talent is evaluated objectively rather than by relying on mental models or shortcuts. Participants are given the opportunity to recognize and interrupt bias when evaluating performance, as well as when making promotion decisions based on that evaluation.


  *   Microlearning: "Managing Bias in Performance Reviews<<URL>>": Unconscious biases can derail our best efforts to be objective and accurate when it comes to evaluating performance. Are we inadvertently giving higher ratings to employees who are more 'like us'? What are we doing to ensure our evaluation process is consistent across our entire team? Are we sure we're aware of the variety of work or projects each team member has worked on, or are we basing our evaluation only on those projects we know about? Are our expectations about a person skewing how we see them? Managing Unconscious Bias in Performance Reviews invites you to look for and mitigate biases in evaluating performance.


You'll hear back from us by the end of the week!

activities.subject: RE: We know you are committed to DEI in 2024
activities.body:
Hi <PERSON>,

I trust this message finds you well and happy 2024!

Many of our clients are busy planning their budget for the year around this time, trying to maximize DEI needs and targeted outcomes with finite resources. We thought you might appreciate having a proactive partner to bounce ideas from, or to help brainstorm ways to achieve your annual DEI and cultural competence goals.

I welcome finding a time that suits your schedule in the next few weeks to connect further. What week works best for you? I can send you my availability.

We'd love to stay in touch in case there are ways we can collaborate but if I don't hear from you in the next week or two, that's understandable, given your multiple priorities.

Wishing you continued success and prosperity in 2024!

activities.subject: Boost cultural literacy at Uber in 2024
activities.body:
Hi, <PERSON> - I hope you're doing well. It has been a while. We need to connect soon.

As a recent XYZ client, I'm reaching out to see if you're thinking about 2024 programming and if we could potentially help you with that. It's an opportunity to engage in authentic, yearlong cultural literacy upskilling around the cultures that Uber staff belong to and are influenced and inspired by. With events being what they are in the world today, ensuring that we are all operating in a cross-culturally competent manner is even more critical.

Our culture-specific Spotlights are not superficial.

These one-hour, interactive, deep-dive workshops are focused on the experience of being a member of these communities, and contribute to building cultural competence, inclusion skills, and a culture of belonging throughout the firm.

Spotlight on:
Suggested Delivery Month in 2024
Black/African American Community
February (Black History Month)
Women in Leadership
March (Women's History Month)

Being an Ally for the Asian American Community
May (AAPI Heritage Month)
The LGBTQ+ Community
June (LGBTQ+ Pride Month)
Persons with Disabilities
July (Disability Pride Month)
The <NRP>/Latinx/e Community
September (Hispanic Heritage Month)
Indigenous People in <LOCATION>
October (Indigenous Peoples' Day) or November (Native American Heritage Month)
U.S. Veterans Community
November (Veterans' Day)
U.S. Generations
December (Or April or August)

Both people managers and individual contributors consistently find these sessions relevant and applicable for their workplace goals and relationships, as they include topics like:

  *   Relevant statistics and data that communicate this community's makeup, impact, and experiences
  *   The community's values, priorities, strengths
  *   Dispelling any myths or stereotypes about the community
  *   Challenges or barriers members of this group tend to face in the workplace, and
  *   Strategies & tips for what participants can do to broaden inclusion and belonging for members of this community.

Now through December, you can save 20% when you purchase our bundle of nine 1-hour, interactive, deep-dive workshops when you pay up front.

I'm happy to schedule a time to discuss - if this fits into your plans at all.

<PERSON>

<PERSON> (He/Him)
Co-CEO and Managing Principal
XYZ

activities.subject: FW: Anti-bias Interventions: Proposals from XYZ
activities.body:
My two cents:

  1.  Our eLearnings were all intentionally designed to be interactive, with multiple activities and hands-on exercises. They 100% aren’t “all reading and listening”. It could be that Paradigm’s eLearnings are ‘flashier’ or more updated from a look and feel perspective.
  2.  Our microlearnings used to be just a video (so around 5-7 minutes) with an accompanying pdf ‘job aid’. We incorporated the job aid concepts and examples into our current microlearning modules, thus increasing the course’s length (beyond just watching a video). Ironic.



<PERSON> (MBA, Latina, <NRP>, Mom)
(she/her) Why pronouns matter<

activities.note_body: 2/16/2024 DISCOVERY CALLUber participants: <PERSON>, <PERSON>, <PERSON> TamayoXYZ participants: RP, ChuckPre-call <PERSON> (requests from emails, other knowledge)From <PERSON>: I'm reaching out to see if there’s an opportunity to collaborate on a training we’re building out at Uber. We’re currently scoping a new anti-bias training pilot for all interviewers and hiring managers at Uber. For the pilot, in addition to testing content, we want to experiment with 3 different modalities for delivery:1.       live training,2.       online/self-paced, and3.       microlearning/just-in-time.We’d like to offer these options to different test groups and gather data around which type of training is best attended, best-received by participants, and has the greatest impact on hiring behavior.We also would like to customize content across each region we operate within (EMEA, NAMER, APAC, and LATAM).The team has been in the process of meeting with vendors to learn about their offerings. Would it be possible to sync on a call next week?  CALL NOTES:Recently went through a civil rights assessment that requires hiring anti bias training (please see ‘Equity in Hiring’ section on pages 45-46 in their CRA Report.)Note: In the fall of 203, Uber took another step, and engaged Covington & Burling LLP (law firm) to assess the company’s efforts to promote civil rights and DEI and to make recommendations for additional actions the company could take to achieve its civil rights and DEI objectives in <LOCATION>.  Covington reviewed documents and data; interviewed each member of the company’s executive team and many internal subject-matter experts; convened roundtables with leaders of Uber’s employee resource groups (ERGs) and members of Uber Crew (drivers and couriers elected to represent those communities); held a listening session with national advocacy and civil rights organizations; and spoke with nonprofit organizations with which Uber partners.  Based on this work, Covington concluded that Uber has taken significant steps to promote civil rights and DEI for all users on its <LOCATION> mobility platform, in its corporate workforce, and in the communities it serves.  Covington also identified additional steps the company could take to achieve these objectives…Have an ‘Advancing Anti Racism’ trainingThe Anti Bias training should take about an hourUsed to have an online training called “Hire the Uber Way” – but it isn’t mandatory, just highly recommended - inclusion is a smallish part of this <URL><PERSON> built an <NRP> Jiring training – but it had to be delivered live, and right now don’t have the scale and scope to deliver.<PERSON> – we could be doing more <PERSON> trainingOona King is new CDOPilot – iterating on content and modalityDiane: can you send <LOCATION> info on Performance management too: MBPR, link to ETIPopup or stopgap mechanism so that people can’t interview others unless they complete the training.Testing in different regions – as a global pilot. Working with regional DEI VP’<URL>other person who was not able to attend today, <PERSON>, leads DEI for Uber in APAC (<EMAIL_ADDRESS>).3 pilots for global live training – combining a region with certain <LOCATION> timezones.30k people, 4500-5000 people <URL>rrently working on revamping onboarding and new manager training (‘manager effectiveness curriculum’).They have an inclusive leadership training runs about 3x a year for new managersLanguages? We’d probably need it translates into Spanish and <NRP>, <NRP> <LOCATION>. But not for <URL>s for preview of online contentFor live training – off the shelf for now. Table of contents – <URL>asures for success? Our internal researchers identified:  ·         How many and who have completed the training, and finished it·         A pre- and post- questionnaire to test knowledge·         General feedback about the training·         We track candidate demographics from stage to stage – is there any change to hiring outcomesWe have pretty good representation in our sourcing pipelines, no need to go into that topic.<PERSON>: We also want all of <LOCATION> to go through it eventually.Budget? Another vendor quoted $50k – access to all learnings (6 months, but addl fee for ongoing access) and 3 live sessions. 50 participants in each pilot <URL>xt steps:·         Make a decision by end of month, so get back to them by next Friday·         Send info and costs for MBH 1-hr workshop, HPTT, and MBH/MBI microlearnings.·         Send info on Performance management too: MBPR, link to ETI

  *   “Hiring & Promoting Top Talent”<<URL>>: This course explores the hidden bias in talent acquisition and development. It includes insights into how assessing for ‘cultural fit’ impacts the organization’s ability to attract and hire culturally diverse top talent, and build and support a robust and diverse talent pipeline. Participants also explore how mentoring, staffing teams, key assignments, and coaching across cultures drive the readiness of top talent for their next opportunity.

<PERSON>: Short, digital, impactful learning tools offer reinforcements for participants to access at the point of decision or needed action. Such "in the moment" nudges help sustain behavioral change, facilitating systemic transformation.


  *   “Managing Bias in Hiring<<URL>>”: Unconscious biases can derail our best efforts to be objective and accurate when it comes to hiring the best person for the job. Is bias at play when we hire for ‘cultural fit’? Are we interpreting similarities with candidates as evidence that they will be successful in this role? Are groupthink or expectations about people of certain backgrounds limiting our ability to find the best candidates? This course allows us to become aware of our biases so that we can attend to them and interrupt them while evaluating and selecting diverse top talent.


  *   “Managing <PERSON> in Interviewing<<URL>>”: Unconscious biases can derail our best efforts to interview candidates of all backgrounds objectively and accurately. Are we letting our commonalities with a candidate influence our perception of their skills or their ‘fit’? Are our perceptions of a candidate being unconsciously skewed based on preconceived judgments we formed from information on their résumé? Are we unconsciously changing the questions we ask to certain candidates? This course invites you to look for and mitigate unconscious bias that may be hampering your best intentions when interviewing diverse job candidates.


ANTI-BIAS LEARNING INTERVENTIONS: PERFORMANCE EVALUATION


  *   eLearning: “Evaluating Talent Inclusively<<URL>>”: This program provides managers powerful examples of how bias can impact performance evaluation. Activities highlight meaningful examples of how to challenge bias in ourselves and one another and ensure that talent is evaluated objectively rather than by relying on mental models or shortcuts. Participants are given the opportunity to recognize and interrupt bias when evaluating performance, as well as when making promotion decisions based on that evaluation.


  *   Microlearning: “Managing Bias in Performance Reviews<<URL>>”: Unconscious biases can derail our best efforts to be objective and accurate when it comes to evaluating performance. Are we inadvertently giving higher ratings to employees who are more ‘like us’? What are we doing to ensure our evaluation process is consistent across our entire team? Are we sure we’re aware of the variety of work or projects each team member has worked on, or are we basing our evaluation only on those projects we know about? Are our expectations about a person skewing how we see them? Managing Unconscious Bias in Performance Reviews invites you to look for and mitigate biases in evaluating performance.


You’ll hear back from us by the end of the week!

My two cents:

  1.  Our eLearnings were all intentionally designed to be interactive, with multiple activities and hands-on exercises. They 100% aren’t “all reading and listening”. It could be that Paradigm’s eLearnings are ‘flashier’ or more updated from a look and feel perspective.
  2.  Our microlearnings used to be just a video (so around 5-7 minutes) with an accompanying pdf ‘job aid’. We incorporated the job aid concepts and examples into our current microlearning modules, thus increasing the course’s length (beyond just watching a video). Ironic.

My response in blue

Colgate-Palmolive Company
Senior Director <PERSON>, Equity, & Inclusion
300 <LOCATION>
<LOCATION>, <LOCATION> 10022










On Fri, Feb 23, 2024 at 12:41 PM <PERSON> <<EMAIL_ADDRESS><mailto:<EMAIL_ADDRESS>>> wrote:
Hi <PERSON> and <PERSON> –

I went through all your feedback on the microlearnings, thanks again.

A few questions/comments:


  1.  Managing <PERSON> in Hiring:

     *   You had a comment about this section of the video voiceover: “Have you ever thought to yourself something like: “How will she handle all the travel the role requires?” The real question is – do we also worry about such things for men? Such bias is based on stereotypes about gender roles. We need decision makers in the hiring process to challenge such bias, so it doesn’t get in the way of us hiring top talent—who in many cases will be women.”
     *   Your comment is “<URL>ment made in voiceover that won’t get in the way of hiring top talent in many cases with be women?? Sounds like fact. This piece needs to be rephrased.” I’d be interested in hearing more about is problematic here… Here the narration is giving an example about how we have double standards or judge people differently based on stereotypes about their gender. The part about “who in many cases will be women” refers to that we will be inevitably be hiring women for some of our roles, as we don’t look at gender as a factor when hiring and women make up roughly half the population.
                       I feel this can be misconstrued by our audience as a goal. I would like to remove or change.  "who in may cases will be women"  Got it – so we’ll remove the “who in many cases will be women” part of the voiceover.


  1.  Managing <PERSON> in Interviewing:

     *   Re: the “Implicit Stereotyping Bias” in the “Tips for Mitigating Bias in Interviews” section, one of the bullets says: “Substitute a different identity for the candidate, and test out if you’d evaluate the person’s behavior track record or skills the same way. For example, would you react negatively to a female candidate highlighting her competitiveness and toughness versus if a man did so? Or would you react differently to a Black candidate describing how hard working they are than to a white candidate saying the same thing?”
     *   Your comment is: “I would change this example for other no ethnicity.” I know you’re referring to the question about race. Could you please say more about what you could like to see replace this question?
                            I think this may  be <PERSON>'s comment? Yes, it was.


  1.  Managing Bias in Talent Review:

     *   In the video voiceover, one section says: “From a talent review perspective, those in the majority are often blind to the experiences of those in the minority – who may have a higher bar or different performance expectations set for them, compared to their colleagues in the majority.” The feedback from client is “Majority versus the minority may be polarizing and alienate the majority if white males or is it any group that may be considered majority which can change based on the context Is there another way to rephrase? Also majority and minority may be more of <LOCATION> centric concept connected to diversity. Is there any way to reposition to be globally understood?” Re: the “majority/minority” phrasing – I do understand your comment, <PERSON>. And we were intentional about this language so that it resonates globally. Majority cultures differ by country/region – so for example in <LOCATION>, <NRP> are in the majority in terms of ethnicity. And in <LOCATION> most corporate leadership positions are filled by people who come from upper class socioeconomic backgrounds.  Thoughts? Let me look at the learning again. Based on the visual cues, it seemed more about men and women.  Will wait to hear from you on this one then. Another option could be to change the stock images/video rather than the voiceover narration – which would be more expensive.


     *   Re: the Maya <PERSON> quote – I recommend that we replace with this quote: “Being 100% sure of yourself at all times betrays arrogance and breeds complacency. Questioning yourself reflects humility and propels growth.” -- <PERSON>, Organizational Psychologist at the Wharton School and author of Hidden Potential: The Science of Achieving Greater Things   Thoughts? Are there other options?  Need a thought with simplicity in context. I did spend some time researching this morning and thought this one was the best of the ones I saw (plus it’s a white man saying it, which also goes to your comment about diversifying the visuals of the microlearnings in general). If you have another suggestion we’d be happy to insert it, or if you could provide more specificity around what you’re looking for I could try again.

Everything else was pretty clear.

Thanks, both!
<PERSON><PERSON> (MBA, Latina, <NRP>, Mom)
(she/her) Why pronouns matter<

Hello Team - Many thanks for sharing all this content.

<PERSON> and I already reviewed all the content and provided feedback in the comment part for the five micro learnings. Now you can proceed to review and provide a quote considering the edits suggested. Please add into the quote the two options that you mentioned in your latest email: the 3 years licensing or buying the content and customize with Colgate logo, etc.

Regarding the eLearning about Unconscious Bias (targeted for Individual Contributors), we don't consider that fit the need that we have and the concept of "Moments that Matter" that we want to tackle this year.

Additional input and forward actions:
1. Pre-SHIFT Workshop: Please include into the quote the cost of this material (the three micro-lessons) for workers.
Do you have a version of this workshop that could work for Salaried & Clerical employees (different types of examples)?  We like the concept of this workshop and we would like to explore it further.

2. Managing Unconscious Bias around the process of Reward & Recognition: Could you please add to the quote the cost & estimated timing to create a micro learning regarding this topic.

3. Translations: Include into the quote the cost of translation of the 5 micro learnings to the 10 and/or17 languages shared.

Many thanks for partnering with us and let us know if you have further questions.

<PERSON>On Thu, Jan 25, 2024 at 12:09 PM <PERSON> <<EMAIL_ADDRESS><mailto:<EMAIL_ADDRESS>>> wrote:
Hi Sandra & Jesma,
Thank you both for meeting with us today, it was great getting to hear your feedback. The demo link below will request your name and email address. After you enter that information, you will be taken directly into the course. Here is the link for our E-learning: Introduction to Managing Unconscious Bias<<URL>>.
The link is active until 2/12 and you have access to 3 registration seats.
Here is a quick overview of the objectives for this course:


  *   Understand how our brains work when thinking about difference and sameness, including examples of related research that help us understand our own brain’s shortcuts
  *   Identify potential individual and organizational biases that need addressing
  *   Implement techniques for responding to unconscious biases
  *   Understand how microinequities surface and the possible outcomes if they’re ignored
  *   Implement techniques to limit engaging in microinequities, including how to use inclusive behaviors



If you have any questions, feel free to reach out. I’m happy to help!

activities.subject: Short, high-impact sessions on the <NRP> and the Jewish Experiences in the <LOCATION>
activities.body:
Hi Jesma,​

We’re thrilled to shared that we’re launching two brand new Spotlight sessions aimed at highlighting the experiences, influences, values and rich cultures of the <NRP> and <NRP> communities in the <LOCATION>

Our Spotlights are one-hour, interactive, deep-dive workshops are focused on the experience of being a member of these communities, and contribute to building cultural competence, inclusion skills, and a culture of belonging throughout your organization. 

☪️Spotlight on the Muslim Community (1-hr)
This session explores the complexities of being <NRP> in <LOCATION> and the simultaneously varied and shared experiences and worldviews of <LOCATION>’s <NRP> community. In this session, we unpack the concepts of culture versus religion and discuss current issues and events impacting the <NRP> experience and perspectives. Best practices for allyship and countering bias in the workplace will be shared. Session objectives:
Explore factors that have shaped the lived experiences and cultural values of the <NRP> community, including shared experiences and common influences Recognize the depth and diversity of the <NRP> community in the <LOCATION> Discuss <NRP> sentiment (especially since 9/11) and its impact on the <NRP> community Explore strategies to support and be an ally to your <NRP> colleagues and the community at large 
🔯Spotlight on the Jewish Community (1-hr)
This session introduces participants to key historical and social/cultural events that shape this community, as well as the cultural values and practices that influence the <NRP> experience. The session will also unpack stereotypes, debunk myths, and address antisemitism and its impact in the workplace today. We share best practices for supporting and providing allyship to our colleagues with the community, and how to counter antisemitic bias and microaggressions. Session objectives:
Explore factors that have shaped the lived experiences and cultural values of the <NRP> community, including shared experiences and common influences. Recognize the depth and diversity of the <NRP> community in the <LOCATION> Discuss the current state of Antisemitism and its impact on the <NRP> community. Explore strategies to support and be an ally to your <NRP> colleagues and the community at large. Below are one-pagers for each session, that you may share with your stakeholders. 

Other Spotlights that you may consider for 2024:
Being an Ally for the Asian American Community (May, AAPI Heritage Month) Spotlight on the LGBTQ+ Community (June, LGBTQ+ Pride Month) Spotlight on Persons with Disabilities (July, Disability Pride Month) Spotlight on U.S. Generations (April, August, December, anytime) Spotlight on the <NRP>/Latinx/e Community (September, Hispanic Heritage Month 9/15-10/15) Spotlight on Indigenous People in <LOCATION> (October, Indigenous Peoples’ Day or November, Native American Heritage Month) Spotlight on the U.S. Veterans Community (November, Veterans’ Day) If you have any questions and would like to connect, please let me what days work best and I’ll send over some times.

Hi <PERSON>, how are you? I can’t imagine the turbulent months you’ve had but I do hope things have settled down and that the future looks bright. As <PERSON> said, it’s terrific to hear from you!

I’ve been refreshing my memory on our past conversations and am now up to date. [Image removed by sender. 🙂]

Delivering ‘Inclusive Talent Acquisition’ (two, 2.25 hour halves) in May works great. We had talked about giving you access to several of our digital microlearnings, which are short, high impact learning tools that offer refreshers and reinforcements for participants to access right at the point of decision or needed action (e.g., before hiring for a role). Such "in the moment" nudges help sustain behavioral change, facilitating systemic transformation.

We now offer the opportunity for organizations to purchase these microlearnings, to house in your LMS and access in perpetuity. Is this something that might interest you?

Here are demo links to the 3 we talked about, pertaining to talent acquisition:

  *   Managing <PERSON> in Recruiting<

activities.subject: RE: Scheduling mtg in early Dec?
activities.body:
Hi <PERSON>

I think if the session covers multiple cultures as there are managers in NA managing teams in <LOCATION> and APAC so broad examples in the main model will be sufficient; I don't think at this stage we need to localise the materials; so long as examples are referenceable.

activities.subject: RE: Scheduling mtg in early Dec?
activities.body:
PHISH ALERT! CHECK VALIDITY IF CLICKING, SHARING, RESPONDING

Thank you so much, <PERSON>. Super helpful.

We can also include estimates for what it would cost to culturally-adapt a session for each region. Alternatively, we could create a 'global' version where we offer examples from different parts of the world.

Thoughts?

<PERSON>
(she/her)
Head of Client Solutions
XYZ

activities.subject: RE: Scheduling mtg in early Dec?
activities.body:
Hi <PERSON>, <PERSON>

Great to catch up earlier.

There are 841 managers across the organisation:

  *   400 - APAC region
  *   111 - EMEA region
  *   330 - <LOCATION> region

Let me know if you need anything else to prepare a distilled proposal.

activities.subject: RE: Scheduling mtg in early Dec?
activities.body:
Hi <PERSON>Apologies for the delay we have been waiting on a couple of internal discussions which we have now had.

We would like to revisit the proposal with the focus to start being:

  *   Facilitation of Unconscious Bias training sessions with facilitated open conversations on DEIB topics
  *   Explore accreditation for e2open designated team members to facilitate trainings

The proposal we have received is fantastic and very detailed but I think is an aspirational learning journey, we need to crawl before we run. We need first to set the tone and share insights and awareness before we look to embed into the learning culture (at this time anyway).

If you can in the mean time look at a scaled back version that would be really appreciated.

activities.subject: RE: Scheduling mtg in early Dec?
activities.body:
PHISH ALERT! CHECK VALIDITY IF CLICKING, SHARING, RESPONDING


Understood, <PERSON>. Here are a few times for <PERSON> (all times GMT):

Tues 9th:  1:30-3pm , 4-6pm
10th  1:30-3pm, 4-6pm
11th  1:30-6pm
12th  1:30-3pm, 4-5pm

If none of these work, please send us a couple of times that work for you the following week?

activities.subject: RE: Scheduling mtg in early Dec?
activities.body:
Hi <PERSON>

We have a team call later next week to review or DEIB proposal. I am not sure if we will be at a point early December for a decision as it won't go to the board this side of Christmas I wouldn't imagine.

I would suggest January a better target, apologies.

activities.subject: Scheduling mtg in early Dec?
activities.body:

Hello again, <PERSON> - I'm sorry to bother you, my Dec is filling up and wanted to know if any of the below dates/times worked for you and your team for the first week of Dec? I'm happy to send you an invitation from our end.

XYZ

Mon Dec 4  2-5pm

We plan to have a proposal reviewed mid/end November. Shall we set a follow up for early Dec as a check in and initial responses to the proposal?

activities.subject: RE: Scheduling mtg in early Dec?
activities.body:
PHISH ALERT! CHECK VALIDITY IF CLICKING, SHARING, RESPONDING

Hi <PERSON>,

We can definitely make the adjustments to our proposal.

Re: the unconscious bias training:

  *   Which constituencies should we be targeting in the revised proposal?  The ELT? People Managers? Both? Individual contributors?  We have UB sessions targeted to 'everyone' and another targeted to people leaders that goes deeper into how UB influences how we treat/evaluate people.[Comment/Remark SMa]  We want to cover all team members including leaders/executives
  *   We can certainly facilitate open conversations on DEIB topics, or alternatively we could supply you with <PERSON> so that E2open can facilitate these conversations internally
  *   We can definitely provide accreditation/Train-the-Trainer option for your internal team of facilitators.

Is there any way you could fit in a 30-minute meeting next week with <PERSON> and I, to talk through this real quick, so we have what we need to send you the updated proposal?

Look forward to hearing from you!

activities.subject: RE: DEI Services Proposal for <PERSON> from XYZ
activities.body: <PERSON> and I agreed on a 20% discount, and they responded by saying they want to sign the contract TODAY and pay the full amount in December! Woo hoo! $40k of new money! <PERSON> and I will design and deliver this (she already said yes), so it will be like a pilot for a new product!

activities.subject: Quickly poking our head in
activities.body:
Hi <PERSON>, just checking in again on status for this project.

Please note that we are very open to discussing your budget and adapting a plan that meets your needs. Our goal is to partner with you to find the best, most cost-effective solutions for E2open. We'd love to have the opportunity to respond to your concerns and make adjustments to ensure alignment.

Best!
<PERSON><PERSON> (MBA, Latina, <NRP>, Mom)
(she/her) Why pronouns matter<

activities.subject: RE: Gentle followup: New proposal options for E2open
activities.body:
Hi <PERSON>! Sorry to bother you again - I just re-read our notes from our last meeting and noticed you mentioned you wanted to make a decision by March 1st, which is approaching quickly. Lmk if you'd like to set up a meeting. If we are going to be working together, I also want to ensure we have all our ducks in a row on our end in terms of resource allocation. Thank you! <PERSON><PERSON>
(she/her)
Head of Client Solutions
XYZ

activities.subject: RE: Gentle followup: New proposal options for E2open
activities.body:
Hi <PERSON>, how are you? Just checking in again. No need to respond if you're not ready, and please let me know if my emails are bothersome. [?]
As always, please let us know if you need help with anything.
Best!
<PERSON><PERSON>
(she/her)
Head of Client Solutions
XYZ

activities.subject: Gentle followup: New proposal options for E2open
activities.body:
Hi <PERSON>,
How are you?
<PERSON> and I are hoping that the revised proposals were clear.
Would it be convenient for you if we scheduled a meeting to walk you through it and answer your questions (next week, the week after, the week after that - whatever works for you)?
I can't believe it's almost February!

activities.subject: New proposal options for E2open

Hi <PERSON>,

Hope you had a great weekend! Here are the links to access the newly revised proposals we've been working on.

First version (XYZ facilitates everything): <URL>

Second Version (TTT option): <URL>

If you have any questions, I'm happy to help. After you've reviewed the proposals, let me know if you'd like to set up some time to follow up on any questions or changes you'd like to see. Looking forward to your feedback!

activities.subject: WSJ article "Corporate America Tweaks Diversity Initiatives" & my analysis
activities.body:
Hi <PERSON>,

As you continue to be a SME for E2open’s top leaders, I wanted to send you this article which you may have already seen. It’s pretty short, and gives language about the current challenges in corporate <LOCATION> (which are spreading to other parts of the world, unfortunately). You can help your stakeholders make sense of it.

Here are my thoughts. It seems to me the two main points that are being pushed back against are:

  1.  Hiring or promotion ‘quotas’ (which is something that XYZ or any other DEI professional I know or have worked with has ever recommended) and
  2.  ‘Blaming’ white populations by, for example, calling people ‘white supremacists’ or stating something ridiculous like all white people are racist.

Neither of the points above are part of what achieving DEI is all about. Inclusive practices are alive and well, and I think that most organizations understand that there’s no going back.

<URL><<URL>>

activities.subject: Do you know of a team struggling with alignment or interpersonal issues?
activities.body:
Dear <PERSON>,

Hope you’re having a productive <US_DRIVER_LICENSE> – I can’t believe it’s almost over already!

I know we’re currently in communication, just wanted to let you about a new XYZ offering.

<PERSON> said that “culture eats strategy for breakfast” – and we continue to see examples that prove him right. 

We’ve developed an intensive program where we help team members create the team culture they need and crave to succeed. 

This workshop is for intact teams who are struggling with issues that are interfering with their performance due to ineffective communication and/or working relationships, for example:
- Interpersonal issues
- Issues with the leader/manager 
- Poor group dynamics
- Harmful microbehaviors
The workshop content has its strong foundation, but we tailor it based on interviews, focus groups, or surveys of all team members. This is key. During the program itself, facilitators and your stakeholder together, create a “brave” space for all participants to feel heard and be engaged During the program, participants co-create a Team Charter: five to seven concrete behaviors that all team members will commit to going forward The workshop is facilitated by 2 highly skilled professionals who coach participants to arrive at solutions The workshop is designed for intact teams of up to 20 participants, conducive to deep attention to key issues that are getting in their way If this intervention sounds like something that would help remove an obstacle for your team (or another team in your org), we’d love to hear more and see if/how we could help. 

Simply reply to this email and we can send a few available timeslots for you to choose from, or you could send us your availability if you prefer.

I had a note to follow-up with you folks on our earlier conversations about possible programming for your staff. We'd love to talk with you about some of these affordable ways to engage your staff at a time of such political uncertainty and unease among your more vulnerable populations. The Spotlights have proven to be a great way to let folks know they have not become invisible.

activities.subject: BRG/ERG Support
activities.body:
Hi, <PERSON> -

It was wonderful to connect this week with you. Its been a while.

Per our call, I am attaching information on BRG/ERG toolkit that we developed for a client who needed some added assistance in 'professionalizing' their approach to BRG/ERGs. They found that they didn't have a standard model, or even a standard set of expectations for their BRGs, as each had developed organically over the years. They also found that their Executive Sponsorship was inconsistent among the BRGs.

We led multiple conversations with represented populations to see what they know of BRGs at the organization, what they expected from their BRGs, and what was keeping them from joining (if they hadn't). We also spoke to the business leadership to understand their expectations. We then used this data to form the training and consulting interventions for both the BRG leaders and the executive sponsors.

I will schedule some time next week to discuss any questions you might have.

<PERSON>

I’ve been refreshing my memory on our past conversations and am now up to date. [Image removed by sender. 🙂]

Delivering ‘Inclusive Talent Acquisition’ (two, 2.25 hour halves) in May works great. We now offer the opportunity for organizations to purchase these microlearnings, to house in your LMS and access in perpetuity. Is this something that might interest you?

Hi <PERSON> –  how are you?

I wanted to let you know that in terms of day to day and strategic DEI planning going forward, your Consultant/Account Manager will be <PERSON><<URL>>, who is an outstanding consultant, coworker, and friend. The two of us have met and I’ve briefed her on our conversations thus far. She is aware of SRC, what y’all do, that we started talking last summer, and the Inclusive Talent Acquisition session on May 8th and 9th from 10-12:15pm ET.

A little about <PERSON> (btw her name is pronounced with the emphasis on the first syllable):

  *   Has a strong track record working with clients to meet business objectives through strategic talent management, DEI, and management support.
  *   Her strength is identifying the intersection of culture, employee wellbeing, business priorities, and diversity/inclusion.
  *   She has worked with organizations in the <LOCATION> as well as in <LOCATION>, <LOCATION>, <LOCATION>, <LOCATION>, <LOCATION>, <LOCATION>, and the <LOCATION> to strategically consider business priorities, identify barriers to employee engagement, and implement strategies for building an inclusive workplace culture.
  *   <PERSON> has presented at national and international venues such as the Conference Board, National Human Resource Development India, National Business Group on Health, Working Mother, World@Work, and the World Forum Foundation.
  *   Her career focus has been engaging employers to participate in supporting the workforce and the communities where they live and work.
  *   <PERSON> lives in <LOCATION>, <LOCATION> – much closer to you than me!

<PERSON>: As you now know,  <PERSON> is Sr. Manager, D&I and is interested in continuing to partner with us (in separate SOWs in the future) around:

  1.  The TA-related microlearnings (as reinforcements and priming tools) “Managing Bias in Recruiting,” “Managing Bias in Hiring,” and “Managing Bias in Interviewing”, plus
  2.  The Inclusive Performance Evaluation package (1-hr “Inclusive Perf Eval” workshop + “Managing Bias in Performance Reviews” microlearning as reinforcement and priming tool) – as we talked about their FY starts Oct 1st.

Of course, I’m not going anywhere, but you’re definitely in good hands with <PERSON> leading this project and relationship.
