activities.subject: Exclusive Invitation to Participate in XYZ's climate Interview
activities.body:
Dear Maddie,​

Over the past 24 years of working with organizations like yours, we have learned the impact internal and external climates have on our clients doing the work to support inclusion within their organizations. These past few years have truly been filled with change, directional shifts, and future uncertainty. We understand the importance of being a true partner and are excited to announce our exclusive initiative to support our stakeholders by conducting a comprehensive climate interview and survey. The goal of the survey will be to assess how the mindsets and systems within organizations have influenced organizational climate over the past few years and impacted inclusive workplaces. The information we collect from the interview and survey will be treated with utmost confidentiality and the key takeaways will be shared with all selected participants. Based on the key takeaways, we will be sharing relevant resources, developing new content, providing action steps, and offering opportunities to learn and collaborate with peers. 

Please select the time that works best for a 30-minute interview: <URL>

Thank you for considering this opportunity. We look forward to your participation and serving as a continued resource to you and your organization.

activities.subject: REGISTER FOR FREE PREVIEW: Spotlights on the <NRP> & Jewish Communities in the <LOCATION>
activities.body:
Hi Maddie,​

As part of our ongoing commitment to fostering cultural understanding and promoting inclusion, we’re excited to announce an upcoming no-cost session previewing our two new programs: "Spotlight on the Jewish Community in the <LOCATION>" and "Spotlight on the Muslim Community in the <LOCATION>." The preview will take place on May 29th, 2024 from 2-3pm ET / 1-2pm CT. 

These two additions to our Spotlights library were carefully designed and vetted by interculturalists and culture-expert members of the <NRP> and <NRP> community. Facilitated by two cross-cultural expert facilitators (one a member of the community and one ally), the Spotlights provide participants with valuable insights into the histories, values, experiences, and influences that shape each of these distinct cultures, and deliver an insightful and nuanced understanding of the <NRP> and <NRP> experiences in <LOCATION> - dispelling misconceptions and fostering empathy. These sessions do not explain or resolve current geopolitical events, do not advocate particular points of view or debate history, and like all of our Spotlights, aim to build cultural competence and understanding. 

The Spotlights helps participants: 
Explore factors that have shaped the lived experiences and cultural values of the community in the <LOCATION>, including shared experiences and common influences. Recognize the depth and diversity of the community in the <LOCATION> Discuss historical and contemporary prejudice against the community. Explore strategies to support and be an ally to your colleagues and the community at large. In our preview we’ll demonstrate sample content from both Spotlights, show you the agenda for each, and answer your questions. 

REGISTER FOR THE SPOTLIGHTS PREVIEW:
Wednesday, May 29th, 2024 from 2-3pm ET / 1-2pm CT Register Here: <URL> 

We believe that these Spotlights can be valuable tools which, in conjunction with other elements of your DEI infrastructure, work towards de-polarization and enhancing participants’ ability to engage meaningfully with individuals from these backgrounds. 

We're looking forward to seeing you there!

activities.subject: Short, high-impact sessions on the <NRP> and the Jewish Experiences in the <LOCATION>
activities.body:
Hi Maddie,​

We’re thrilled to shared that we’re launching two brand new Spotlight sessions aimed at highlighting the experiences, influences, values and rich cultures of the <NRP> and <NRP> communities in the <LOCATION>

Our Spotlights are one-hour, interactive, deep-dive workshops are focused on the experience of being a member of these communities, and contribute to building cultural competence, inclusion skills, and a culture of belonging throughout your organization. 

☪️Spotlight on the Muslim Community (1-hr)
This session explores the complexities of being <NRP> in <LOCATION> and the simultaneously varied and shared experiences and worldviews of <LOCATION>’s <NRP> community. In this session, we unpack the concepts of culture versus religion and discuss current issues and events impacting the <NRP> experience and perspectives. Best practices for allyship and countering bias in the workplace will be shared. Session objectives:
Explore factors that have shaped the lived experiences and cultural values of the <NRP> community, including shared experiences and common influences Recognize the depth and diversity of the <NRP> community in the <LOCATION> Discuss <NRP> sentiment (especially since 9/11) and its impact on the <NRP> community Explore strategies to support and be an ally to your <NRP> colleagues and the community at large 
🔯Spotlight on the Jewish Community (1-hr)
This session introduces participants to key historical and social/cultural events that shape this community, as well as the cultural values and practices that influence the <NRP> experience. The session will also unpack stereotypes, debunk myths, and address antisemitism and its impact in the workplace today. We share best practices for supporting and providing allyship to our colleagues with the community, and how to counter antisemitic bias and microaggressions. Session objectives:
Explore factors that have shaped the lived experiences and cultural values of the <NRP> community, including shared experiences and common influences. Recognize the depth and diversity of the <NRP> community in the <LOCATION> Discuss the current state of Antisemitism and its impact on the <NRP> community. Explore strategies to support and be an ally to your <NRP> colleagues and the community at large. Below are one-pagers for each session, that you may share with your stakeholders. 

Other Spotlights that you may consider for 2024:
Being an Ally for the Asian American Community (May, AAPI Heritage Month) Spotlight on the LGBTQ+ Community (June, LGBTQ+ Pride Month) Spotlight on Persons with Disabilities (July, Disability Pride Month) Spotlight on U.S. Generations (April, August, December, anytime) Spotlight on the <NRP>/Latinx/e Community (September, Hispanic Heritage Month 9/15-10/15) Spotlight on Indigenous People in <LOCATION> (October, Indigenous Peoples’ Day or November, Native American Heritage Month) Spotlight on the U.S. Veterans Community (November, Veterans’ Day) If you have any questions and would like to connect, please let me what days work best and I’ll send over some times.

activities.subject: Commemorating Juneteenth & Its Legacy
activities.body:
Dear Maddie,​

Many employers are planning to recognize <LOCATION> this year to celebrate this significant date in <NRP> history. 

<LOCATION>, a federal holiday celebrated annually on June 19th, marks the completion of emancipation of enslaved <NRP> in <LOCATION>, and symbolizes freedom, resilience, and the ongoing struggle for equality.

We believe that it's crucial to take the opportunity to reflect, learn, and engage in meaningful conversations about <LOCATION> and its importance to our employees and clients. To help you facilitate this dialogue, we have developed a one-hour session on this topic.

Our virtual workshop, Understanding <LOCATION> and Its Legacy, has the following objectives:
Explore <LOCATION>’s historical context, its significance in <NRP> history, and how it has evolved over time. Understand how many organizations have historically exploited the holiday. Explore ways in which individuals and organizations can commit to supporting and advocating for <NRP> communities beyond designated months or holidays. We also invite you to sample our “Commemorating Juneteenth” microlearning via this link: <URL> It will remain open and available for you until May 31st. Just enter your email address and name, and you’ll get access.

Understanding the roots of this holiday and its lasting impact is an important element for fostering empathy, awareness, and inclusion. Bringing colleagues together to engage in this opportunity to learn about history and progress has a positive impact in the workplace.

If you’re interested or have any questions, please reply to this email and we can set up a meeting.

activities.subject: Essential Guide to Dialogues about <LOCATION>-Palestine
activities.body:
Hi Maddie,​

We know that world events impact us in many ways, and that we don’t stop being who we are when we to go to work. With the ongoing <LOCATION>-Palestine conflict, we thought it would be helpful to provide you with a structure and process for having this type of dialogue. We wanted to send you this Essential Guide to Dialogues about <LOCATION>-Palestine: wanted%20to%20send%20you%20a%20quick%20note%20to%20let%20you%20know%20that%20we%20know%20that%20many%20workplaces%20have%20been%20talking%20about%20and%20affected%20by%20the%20Israel-Palestine%20conflict.%20We%20also%20know%20that%20world%20events%20impact%20us%20in%20many%20ways,%20and%20that%20we%20don’t%20stop%20being%20who%20we%20are%20when%20we%20to%20go%20to%20work.%20In%20case%20you%20or%20any%20of%20your%20colleagues%20is%20interested%20in%20a%20structure%20and%20process%20for%20having%20this%20dialogue,%20I%20attach%20the%20recently%20published%20Essential%20Guide%20to%20Dialogues%20about%20Israel-Palestine,%20put%20out%20by%20the%20organization%20Essential%20Partners.%20%20It’s%20excellent.%20%20The%20bulk%20of%20this%20guide/resource%20is%20about%20how%20to%20set%20up%20such%20a%20dialogue%20–%20including:, put out by the organization Essential Partners: <URL> It’s excellent. 

The bulk of this guide/resource is about how to set up such a dialogue – including:
The difference between dialogue and debate The importance of communication agreements (some really good ones included – please see bottom of p. 6/top of p. 7) Logistics (how, where, what) Structures for reflection, speaking & listening (the Go-Round; the Intentional Pause; Reflect, Write, Respond) Preparing for the dialogue as a facilitator (lots of support provided!) Participant intervention tips (in-depth and valuable) A sample agenda Dialogue prompts (they offer a few sets of prompts, depending on what your audience and context is – please see the one on p. 20 which is designed for the purpose of ‘better understanding different perspectives’: This dialogue guide is a great complement to our two brand new workshops: Spotlight on the Muslim Community in the <LOCATION> and Spotlight on the Jewish Community in the <LOCATION> - one-hour interactive, deep-dive workshops are focused on the experience of being a member of these communities, and aim at highlighting their experiences, influences, values and rich cultures. 

☪️Spotlight on the Muslim Community (1-hr): Explores the complexities of being <NRP> in <LOCATION> and the simultaneously varied and shared experiences and worldviews of <LOCATION>’s <NRP> community. In this session, we unpack the concepts of culture versus religion and discuss current issues and events impacting the <NRP> experience and perspectives. Best practices for allyship and countering bias in the workplace will be shared. 

🔯Spotlight on the Jewish Community (1-hr): Introduces participants to key historical and social/cultural events that shape this community, as well as the cultural values and practices that influence the <NRP> experience. The session will also unpack stereotypes, debunk myths, and address antisemitism and its impact in the workplace today. We share best practices for supporting and providing allyship to our colleagues with the community, and how to counter antisemitic bias and microaggressions. 

If you’re interested in talking further about scheduling these vital learning opportunities, please reply to this email and we can set up a meeting.

activities.subject: Get Ready for Black History Month
activities.body:
Dear Jakeim,​

Happy New Year! As we step into 2025, we hope this year brings success, growth, and meaningful connections for you and your team. With Black History Month approaching, it’s the perfect opportunity to reflect, learn, and engage in impactful conversations about diversity and inclusion. At XYZ, we’re here to support your efforts with our engaging Spotlight on the Black/African American Community session.

This 1-hour virtual learning experience offers:
Insight into the history and contributions of the Black/African American community. Strategies for fostering inclusion and allyship within your organization. An interactive format that encourages questions and dialogue. Whether you’re looking to celebrate Black History Month or deepen your organization’s commitment to equity, this session provides actionable tools for change.

Let’s connect to bring this impactful learning to your team. 

Schedule a meeting with us using this calendar link: <URL>

activities.subject: New XYZ Spotlight: Neurodiversity Inclusion in the Workplace
activities.body:
Hi Jakeim,​ 

Following up on my last message about our Spotlight on Neurodiversity Inclusion in the Workplace, I wanted to share how this training, along with our other Spotlights focused on the rich communities that shape every organization, can equip your team with skills they can apply right away. 

This session covers: 
Practical inclusion strategies that your team can start using immediately to support neurodivergent colleagues. Real-world examples and insights into the cultural experiences of neurodivergent people. Tools and resources to foster a more inclusive, respectful, and innovative workplace. I would like to schedule time to share some of these resources with you, learn about your current initiatives and answer any questions. Please let me know when is best for us to connect. We are confident this session could bring valuable insights to your team! 

Looking forward to your thoughts.

activities.subject: Get Ready for Hispanic Heritage Month with XYZ's Spotlight Bundle Offer!
activities.body:
Hi Jakeim,​ 

I hope all is well! As you are planning out end of summer initiatives, as well as, strategizing for the next quarter and year, I wanted to share some of the ways we support our clients when it comes to culture focused education initiatives. Below I’ve listed an overview of the type of rollout we see when clients purchase our various Community Spotlight Bundles. Our rollouts are flexible based on your budget. I would like to schedule time with you to learn more about how we can best partner and answer any questions, I’m happy to help! 

Overview of our Spotlight Series: 
The Muslim Community – suggested delivery date, January (Muslim Heritage Month) (2 facilitators: 1 Cultural Insider & 1 Ally) Black/African Community – suggested delivery date, February (Black History month) (1 Facilitator) Women in Leadership – suggested delivery date, March (Women’s History Month) (1 Facilitator) The Jewish Community – suggested delivery date, May (Jewish Heritage Month) (2 facilitators: 1 Cultural Insider & 1 Ally) Being an Ally for the Asian American Community – Suggested delivery date, May (AAPI Heritage month) (2 facilitators: 1 Cultural Insider & 1 Ally) The LGBTQ+ Community – suggested delivery date, June (Pride Month) (1 Facilitator) Persons with Disabilities – suggested delivery date, July (Disability Pride Month) (1 Facilitator) The Hispanic Community – suggested delivery date, September (Hispanic Heritage Month) (1 Facilitator) Indigenous People in <LOCATION> – suggested delivery date, October (Indigenous Peoples’ Day) or November (Native American Heritage Month) (2 facilitators: 1 Cultural Insider & 1 Ally) U.S. Veterans Community – suggested delivery date, November (Veterans’ Day) (1 Facilitator) U.S Generations – suggested delivery date, December, April or August (1 Facilitator) Special bundle pricing available for full rollouts. We’d love to connect to share additional resources with you. Let me know what week works best for you and I’ll send over some times. 

Have a great week!

activities.subject: Introducing Our Enhanced Cross Cultural Learning Partner Program
activities.body:
Hello Jakeim,​ 

I hope you're doing well. I wanted to follow up on my previous email regarding our Cross Cultural Learning Partner (CCLP) program, as I understand things can get busy. 

To quickly recap, the CCLP program is an innovative and personalized DEI training designed to foster deeper cultural understanding and sustained growth. The Intercultural Development Inventory (IDI) Assessment is a crucial tool within the CCLP program, helping participants not only identify where they are in terms of intercultural competence but also guiding them through the phases of development. Here's how it elevates the training experience: 
Understanding Key Developmental Phases: Throughout the program, participants will navigate various phases of intercultural development, progressing from a primarily monocultural perspective to a more inclusive intercultural viewpoint. This understanding is essential for fostering inclusive environments and navigating cultural differences effectively. Targeted Growth: By taking the IDI assessment at the beginning of the program, participants establish a clear baseline of where they currently stand in their intercultural development journey. We follow up with post IDI assessments as well conducted at the end of the program. This allows us to clearly measure the progress they've made, highlighting the growth in their ability to navigate and understand cultural differences more effectively over the 6-12 month program. We’d love to set up a time to discuss how the IDI assessment and the CCLP program can be implemented to meet your team’s needs. Please let me know what week works best, and I can send over some times to connect. 

Looking forward to your response.

activities.subject: Essential Guide to Dialogues about <LOCATION>-Palestine
activities.body:
Hello again, <PERSON>. I don’t want to bother you, so please let me know if we’re emailing you too much!

Wanted to see if it would be useful to set up a follow-up meeting with you, once you’ve had a chance to review what we sent? Next week or the week after? (or whichever week works for you)


Also, I know that many workplaces have been talking about and affected by the <LOCATION>-Palestine conflict. We know that world events impact us in many ways, and that we don’t stop being who we are when we to go to work. In case you or any of your colleagues is interested in a structure and process for having this dialogue, I attach the recently published Essential Guide to Dialogues about <LOCATION>-Palestine, put out by the organization Essential Partners<<URL>>.  The bulk of this guide/resource is about how to set up such a dialogue – including:
·         The difference between dialogue and debate
·         The importance of communication agreements (some really good ones included – pls see bottom of p. 6/top of p. 7)
·         Logistics (how, where, what)
·         Structures for reflection, speaking & listening (the Go-Round; the Intentional Pause; Reflect, Write, Respond)
·         Preparing for the dialogue as a facilitator (lots of support provided!)
·         Participant intervention tips (in-depth and valuable)
·         A sample agenda
·         Dialogue prompts (they offer a few sets of prompts, depending on what your audience and context is – please see the one on p. 20 which is designed for the purpose of ‘better understanding different perspectives’:


This dialogue guide is a great complement to our two brand new workshops: Spotlight on the Muslim Community in the <LOCATION> and Spotlight on the Jewish Community in the <LOCATION> These one-hour interactive, deep-dive workshops are focused on the experience of being a member of these communities, and aim at highlighting the their experiences, influences, values and rich cultures.

☪️Spotlight on the Muslim Community (1-hr)
This session explores the complexities of being <NRP> in <LOCATION> and the simultaneously varied and shared experiences and worldviews of <LOCATION>’s <NRP> community. In this session, we unpack the concepts of culture versus religion and discuss current issues and events impacting the <NRP> experience and perspectives. Best practices for allyship and countering bias in the workplace will be shared.

🔯Spotlight on the Jewish Community (1-hr)
This session introduces participants to key historical and social/cultural events that shape this community, as well as the cultural values and practices that influence the <NRP> experience. The session will also unpack stereotypes, debunk myths, and address antisemitism and its impact in the workplace today. We share best practices for supporting and providing allyship to our colleagues with the community, and how to counter antisemitic bias and microaggressions.

Please see attached one-pagers for each session, that you may share with your stakeholders.

activities.subject: <PERSON> from XYZ
activities.body:
Hi <PERSON>,
How are you?

Thanks so  much for taking the time to share your DEI goals with us last week. We’d absolutely love to have an opportunity to work with y’all!

Here’s a quick recap of what we heard you say:
·         Energizer is an organization with a little over 5,000 colleagues around the world, about 50/50 salaried vs. hourly employees.
·         DEIB foundation at Energizer is there, including a global DEIB Council and ERGs. You’d like to take DEIB to the next level.
·         Torrance helped you with an assessment and benchmarking – and now have a 6-year roadmap that includes various aspects of DEI, including TA, L&D, community outreach, etc.
·         There is a Board of Directors meeting taking place this September, where you’d like to present on your strategy and plans
·         Energizer’s LMS is connected to Linked In Learning, and you’re now looking for some additional learning to complement it
·         Each of the past 3 years has had a theme around DEI learning & development: first around Diversity, then Equity, and then inclusion. This year the focus is on Belonging, you already have two mandatory trainings for this year.
·         This year Energize added a question about Belonging in its annual engagement survey. Your benchmark was 75 but Energizer scored a 77, which is fantastic. You’ve looked at the employee comments in the survey, and a lot of them are around communication – in particular around working remotely (many people managers are managing employees in other countries) and understanding different cultures around the globe.
·         You’re interested in shorter, interactive bites of learning (e.g., 20-30 min).
·         In speaking with XYZ, you’re looking ahead to FY 2025 (which starts on Oct 1st, is that correct?)

Attached is a short deck that contains:

1.       Information and background on us (slides 1-9)

2.       Overview of our eLearning courses (slides 10-12)

3.       Overview of our microlearning courses (slides 13-14)

4.       I also included info on our 1-hour interactive virtual facilitated mini-workshops, just in case! (slides 13-14)

One other thing I wanted to highlight, for your hourly employees who work in plants and distribution environments, are our Pre-Shift Discussion Guides for Plant Workers. These 'microlessons' are internally facilitated (by supervisors, managers, HR representatives) and designed to help facilitate conversations and engage in application with teams to strengthen learning outcomes and influence inclusive behaviors company-wide.

1.       "Identifying <PERSON>" allows participants to identify unconscious bias from their own experiences. Participants will explore assumptions or judgments that either they have made or have been made about them, practice what to do when unconscious bias surfaces within the team, and identify behaviors to respectfully address out bias in the future.

2.       "Microinequities" explores day-to-day examples and impacts of microinequities in participants’ own workplace. Participants will learn more about microinequities and how they can affect an organization or team, hold an open discussion to identify examples of microinequities they’ve seen, and identify behaviors (sometimes known as ‘microaffirmations’) that counter negative impacts of microinequities; for example, when we are intentional about finding ways to include team members and make sure they feel they belong.

3.       "Unstereotyping Through Relationship-Building" explores the power of first impressions and implicit associations in evaluating colleagues’ potential and value in our workplace. Participants will practice exploring the impact of visual cues that trigger unconscious biases and identify behaviors that can help counter unconscious biases, by stepping out of our comfort zone to develop relationships and more robust associations with people who are different from ourselves.


Please let me know if you’d like to know more about any of the above, and we can send you more detailed info and pricing.

activities.subject: REGISTER FOR COMPLIMENTARY PREVIEW: Spotlight on Neurodiversity Inclusion in the Workplace

At XYZ, we’re excited to share details about our upcoming Spotlight session preview, Neurodiversity Inclusion in the Workplace, scheduled for November 13th at 1-2pm CT / 2-3pm EST.

This session will offer invaluable insights and practical strategies for fostering a more inclusive work environment, particularly for neurodivergent team members. Here’s what you can expect to learn:
Key definitions, models, and vocabulary that will help your team better understand the experiences of neurodivergent colleagues Exploration of shared cultural experiences and challenges that neurodivergent individuals often face in the workplace Proven strategies to create an inclusive environment where all neurological variations are respected and celebrated Practical inclusion skills you can apply immediately to make your workplace more welcoming to neurodivergent team members Whether you're looking to enhance your organization’s intercultural competence or create a more inclusive and supportive environment, this session provides a great opportunity to build understanding and take actionable steps toward fostering true inclusion for all.

activities.subject: Introducing Our Enhanced Cross Cultural Learning Partner Program
activities.body:
Dear Jakeim,​

I hope this message finds you well. At XYZ, we are always striving to innovate and provide the most impactful solutions for fostering Diversity, Equity, and Inclusion within organizations. With that commitment in mind, we are excited to introduce our updated and elevated training program: The Cross Cultural Learning Partner (CCLP).

What makes our CCLP program stand out from traditional DEI training programs? It’s designed to offer a more personalized, in-depth, and continuous learning experience. Here’s how:
Collaborative Learning: Unlike typical trainings where participants learn individually, CCLP pairs each participant with a learning partner that is culturally different in a significant way. This partnership encourages mutual support and shared growth, making the learning process richer and more effective. The cultural differences between partners offer real, lived scenarios that can be explored through open communication. Extended Engagement: While most DEI sessions are limited to just a few hours, our CCLP program spans 6 to 12 months. This extended timeframe allows for a deeper exploration of cultural competencies, continuous learning, and the opportunity to apply and reflect on insights over time. Real-World Scenarios: CCLP moves beyond hypothetical situations by integrating your unique experiences into the training. This makes the learning more relevant and directly applicable to the challenges and opportunities within your organization. Measurable Growth: Understanding your progress is key to effective learning. CCLP includes pre- and post-assessments, enabling participants to track their development and gain clear insights into how much they’ve grown after the program. We believe that our CCLP program offers a transformative approach to DEI training, and we would love to explore how it can benefit your team or organization. If you’re interested in learning more or setting up a time to discuss further, please don’t hesitate to reach out.

Looking forward to connecting!

activities.subject: Get Ready for Hispanic Heritage Month with XYZ's Spotlight Bundle Offer!
activities.body:
Dear Jakeim,​

As Hispanic Heritage Month approaches, now is the perfect time to celebrate and deepen your organization's understanding of the <NRP> community's rich history, culture, and contributions. At XYZ, we are excited to offer our Spotlight on the Hispanic Community, designed to educate and engage your teams in meaningful conversations during this important time. This Spotlight session is available both in English and Spanish.

Our Spotlights are one-hour, interactive, deep-dive workshops that focus on the experience of being a member of these communities, and contribute to building cultural competence, inclusion skills and a culture of belonging throughout the firm.

In addition, we are running a special offer on our Spotlight Bundle, which includes a total of 11 Spotlight sessions. As your teams plan for their 2025 initiatives, our Spotlight Bundle offers an excellent opportunity to ensure a focused and consistent effort to highlight and educate employees about various communities that make up their peers. Whether you're looking to enhance your DEI initiatives or simply want to keep the conversation going, we feel this bundle is a valuable resource for your organization.

Here’s are the names of the other 10 Spotlight sessions: The Jewish Community, The Muslim Community, Black/African Community, Women in Leadership, Being an Ally for the Asian American Community, The LGBTQ+ Community, Persons with Disabilities, Indigenous People in <LOCATION>, U.S. Veterans Community, and U.S Generations.

I’d love to schedule some time to discuss how our Spotlights can align with your goals and enrich your team's understanding of the <NRP> community and beyond. Let me know what week works best for you and I can send over some times to connect.

Looking forward to hearing from you!

activities.subject: Elevate Engagement and Collaboration in 2025 with XYZ’s <LOCATION>!
activities.body:
Hi Jakeim,​

As you look ahead to 2025, we’re excited to introduce XYZ’s lineup of <LOCATION>—a series of 75-minute dynamic, interactive virtual trainings designed to foster engagement, support effective collaboration, and enhance intercultural competence across your organization. These sessions delve into key areas such as inclusive leadership, building cultural competence, collaborating across generations, and neurodiversity inclusion in the workplace. Each of these sessions provides practical strategies for teams to work more cohesively in today’s diverse environments.

Whether your goal is to drive engagement, inclusion, or cultural literacy, our <LOCATION> are a flexible resource that can be tailored to fit your organization’s unique goals.

Take a look at our Miniworkshop Sessions Overview: <URL> where you'll see the breadth of topics we cover (we can custom-build one for you too!).

We’d love to discuss how these sessions could align with your 2025 learning goals.

Looking forward to connecting!

activities.subject: New XYZ Spotlight: Neurodiversity Inclusion in the Workplace
activities.body:
Hi Jakeim,​

I hope this message finds you well. We’re excited to introduce our latest timely training session, Spotlight on Neurodiversity Inclusion in the Workplace. This 75-minute virtual session, structured similar to our library of spotlights on various communities, is designed to offer valuable insights into the experiences of neurodivergent colleagues and provide practical strategies for fostering an inclusive workplace.

In this session, you’ll:
Learn the terminology and models to better understand neurodivergent experiences. Gain insights into the shared cultural experiences of neurodivergent individuals. Acquire actionable strategies to create an inclusive environment for neurodivergent team members. This course not only dives into the definitions and experiences of neurodivergent people but also helps you build an inclusive culture where every neurological difference is respected and celebrated.

Would you be open to discussing how this training can enhance your team's approach to inclusivity? We’d be happy to schedule a meeting in the next week to explore this further.

Looking forward to hearing from you.

activities.subject: Essential Guide to Dialogues about <LOCATION>-Palestine
activities.body:
Hello again, <PERSON>. I don’t want to bother you, so please let me know if we’re emailing you too much!

Wanted to see if it would be useful to set up a follow-up meeting with you, once you’ve had a chance to review what we sent? Next week or the week after? (or whichever week works for you)


Also, I know that many workplaces have been talking about and affected by the <LOCATION>-Palestine conflict. We know that world events impact us in many ways, and that we don’t stop being who we are when we to go to work. In case you or any of your colleagues is interested in a structure and process for having this dialogue, I attach the recently published Essential Guide to Dialogues about <LOCATION>-Palestine, put out by the organization Essential Partners<<URL>>.  The bulk of this guide/resource is about how to set up such a dialogue – including:
·         The difference between dialogue and debate
·         The importance of communication agreements (some really good ones included – pls see bottom of p. 6/top of p. 7)
·         Logistics (how, where, what)
·         Structures for reflection, speaking & listening (the Go-Round; the Intentional Pause; Reflect, Write, Respond)
·         Preparing for the dialogue as a facilitator (lots of support provided!)
·         Participant intervention tips (in-depth and valuable)
·         A sample agenda
·         Dialogue prompts (they offer a few sets of prompts, depending on what your audience and context is – please see the one on p. 20 which is designed for the purpose of ‘better understanding different perspectives’:


This dialogue guide is a great complement to our two brand new workshops: Spotlight on the Muslim Community in the <LOCATION> and Spotlight on the Jewish Community in the <LOCATION> These one-hour interactive, deep-dive workshops are focused on the experience of being a member of these communities, and aim at highlighting the their experiences, influences, values and rich cultures.

☪️Spotlight on the Muslim Community (1-hr)
This session explores the complexities of being <NRP> in <LOCATION> and the simultaneously varied and shared experiences and worldviews of <LOCATION>’s <NRP> community. In this session, we unpack the concepts of culture versus religion and discuss current issues and events impacting the <NRP> experience and perspectives. Best practices for allyship and countering bias in the workplace will be shared.

🔯Spotlight on the Jewish Community (1-hr)
This session introduces participants to key historical and social/cultural events that shape this community, as well as the cultural values and practices that influence the <NRP> experience. The session will also unpack stereotypes, debunk myths, and address antisemitism and its impact in the workplace today. We share best practices for supporting and providing allyship to our colleagues with the community, and how to counter antisemitic bias and microaggressions.

Please see attached one-pagers for each session, that you may share with your stakeholders.

activities.subject: Missed Our Neurodiversity Spotlight Preview? Watch the Recording!
activities.body:
Hi Jakeim,​

Thank you for your interest in our recent live preview of the newest XYZ Spotlight session on Neurodiversity Inclusion in the Workplace. We’ve heard from other attendees that the session proved to be a catalyst for rich conversations in their organizations, and we're thrilled with the engagement and insights shared.

If you missed the live session—or want to revisit key moments—you can now access the recording!

Spotlight on Neurodiversity in the Workplace: <URL>

This recording is a great resource to:
Catch up on what you missed if you were unable to attend. Share with decision-making leaders and colleagues who couldn’t attend. Reflect on ways to foster more inclusive environments for neurodivergent talent. We believe that this preview will inspire deeper conversations within your team. Let us know if we can connect with you on scheduling sessions for your organization or if you'd like to learn more about our other award-winning, cost-effective training or consulting solutions.

Schedule a Meeting: <URL>

For additional insights, feel free to explore our latest blog post on neurodiversity: <URL>

Looking forward to connecting with you!

activities.subject: RE: Reconnect | XYZ & Tractor Supply
activities.body:
Hi <PERSON> – thanks for taking us through your DEI priorities.

We understand that you’re currently refreshing TM and DEI strategy and roadmap, and that you, together with <PERSON>, TS’ CHRO, broke out into 3 buckets what you’re working to solve for:


  1.  LEADERS – Directors and above, start with CEO and direct reports.


The Challenge & Desired Approach

  *   New people managers have a very robust 2-day leadership development program with an embedded internally-developed 1-hour DEI component. This component needs revamping, as currently it only touches on unconscious bias, microaggressions, and inclusive leadership but doesn’t go deep enough, doesn’t go into the nuances of actual people decisions, and it’s more of a lecture vs. contextualized / interactive.
  *   In addition, leaders are apprehensive about broaching these topics because they genuinely don’t want to say the wrong thing. It’s awkward and silence is preferable given the potential consequences for misspeaking, even it it’s well-intentioned or based on sincere ignorance.
  *   Unfortunately, this anxiety and silence has consequences with their teams, and it shows up for example in check-ins with their reports - who often do want to talk about this and who do have real concerns and important things to share that connect to their careers, engagement, and sense of belonging.
  *   So the main challenge is, how can TS leaders connect and lead in a way that connects inclusively? How can leaders coach, develop, sponsor, and have conversations with team members in ways that makes team members of all backgrounds feel heard and understood? What can people managers do to be consciously inclusive and equitable when they assign stretch opportunities, important clients, and visible projects? When they evaluate team members for promotions and make succession planning decision? How can leaders be intentionally inclusive when it comes to recognition and rewards, engaging with TMEGs, and having the confidence and skills to acknowledge and talk about cultural differences vs. staying silent or pretending they don’t exist?
  *   The learning interventions should not center e.g., “microaggressions” and “unconscious bias” as ‘bad things’ that we need to get rid of. These topics will of course be broached, but in practical ways, in the context of realistic examples or scenarios. Rather than telling leaders and people managers what’s important, show them. While they’re considering a scenario, unpack the implications during the debrief and point out which behaviors may in fact be inadvertently introducing unfairness or exclusion.
  *   The learning should get at the nuances of how unconscious bias, microinequities/microaggressions, and minimizing cultural differences gets in the way of being the inclusive, equitable leader you want to be.
  *   The ultimate goal is to have leaders walk away being pleasantly surprised and armed with clear, practical tools to recognize when potential exclusion or inequity may be happening with themselves and others, and what they can do to intercept or correct it.


XYZ’s Approach for Tractor Supply Leaders

  *   XYZ helps organizations deepen cultural understanding and foster inclusion and belonging by pushing the boundaries that shape our personal and professional communities. We partner with organizations globally to develop the mindsets, skills & systems to succeed in a culturally diverse world.
  *   XYZ will create a learning experience that fits senior leaders and people managers based on the above. Our approach already aligns with Tractor Supply’s. We recommend a mix of facilitated, interactive and dialogue-driven training, digital reinforcers, and resources they can refer to post-training that help them feel empowered to tackle conversations and take action on their own.
  *   When we train virtually, we like to leverage certain tools that provide XYZ with the flexibility to be creative in how the training is structured and implemented.  We begin with our curriculum and proven approaches on <NRP> Leadership and we create an experience that is designed to be engaging and inclusive of different learning styles.  For example:
     *   Visually group polling that engages participants in further discussions.
     *   Quizzes and icebreakers that are interactive and visually engaging.
     *   Audience participation tools to engage in what's under discussion and to ask questions.
     *   Opportunities for participants to share ideas and impressions using word clouds and visual comments.
  *   While these tools are not revolutionary, we leverage them to ensure confidentiality so participants are more comfortable weighing in on their opinions and impressions.  And engaging in learning frameworks such as case studies, videos, annotation, and small group discussions, participants are given opportunities to explore the topic in multiple ways with facilitation. Using the information collected in these tools, we can better track participant learning and insights.  For example, capturing comments on specific points in the framing of content helps XYZ know what is being learned and how to build on the current knowledge.
  *   At the heart of our expertise is approaching DEI through a cultural competence-based lens. The foundation of our “culture first” approach to DEI learning is that we all belong to many different cultures- of nationality, race, generation, gender identity, abilities, religion, geographic region, educational background, socioeconomic background, and many more – at the same time. And each of those cultures are formed by particular experiences and influences in our lives, which have led us to certain core values and outward demonstrations of those values (behaviors) as being the ‘best’ and ‘most effective’. When we intentionally try to understand these experiences, influences, and values (in ourselves and others), we gain crucial insight into understanding, appreciating, navigating, and bridging behaviors that we may not initially be used to.


  1.  HR PROFESSIONALS. HRBPs, HR VPs and Sr Directors, Talent Acquisition, Talent Learning and Development team (which includes DEI).

  *   Members of these constituencies are not always sure how to anchor these conversations with senior leaders, people managers, and team members. These conversations are wide-ranging, and can include mediating particular behaviors that for some people might seem innocuous or simple but for others is offensive, hurtful, or disengaging. They need upskilling on DEI and intercultural competence, and how to use these insights to have productive conversations with the constituencies they serve.
  *   Examples of facilitated workshops we can offer these cohorts are “Inclusive Talent Acquisition” and  “Inclusive Talent Review,” and we recommend the Intercultural Development Inventory for self-awareness and identifying areas of development as well.
  *   We also have a “FAQ about DEI” document with answers that have been found useful by many HR leaders. We’ve attached the list of questions to this email with a couple of sample answers.
  *   I’ve also attached our DEI Facilitator Development Guide as another sample tool that you’re your HR leaders may find useful.
  *   Learning interventions for these cohorts would be centered on helping them articulate, in plain terms, what is DEI is and why it’s important, and on upskilling their intercultural competence and ability to have productive conversations about DEI.


  1.  TEAM MEMBERS WHO ARE INDIVIDUAL CONTRIBUTORS. Tools/resources for team members in offices and in distribution centers and stores.

  *   Here we would listen to your guidance but we have a library of digital eLearnings and microlernings:

eLearnings:

     *   Introduction to Managing Unconscious Bias (IMUB) – For everyone
     *   Culture & Identity (C&I) – For everyone
     *   Practicing Inclusion (PI) – For everyone or for people managers
     *   Fostering Collaboration (FC) – For people managers
     *   Managing with Intercultural Competence (MIC) – For people managers
     *   Hiring & Promoting Top Talent (HPTT) – For people managers
     *   Evaluating Talent <PERSON> (<PERSON>) – For people managers



JIT microLearnings: (for  people managers)

     *   Managing <PERSON> in Recruiting (MBR)
     *   Managing <PERSON> in Hiring (MBH)
     *   Managing <PERSON> in Interviewing (MBI)
     *   Managing Bias in Performance Reviews (MBPR)
     *   Managing Bias in Talent Reviews (MBTR)
  *   We’re also able to provide tips and strategies for the screen in the break room, as you mentioned during our meeting, or as fillable pdfs for longer-term reference.
  *   Finally, have Microlessons aka “re-Shift Discussion Guides” for team members who work in distribution or plant environments. These 'microlessons' are internally-facilitated conversations and engage in application with teams to strengthen learning outcomes and influence inclusive behaviors company-wide. Topics include “Identifying <PERSON>”, “Microinequities”, and “Unstereotyping Through Relationship Building”.


Finally – the attached deck is broken out into:

  *   Slides 1-4: About XYZ
  *   Slides 5-27 Examples of our frameworks and approaches, with some sample content.

I’ve also been meaning to say kudos to <PERSON> for being on the CEO Action for D&I!

Please let us know if you need us to clarify anything, and we’ll follow up with you in the next week.

Warmly,
<PERSON><PERSON><

activities.subject: RE: Reconnect | XYZ & Tractor Supply
activities.body:
Hi <PERSON>,
Thank you so much for reaching out to schedule ‘part 2’ – we’re available at:


  *   Tues 10am CT
  *   Thu anytime after 11am CT

Please let us know what slot works for you and we’ll send you an invite.

Also, I’ve attached:

  1.  Sample learning journeys for senior leaders, people managers, and individual contributors (focus on unconscious bias)
  2.  Sample learning journeys for senior leaders, people managers, and individual contributors (focus on inclusion and intercultural competence)
  3.  XYZ’s inclusive leadership competencies (including behavior detail)

Community-Specific Spotlights
During our meeting we also talked about our <LOCATION>. These are 1-hr (and in some cases 1.5-hr) interactive, deep-dive workshops that focus on the experience of being a member of a particular community. They’re designed with the goal of building cultural competence, inclusion skills, and a culture of belonging around these cultural groups. Many of our clients schedule them around particular heritage/observation months. For example:


Spotlight on:
Suggested Delivery Month
1
Black/African American Community
February (Black History Month)
2
Women in Leadership
March (Women’s History Month)

3
Spotlight on the Muslim American Community
During Ramadan (different every year – in 2025 it will be 1-29 March)
4
Being an Ally for the Asian American Community
May (AAPI Heritage Month) (Spotlight on the AAPI Community is currently in our content queue)
5
Spotlight on the Jewish American Community
May (Jewish American Heritage Month)
6
The LGBTQ+ Community
June (LGBTQ+ Pride Month)
7
Persons with Disabilities
July (Disability Pride Month)
8
U.S. Generations
August (or April or December)
9
The <NRP>/Latinx/e Community
September (Hispanic Heritage Month)
10
Indigenous People in <LOCATION>
October (Indigenous Peoples’ Day) or November (Native American Heritage Month)
11
U.S. Veterans Community
November (Veterans’ Day)

Both people managers and individual contributors consistently find these sessions relevant and applicable for their workplace goals and relationships, as they include topics like:

  *   Relevant statistics and data that communicate this community’s makeup, impact, and experiences
  *   The community’s values, priorities, strengths
  *   Dispelling any myths or stereotypes about the community
  *   Challenges or barriers members of this group tend to face in the workplace, and
  *   Strategies & tips for what participants can do to broaden inclusion and belonging for members of this community.


Talk to you this week!
<PERSON><PERSON><

activities.subject: Essential Guide to Dialogues about <LOCATION>-Palestine
activities.body:
Hi, <PERSON>! Hope you’re doing great. Hopefully what we sent was coherent and easy to follow.

Separately - we know that many workplaces have been talking about and affected by the <LOCATION>-Palestine conflict. We also know that world events impact us in many ways, and that we don’t stop being who we are when we to go to work. In case you or any of your colleagues is interested in a structure and process for having this dialogue, I attach the recently published Essential Guide to Dialogues about <LOCATION>-Palestine, put out by the organization Essential Partners<<URL>>.  The bulk of this guide/resource is about how to set up such a dialogue – including:
·         The difference between dialogue and debate
·         The importance of communication agreements (some really good ones included – pls see bottom of p. 6/top of p. 7)
·         Logistics (how, where, what)
·         Structures for reflection, speaking & listening (the Go-Round; the Intentional Pause; Reflect, Write, Respond)
·         Preparing for the dialogue as a facilitator (lots of support provided!)
·         Participant intervention tips (in-depth and valuable)
·         A sample agenda
·         Dialogue prompts (they offer a few sets of prompts, depending on what your audience and context is – please see the one on p. 20 which is designed for the purpose of ‘better understanding different perspectives’:


This dialogue guide is a great complement to our two brand new workshops: Spotlight on the Muslim Community in the <LOCATION> and Spotlight on the Jewish Community in the <LOCATION> These one-hour interactive, deep-dive workshops are focused on the experience of being a member of these communities, and aim at highlighting the their experiences, influences, values and rich cultures.

☪️Spotlight on the Muslim Community (1-hr): Explores the complexities of being <NRP> in <LOCATION> and the simultaneously varied and shared experiences and worldviews of <LOCATION>’s <NRP> community. In this session, we unpack the concepts of culture versus religion and discuss current issues and events impacting the <NRP> experience and perspectives. Best practices for allyship and countering bias in the workplace will be shared.

🔯Spotlight on the Jewish Community (1-hr): Introduces participants to key historical and social/cultural events that shape this community, as well as the cultural values and practices that influence the <NRP> experience. The session will also unpack stereotypes, debunk myths, and address antisemitism and its impact in the workplace today. We share best practices for supporting and providing allyship to our colleagues with the community, and how to counter antisemitic bias and microaggressions.

Please see attached one-pagers for each session, that you may share with your stakeholders.

Hope we can connect soon!

activities.note_body: Call Notes 4 April 2024Client: <PERSON>, Head of DEIXYZ: RP, <PERSON>, AlisaPre-call <PERSON> (requests from emails, other <PERSON> came in through <PERSON>. Prior to joining them, she was a contractor through <LOCATION> – not an employee. TS was a client of Korn <URL>e’s been in her role in Oct. Ex Aon Hewitt. Not familiar with our current product offerings. Building out a DEI roadmap at tractor <URL><PERSON>’s email: “I’m securing time to discuss the various solutions that XYZ offers relative to DEI learning solutions. My goal for this discussion is understanding your suite of offerings and share our needs in this space at Tractor Supply Company.”About Tractor Supply:85 years old, publicly traded – NASDAQ, #291 on the <US_DRIVER_LICENSE>, 50k employeesLargest rural retailer in the <LOCATION>, have over 2,200 stores in 49 <URL>actor Supply specializes in providing products for agricultural, rural lifestyle, and home improvement needs. Some of the items typically sold by Tractor Supply include:·         Farming and agricultural supplies such as livestock feed, hay, and bedding.·         Farm equipment and tools including tractors, mowers, and chainsaws.·         Gardening supplies like seeds, fertilizers, and gardening tools.·         Pet care products including food, bedding, and accessories for various animals.·         Home improvement and maintenance items such as hardware, tools, and building materials.·         Outdoor apparel and footwear suitable for work and outdoor activities.·         Livestock and pet feeders, waterers, and containment systems.·         <PERSON> and garden equipment such as lawnmowers, trimmers, and leaf <URL>actor Supply Company's customers are farmers, horse owners, ranchers, part-time and hobby farmers, and suburban and rural homeowners, as well as contractors and <URL>is is Tractor Supply’s DEI page·         ERGs: <NRP> on the RISE, <LOCATION>, Asian Pacific Life Out Here, Women Out Here, <PERSON>, <LOCATION>, LGBTQ+ You Belong OUT Here·         Member of CEO Action for D&ICALL NOTES:I am based in <LOCATION> but 1-3 times a month I travel <LOCATION> – outside of <LOCATION>, our main location.Leadership development from a DEI perspectiveHave been on a 90-day plus tour of the orgOrg has had some level of DEI focus since 2017-182-pronged focus:·         Representation and hiring·         Team member retention (TM = what they call employees) – for distinct groups, cultural awareness and connectivityI have a background in instructional technology (online courses, facilitation, developing training solutions for leaders and others) – 20 years, 1- years in DEICurrently refreshing TM and DEI strategy and roadmap – to offer team members and leadersTraining for Leadership - Folks don’t want to say the wrong thing, so people feel awkward and silence is preferableFrom a UR group perspective – feels performative, not properly developedRP asked about current DEI training.·         Tractor Supply people managers have a very robust 2-day leadership development program – with a DEI component that is embedded, but it needs to change - it’s only 1hour.  It was internally developed. It attempts to touch on UB, microaggressions, and inclusive leadership. Doesn’t go into nuance, how to apply in a real time context. It’s very much like a lecture and not contextualized and not interactive. Not connected to actual people decisions – how to you integrate the employee life cycle moment to these concepts? Make it more robust with breakouts, etc?Also provide annual refresher eLearning/microlearningsPeople don’t understand what DEI is, why it’s important, etc.“Cultural sensitivity training” – how are we thinking about new hire <URL><PERSON>, we call her MK, she’s our CHRO – we talked about solutions in <LOCATION>.       Tools/resources for <PERSON>’s in offices / Distribution centers and stores2.       Specialized folks such as DEI team training, Talent Acquisition, HRBPs3.       Leader bucket – facilitated training, maybe in personWalked her through Managing <PERSON> for People Managers learning journey, gave overview of digital and facilitated workshops. We ran out of <URL>xt steps:·         Send her sample learning journeys, inclusive leadership competencies, list of Spotlights

Call Notes 11 April 2024Client: <PERSON>, Head of DEIXYZ: RP, AlisaI was in <LOCATION> early this week, then going back next weekOn Friday, met with ERGs, Team Member Engagement Groups (Team “Eggs”) – Black group shared – eye opening conv and CEO <PERSON> and his direct reports were there. Black EG brought up a need for “cultural sensitivity training”. CEO <PERSON> is fully locked in and <URL>ere’s fear – retreat and inaction. How does that show up.Looking to solve for:1.      Leaders – Directors and above. Start with CEO and direct reports?a.      Fear shows up in check ins with their reports. How can they connect and lead in a way that’s inclusive? Inclusive coaching, mentorship, sponsorship, conversations & check-ins, equitable development opportunities (including stretch assignments, clients, visible projects), promotions and succession planning, equitable recognition and rewards, confidence around acknowledging and talking about differences vs. staying silent or pretending they don’t exist in service of ‘equality’, engaging with TMEGs.b.      Virtual or face to facec.      Can be subtopics too, not just about the fear – that’s just a high level obstacle.  <PERSON> against what we’re seeing. Create a learning experience that fits for them.e.      Tools and resources where they can feel empowered.f.       There are other areas too – that prohibit this ‘unlock’ – provide resources. A whole experience.2.      HR professionals.a.      Learning for specialized folks such as HRBPs, HR VPs and Sr Directors, Talent Acquisition, Talent Learning and Development team (which includes DEI). There are some niche things that HRBP’s and different groups will have.b.      They’re not always sure how to anchor the conv’s, how to coach around different things – vis a vis people leaders, sr leaders, and individual contributors.c.      Example: there was a team member (TS calls its employees ‘team members’) who changed their profile picture to the Confederate Flag. HRBP was unsure how to handle. How do they position HR partners to talk about things like this? Talk about intent vs. <LOCATION>.      Training that is scenario-based. Talk about TS values, show that we respect everyone, value people as human beings, share stories, show respect to the person.e.      How can we shift mindsets for them to see things that I would naturally see as a DEI person.3.      Individual Contributors. Tools/resources for <PERSON>’s in offices and in distribution centers and stores.a.      More limited bc of their lack of computers and email.b.      Maybe something in the break room on the screen, other tools, short dialogues. Resources they can leverage post session. JIT resources.We don’t want to center the training around “microaggressions” and “unconscious bias” – we want to bring them up organically, as part of realistic examples or scenarios.–       While they’re working through the scenario, can mention ‘that’s a microaggression’ or ‘that’s an example of UB creeping into a people decision that may inadvertently introduce unfairness or exclusion’.–       Like, you’re making a decision – and this happens. How do you recognize it’s happening and what can/do you do to address it?–       Present UB, microaggressions, navigating cultural differences, etc.  in the context of experiences that leaders have in real time.  –       Want to get into the nuances of how microaggressions, UB, monoculturalism and minimization (RP’s words) show up for each role and each function.–       The tools or training can be named “inclusive leadership” or “leading inclusively” or something like that.Here's a draft of something <PERSON> put together (it’s a draft):RP thoughts: LCI, MBML, BCI (use updated names from Chuck)“Out Here Lifestyle” is their motto – rural <LOCATION> – the brand. So, there’s hesitation from some people. Like, “everything is fine, why are we talking about this?” We need a particular approach to ‘disarm them’.  We want people to walk out of our sessions saying ‘I didn’t expect that, I actually thought it was interesting and got something out of it’. Where we surprise them about their assumptions coming <URL>xt steps –Send them info that demonstrates our approach (DIN model, our culture-based approach. DIN model + dimensions of difference) so she can present to leadership (she’s also looking at other vendors):·        Ways we talk about UB, fairness, respect, collaboration –in the context scenarios. Without going in and defining microaggressions, UB…·        Present our frameworks, like an inclusion leadership framework (RP: the UB tree slide), how microaggressions and UB creeps into each of the areas of talent mgmt.·        Examples of tools – how fear shows up and how we approach those conversations (RP: use slides from LCI , brave conversations, POA, understanding microaggressions)·        Have an anchor – use the term ‘inclusive leadership’ or similar  ·        We’re going to take a phased approach. So, maybe a pilot this year.·        Get back to them by end of next week – by Friday the 19th.

activities.subject: RE: Let's catch up on DEI trends - quick call?
activities.body:
Hi, <PERSON> -

I wanted to follow up on my email from last week. I am looking to schedule a brief 20-30 minute call to discuss the current challenges to inclusive leadership and management programs and how our other clients are working to ensure an inclusive workplace that maintains their company's values.

I'd love to hear what you folks are thinking about and what you're planning/doing. I can share what trends I am hearing from other clients and how XYZ can help your organization succeed across differences.

Schedule time: Use this link <<URL>>

I look forward to connecting.

activities.subject: Let's catch up on DEI trends - quick call?
activities.body:
Hi, <PERSON> -

I hope this email finds you well and enjoying the new year.  I am reaching out to a few valued clients-past and present-to schedule a brief listening session about DEI at their organizations.

There is a lot of discourse about DEI right now and much of it is unhelpful to people charged with solving complex people dynamics in the workplace. I'd love to spend a few minutes chatting about what's happening in the space these days. I'm eager to hear about your employee lifecycle challenges, your insights, and share some of the trends we're seeing with our clients.

Would you be open to a brief call next week? I promise to keep it short and valuable.

Let me know if you have 15-30 minutes to spare - I'll be happy to work around your schedule. Below is my <NRP> link if you want to find the best time for you.

<URL>

Looking forward to reconnecting!

activities.subject: RE: Short, high-impact sessions on the <NRP> and the Jewish Experiences in the <LOCATION>
activities.body:
Copying <PERSON> so she can also save this language to send to clients and prospects in the future.

Got it! So they were asking about the J and M Spotlights only. So I’d give him the pricing, tell him it’s for up to 100 ppl per session, and ab the recordings say something like:

About the recordings, we don't typically recommend recording and sharing live sessions, especially around sensitive, culture-specific topics like this, because (a) we strive to make these Spotlights be safe spaces for participants to share, and not feel like their comments will be saved and viewed by others who didn’t attend, (b) people may be less likely to share, comment, or ask questions if they know it’s being recorded, (c) a problematic comment or even a leader saying something ‘inelegant’ is saved for others to view and then possibly quote out of context. We can fit up to 100 folks per session, do you think having 2 or 3 live sessions at different days/times might work for <PERSON>?  Or if you are able to commit to 5+ sessions, we can offer a 10% discount.




<PERSON><

activities.subject: Short, high-impact sessions on the <NRP> and the Jewish Experiences in the <LOCATION>
activities.body:
CAUTION: This email originated from outside of the organization. Do not click links or open attachments unless you recognize the sender and know the content is safe.

Hi Shane,​

We’re thrilled to shared that we’re launching two brand new Spotlight sessions aimed at highlighting the experiences, influences, values and rich cultures of the <NRP> and <NRP> communities in the <LOCATION>

Our Spotlights are one-hour, interactive, deep-dive workshops are focused on the experience of being a member of these communities, and contribute to building cultural competence, inclusion skills, and a culture of belonging throughout your organization.

☪️Spotlight on the Muslim Community (1-hr)
This session explores the complexities of being <NRP> in <LOCATION> and the simultaneously varied and shared experiences and worldviews of <LOCATION>’s <NRP> community. In this session, we unpack the concepts of culture versus religion and discuss current issues and events impacting the <NRP> experience and perspectives. Best practices for allyship and countering bias in the workplace will be shared. Session objectives:

  *   Explore factors that have shaped the lived experiences and cultural values of the <NRP> community, including shared experiences and common influences
  *   Recognize the depth and diversity of the <NRP> community in the <LOCATION>
  *   Discuss <NRP> sentiment (especially since 9/11) and its impact on the <NRP> community
  *   Explore strategies to support and be an ally to your <NRP> colleagues and the community at large

🔯Spotlight on the Jewish Community (1-hr)
This session introduces participants to key historical and social/cultural events that shape this community, as well as the cultural values and practices that influence the <NRP> experience. The session will also unpack stereotypes, debunk myths, and address antisemitism and its impact in the workplace today. We share best practices for supporting and providing allyship to our colleagues with the community, and how to counter antisemitic bias and microaggressions. Session objectives:

  *   Explore factors that have shaped the lived experiences and cultural values of the <NRP> community, including shared experiences and common influences.
  *   Recognize the depth and diversity of the <NRP> community in the <LOCATION>
  *   Discuss the current state of Antisemitism and its impact on the <NRP> community.
  *   Explore strategies to support and be an ally to your <NRP> colleagues and the community at large.
Below are one-pagers for each session, that you may share with your stakeholders.

Other Spotlights that you may consider for 2024:

  *   Being an Ally for the Asian American Community (May, AAPI Heritage Month)
  *   Spotlight on the LGBTQ+ Community (June, LGBTQ+ Pride Month)
  *   Spotlight on Persons with Disabilities (July, Disability Pride Month)
  *   Spotlight on U.S. Generations (April, August, December, anytime)
  *   Spotlight on the <NRP>/Latinx/e Community (September, Hispanic Heritage Month 9/15-10/15)
  *   Spotlight on Indigenous People in <LOCATION> (October, Indigenous Peoples’ Day or November, Native American Heritage Month)
  *   Spotlight on the U.S. Veterans Community (November, Veterans’ Day)
If you have any questions and would like to connect, please let me what days work best and I’ll send over some times.

[Image removed by sender.]
[Image removed by sender.]

activities.subject: BRG/ERG Support
activities.body:
Hi, <PERSON> -

It was wonderful to connect this week with you. Its been a while.

Per our call, I am attaching information on BRG/ERG toolkit that we developed for a client who needed some added assistance in 'professionalizing' their approach to BRG/ERGs. They found that they didn't have a standard model, or even a standard set of expectations for their BRGs, as each had developed organically over the years. They also found that their Executive Sponsorship was inconsistent among the BRGs.

We led multiple conversations with represented populations to see what they know of BRGs at the organization, what they expected from their BRGs, and what was keeping them from joining (if they hadn't). We also spoke to the business leadership to understand their expectations. We then used this data to form the training and consulting interventions for both the BRG leaders and the executive sponsors.

I will schedule some time next week to discuss any questions you might have.

<PERSON>

<PERSON> (He/Him)
Chief Executive Officer

activities.subject: Proposals from XYZ: Cultural Competency Training
activities.body:
Hi, <PERSON>.

Thanks again for giving us the opportunity to partner with Envestnet to optimize collaboration among your <LOCATION> and <LOCATION> development teams – in particular when it comes to understanding and bridging cultural differences.

Attached are two proposals:

  *   Proposal A outlines cultural competence workshops that align with your desired outcomes, with some discovery work on the front end
  *   Proposal B outlines a cultural competence curriculum that includes the same workshops, and is designed to support participants with scalable digital courseware, prework, post-workshop learning reinforcements, as well as more robust discovery/diagnostics on the front end

We’ve assumed one session for the <LOCATION> and 3 sessions for <LOCATION>, but we can adjust those as needed.

Finally, we realize that your RFP also asked us to include testimonials or case studies from previous clients who have benefited from our services. We’ll follow up with those under separate cover if that’s okay. We wanted to send you the main proposal as quickly as possible!

<PERSON>, if the attached is only almost right for your needs, then we look forward to hearing from you so that we can respond swiftly, make adjustments, and get you what you need to ensure alignment.

We look forward to working with you!

activities.subject: Follow-up question RE: Cultural Competency Training
activities.body:
Hello Envestnet team, how are you today?

I’d like to clarify numbers of participants per workshop.

During our conversation last week I thought I heard that out of the approx. 512 participants, 75-100 are people managers.

I thought I also heard that out of the group of 512, about 70% are in <LOCATION> and 30% in the <LOCATION> Is that right?

I’m trying to discern how many workshops would be needed for <LOCATION>-based folks (about <LOCATION> cultural styles and contexts) vs. <LOCATION>-based folks (about <NRP> cultural styles and contexts.)

If we cap our workshops at 100, then based on the above we’d initially plan on:

  *   About 4 sessions for <NRP> audiences
  *   About 2 sessions for <NRP> audiences

There would be a mix of managers and individual contributors in each session.

Thanks!

<PERSON> (MBA, Latina, <NRP>, Mom)

*Multiple teams (Development team, QA function team, product team, business analysts, operations, and etc) working together daily (Scrum team has daily standups) in <LOCATION> and <LOCATION>.
*Teams tend to be 30-50% working in <LOCATION> and 50-70% working in the <LOCATION>.
*Junior emerging leaders in <LOCATION> have had less exposure working with <LOCATION> team leaders (i.e. more limited resources and turnover in <LOCATION>) and are not operating with as effective of collaboration as Senior leaders in <LOCATION>.
*Increase confidence with teams in <LOCATION> to support communication and collaboration with teams in the <LOCATION>.

Looking forward to the opportunity to work with you,

<PERSON> and Team XYZ

activities.subject: RE: Revised Cultural Competency Proposal from XYZ ("Proposal C")
activities.body:
Hi <PERSON>.

This is obviously very disappointing, but we understand.

That said, it would be extremely helpful for us as an organization to understand specifically why we weren't chosen, why the other vendor was chosen, and also who is the vendor you chose (if you don't mind). The budget reason is pretty clear, but we'd love to further understand where our customization abilities (or other areas) fell short, as compared to the other vendor. Is it possible to have a quick 10-15  min call about this? Or, email is fine too if that's easier for you!  Getting your feedback is extremely important to us as we continue our journey, as it would help us to understand the areas where we can improve. It would honestly mean a lot to us and to me (and to <PERSON>) personally.

activities.subject: RE: Revised Cultural Competency Proposal from XYZ ("Proposal C")
activities.body:
Hello XYZ team,

We appreciate the time and effort you invested in preparing and submitting your proposals in response to our recent request for cultural competency training.

After careful consideration of all submitted proposals, we have decided on another vendor.  While your proposal demonstrated several strengths, ultimately alignment on budget and customization needs were met elsewhere.

We genuinely value the opportunity to review your proposal and the conversations we had on this project.  We want to extend our gratitude for your interest and participation in the process and still regard XYZ as an expert in the space.

Although your proposal was not selected on this occasion, we believe XYZ's capabilities and expertise may align with our needs in the future.
Thanks again, and please do not hesitate to reach out if you have any questions.

activities.subject: Revised Cultural Competency Proposal from XYZ ("Proposal C")
activities.body:
EXTERNAL MAIL: USE CAUTION BEFORE CLICKING LINKS OR OPENING ATTACHMENTS. ALWAYS VERIFY THE SOURCE OF MESSAGES.
Hi, Envestnet team -

Attached please find a revised proposal, which includes onsite, in person sessions vs. virtual.

As I thought through the one-facilitator model for these sessions, I realized I was too quick in my response during our meeting last week. I wasn't thinking about how large these groups were (75-100), plus to get the full learning across these culture-specific, longer workshops we do require one cultural insider (a member of the culture being taught about) and an ally (non-culture member) to deliver and model the concepts and strategies in the content. In this case, for "Working with the USA", a <LOCATION> American DEI expert would be the cultural insider and the ally would ideally be an <NRP> cofacilitator (we'd scan our global network to find someone in <LOCATION>). An <NRP> DEI expert would be the cultural insider for "Working with India" and the ally would be an <NRP>.

We can develop a shorter post-workshop sessions specifically for people managers, as we talked about last week. We can discuss what that would look like, and add those to this SOW or create a separate SOW in the future - whichever option works best for you. There would be a development cost and a facilitation cost for such a session. For a one hour session, for example, the cost ballpark would be about $4-$5k for development (assuming about two days of work) and then about $4500k for virtual facilitation and $10k for onsite facilitation.

Finally, is there anything that we haven't asked you or talked about that  you need from this initiative?

activities.subject: Revised Cultural Competency Proposal from XYZ ("Proposal C")
activities.body:
EXTERNAL MAIL: USE CAUTION BEFORE CLICKING LINKS OR OPENING ATTACHMENTS. ALWAYS VERIFY THE SOURCE OF MESSAGES.

Hi, Envestnet team –



Attached please find a revised proposal, which includes onsite, in person sessions vs. virtual.



As I thought through the one-facilitator model for these sessions, I realized I was too quick in my response during our meeting last week. I wasn’t thinking about how large these groups were (75-100), plus to get the full learning across these culture-specific, longer workshops we do require one cultural insider (a member of the culture being taught about) and an ally (non-culture member) to deliver and model the concepts and strategies in the content. In this case, for “Working with the USA”, a <LOCATION> American DEI expert would be the cultural insider and the ally would ideally be an <NRP> cofacilitator (we’d scan our global network to find someone in <LOCATION>). An <NRP> DEI expert would be the cultural insider for “Working with India” and the ally would be an <NRP>.



We can develop a shorter post-workshop sessions specifically for people managers, as we talked about last week. We can discuss what that would look like, and add those to this SOW or create a separate SOW in the future – whichever option works best for you. There would be a development cost and a facilitation cost for such a session. For a one hour session, for example, the cost ballpark would be about $4-$5k for development (assuming about two days of work) and then about $4500k for virtual facilitation and $10k for onsite facilitation.



Finally, is there anything that we haven’t asked you or talked about that  you need from this initiative?
