activities.subject: Short, high-impact sessions on the <NRP> and the Jewish Experiences in the <LOCATION>
activities.body:
Hi Tisha,​

We’re thrilled to shared that we’re launching two brand new Spotlight sessions aimed at highlighting the experiences, influences, values and rich cultures of the <NRP> and <NRP> communities in the <LOCATION>

Our Spotlights are one-hour, interactive, deep-dive workshops are focused on the experience of being a member of these communities, and contribute to building cultural competence, inclusion skills, and a culture of belonging throughout your organization. 

☪️Spotlight on the Muslim Community (1-hr)
This session explores the complexities of being <NRP> in <LOCATION> and the simultaneously varied and shared experiences and worldviews of <LOCATION>’s <NRP> community. In this session, we unpack the concepts of culture versus religion and discuss current issues and events impacting the <NRP> experience and perspectives. Best practices for allyship and countering bias in the workplace will be shared. Session objectives:
Explore factors that have shaped the lived experiences and cultural values of the <NRP> community, including shared experiences and common influences Recognize the depth and diversity of the <NRP> community in the <LOCATION> Discuss <NRP> sentiment (especially since 9/11) and its impact on the <NRP> community Explore strategies to support and be an ally to your <NRP> colleagues and the community at large 
🔯Spotlight on the Jewish Community (1-hr)
This session introduces participants to key historical and social/cultural events that shape this community, as well as the cultural values and practices that influence the <NRP> experience. The session will also unpack stereotypes, debunk myths, and address antisemitism and its impact in the workplace today. We share best practices for supporting and providing allyship to our colleagues with the community, and how to counter antisemitic bias and microaggressions. Session objectives:
Explore factors that have shaped the lived experiences and cultural values of the <NRP> community, including shared experiences and common influences. Recognize the depth and diversity of the <NRP> community in the <LOCATION> Discuss the current state of Antisemitism and its impact on the <NRP> community. Explore strategies to support and be an ally to your <NRP> colleagues and the community at large. Below are one-pagers for each session, that you may share with your stakeholders. 

Other Spotlights that you may consider for 2024:
Being an Ally for the Asian American Community (May, AAPI Heritage Month) Spotlight on the LGBTQ+ Community (June, LGBTQ+ Pride Month) Spotlight on Persons with Disabilities (July, Disability Pride Month) Spotlight on U.S. Generations (April, August, December, anytime) Spotlight on the <NRP>/Latinx/e Community (September, Hispanic Heritage Month 9/15-10/15) Spotlight on Indigenous People in <LOCATION> (October, Indigenous Peoples’ Day or November, Native American Heritage Month) Spotlight on the U.S. Veterans Community (November, Veterans’ Day) If you have any questions and would like to connect, please let me what days work best and I’ll send over some times.

activities.subject: TD Bank's equity learning program
activities.body:
Hi <PERSON>,

How are you?  I hope you’re doing well.



We’d love to continue our conversation about supporting your the equity learning program.



Obviously there’s a lot of discourse about DEI right now and much of it is unhelpful to people charged with solving complex people dynamics in the workplace. We’re emphasizing ensuring people understand what we mean by inclusion and equity (countering some of the media narrative re: ‘DEI’ being about discrimination) and that inclusion means everyone, continuing to find ways to collect useful and compelling data that shows inconsistent experiences within the org (in particular around development/career advancement opportunities, pay, promotion rates, and psychological safety), and designing/embedding inclusive practices into the org’s day-to-day operations rather than it being perceived as a separate thing.



This new HBR article by <PERSON><<URL>> talks about the current landscape as an opportunity to reimagine or ‘reset’ DEI. Lily presents the FAIR acronym, which is substantially similar to DEI. However, I want to highlight <PERSON>’s intriguing reframing  of the ‘R’ which stands for representation. Framing representation as a matter of transparency, trust, and a track record of accountability. Here’s an excerpt:

If a product team aims to build products “for all people” but does not consult or include perspectives from a key audience in their design process, that audience lacks representation — even if a member of the product team shares an identity with that audience…. Representation is a matter of trust, not tokenism. While people may be slightly more inclined to trust those who share identities in common with them, trust is more dependent on the behavior and track record of those in power. It’s possible for a leadership team made up entirely of women to be non-representative of women if none of the leaders take the effort to understand and advocate for the needs of the women they supposedly represent. On the other hand, it’s possible that a product team without direct experience living in rural communities might be very representative of rural communities due to frequent communication, active outreach, and ongoing efforts to understand and advocate for rural communities’ needs.



What are TD Bank’s inclusion goals for 2025? I’d love to hear about them… including what kind of support you’re getting from leadership.



Would you be open to a brief call next week or the next?



Looking forward to reconnecting!



Copying my colleague <PERSON> – as my bandwidth has been tricky lately, I want to make sure one of us replies as quickly as possible.

activities.subject: RE: We're here for you
activities.body:
So great to hear from you. I understand about the timing of the equity program, and we look forward to hearing more soon.  Take good care of yourself!



<PERSON><

activities.subject: RE: We're here for you
activities.body:
Hi <PERSON>,



Thanks so much for reaching out, it's a difficult time on our end as you can imagine. I was actually going to follow up with you next week as I know we owe you an update. We've put the equity learning program on pause for now given the impending change in leadership at the top of the house. Our plan is to still carry forward with work on advancing equity, we're just working with leadership to determine next steps at this time. We appreciate your offer of support and will be in touch once we know more.



Have a nice weekend!

activities.subject: We're here for you
activities.body:
CAUTION: EXTERNAL MAIL. DO NOT CLICK ON LINKS OR OPEN ATTACHMENTS YOU DO NOT TRUST
ATTENTION : COURRIEL EXTERNE. NE CLIQUEZ PAS SUR DES LIENS ET N'OUVREZ PAS DE PIÈCES JOINTES AUXQUELS VOUS NE FAITES PAS CONFIANCE



Hi <PERSON>, wanted to acknowledge the events surrounding TD Bank this week and how difficult this must be for many of you.

Please know we’re here for you in terms of adding the intercultural competence and inclusion lens to any training interventions for your leaders or other employees.

Wishing you a restful weekend –

<PERSON><PERSON><

activities.subject: Hi <PERSON>
activities.body:
Hi <PERSON>, how are you, especially considering the DEI pullback lately by companies like Harley Davidson, Ford, Lowe’s, <PERSON>, <PERSON> and Tractor Supply?  Their statements (except perhaps Tractor Supply’s) seem to want it both ways, saying that inclusion and diversity are still incredibly important, and at the same time making extreme <LOCATION> conservative activists happy by retrenching on things like <NRP> inclusion (specifically removing themselves from the HRC Equality Index and/or promising not to participate in any more Pride parades). It’s extremely disheartening that they’re all copying each other on this – I can see how targeting the LGBTQ+ community is the ‘easiest’ target, we’re such a minority, the object of so much far-right rage, and historically ‘safe enough’ to ignore. I have also seen companies dissolve their DEI teams, instead merging the practice into OD, Learning &  Development, or other areas under HR. So sad.



On the flip side, congratulations on being ranked #9 on Forbes list of <LOCATION>’s Best Employers for Diversity 2024 for the 6th consecutive year and #20 on Fair360's list of 2024 Top 50 Companies for the 12th year in a row!



I know a while ago we talked about strategies to upskill TD Bank’s leaders around equity and belonging. Should we continue those discussions, or did you move in a different direction? Either way, I’d love to know, and also stay in touch and hopefully at some point there will be an opportunity for us to help operationalize your DEI strategy.



I’d be glad to set up a quick meeting (15 or 30 min) to connect!

activities.subject: RE: Checking in - hope I'm not bothering you
activities.body:
Hi <PERSON> – I hope you are well.



I have transitioned to another department, but <PERSON> will keep you updated on progress.



Feel free to reach out to her directly for any further inquiries.  You can also remove me from any correspondence.



Thank you, and all the best.



<PERSON> | Instructional Designer III | TD Bank Group

700 W Georgia Street, 3rd Floor, TD Bank Tower, <LOCATION> | C: <UK_NHS>



Pronouns:  She/Her



"My working day (Pacific Standard Time) may not be your working day.  Please do not feel obliged to reply to this email outside of your normal working hours."







Internal

activities.subject: Checking in - hope I'm not bothering you
activities.body:
Hi, <PERSON> and <PERSON> – how are you? It’s been a little while since we spoke.



I wanted to check in and see how it was going with your plans around upskilling TD Bank leaders around equity and belonging.  I saw that TD Bank just created an Community Ad Board to support its Community Impact Plan for financial and social inclusion in the communities you serve.  And holy cow you got some stellar experience and skills on the Board – from the Chair of Pres. <PERSON>’s board of advisors on HBCU’s, to the President and CEO of the National Assn for Latino Community Asset Builders, the ex-CDO of J&J, the President of the Urban League, the President of NeighborWorks and the President of the NCRC – many congratulations, you’re investing and doing it the right way.



Would love to get an update from you on what you’re thinking and strategizing about. What do you think about setting up a quick meeting?



Warmly,

<PERSON>





<PERSON><

<PERSON> and <PERSON>,



Thanks again for giving us the opportunity to partner with TD Bank to drive structural equity in your organization. And thank you for answering all of our questions in the past few days. We ask questions so that we can provide you with our ‘best’ recommendations, given your goals and context.



Attached are:

  *   Our proposal, and
  *   A short supplement about the Intercultural Development Inventory assessment, which we’re recommending as part of the overall equity audit/assessment



Team, this is what we propose based on our experience and expertise around ‘doing it right’ and setting yourselves up for the best results. However, we completely understand that there are many constraints that may exist (time, budget, etc.). So if the attached is only almost right for your needs, then we look forward to hearing from you so that we can respond swiftly, make adjustments, and get you what you need to ensure alignment!



We’d love to set up a time to walk you through the proposal, if you’d find that helpful.



We look forward to working with you!

activities.subject: RE: Follow-up about Strengthening Equity work from XYZ
activities.body:
You don't often get email from <EMAIL_ADDRESS><mailto:<EMAIL_ADDRESS>>. Learn why this is important<<URL>>

Hi <PERSON> - thank you sincerely for your incredible patience as we finalize arrangements for potential vendors to support our equity work.



At this stage, we're in need of a more formalized proposal and quote outlining the services you can provide.



I've attached the scope of work document from November to refresh your memory on our requirements, but I'd also like to offer some additional guidance to help shape the proposal.



We're interested in a 2-hour, in-person training session that is highly tailored to our organization, with a strong emphasis on TD-centric context.  The audience will include a mix of Executive VPs, and Senior Executives (~50 members).  We're keen to understand how you plan to engage this audience, particularly at the senior executive level.



What would also be helpful is some insight into how the training experience will unfold, including key messages and anticipated takeaways.



Could you please let me know if you're able to provide a proposal, and if so, by when?



Once again – thank you for your patience as we continue to move forward with our evaluation.

activities.subject: TD Bank's equity learning program
activities.body:
Hi <PERSON>,

How are you?  I hope you’re doing well.



We’d love to continue our conversation about supporting your the equity learning program.



Obviously there’s a lot of discourse about DEI right now and much of it is unhelpful to people charged with solving complex people dynamics in the workplace. We’re emphasizing ensuring people understand what we mean by inclusion and equity (countering some of the media narrative re: ‘DEI’ being about discrimination) and that inclusion means everyone, continuing to find ways to collect useful and compelling data that shows inconsistent experiences within the org (in particular around development/career advancement opportunities, pay, promotion rates, and psychological safety), and designing/embedding inclusive practices into the org’s day-to-day operations rather than it being perceived as a separate thing.



This new HBR article by <PERSON><URL>> talks about the current landscape as an opportunity to reimagine or ‘reset’ DEI. Lily presents the FAIR acronym, which is substantially similar to DEI. However, I want to highlight <PERSON>’s intriguing reframing  of the ‘R’ which stands for representation. Framing representation as a matter of transparency, trust, and a track record of accountability. Here’s an excerpt:

If a product team aims to build products “for all people” but does not consult or include perspectives from a key audience in their design process, that audience lacks representation — even if a member of the product team shares an identity with that audience…. Representation is a matter of trust, not tokenism. While people may be slightly more inclined to trust those who share identities in common with them, trust is more dependent on the behavior and track record of those in power. It’s possible for a leadership team made up entirely of women to be non-representative of women if none of the leaders take the effort to understand and advocate for the needs of the women they supposedly represent. On the other hand, it’s possible that a product team without direct experience living in rural communities might be very representative of rural communities due to frequent communication, active outreach, and ongoing efforts to understand and advocate for rural communities’ needs.



What are TD Bank’s inclusion goals for 2025? I’d love to hear about them… including what kind of support you’re getting from leadership.



Would you be open to a brief call next week or the next?



Looking forward to reconnecting!



Copying my colleague <PERSON> – as my bandwidth has been tricky lately, I want to make sure one of us replies as quickly as possible.

activities.subject: RE: Follow-up about Strengthening Equity work from XYZ
activities.body:
You don't often get email from <EMAIL_ADDRESS><mailto:<EMAIL_ADDRESS>>. Learn why this is important<<URL>>

Hi <PERSON> - thank you sincerely for your incredible patience as we finalize arrangements for potential vendors to support our equity work.



At this stage, we're in need of a more formalized proposal and quote outlining the services you can provide.



I've attached the scope of work document from November to refresh your memory on our requirements, but I'd also like to offer some additional guidance to help shape the proposal.



We're interested in a 2-hour, in-person training session that is highly tailored to our organization, with a strong emphasis on TD-centric context.  The audience will include a mix of Executive VPs, and Senior Executives (~50 members).  We're keen to understand how you plan to engage this audience, particularly at the senior executive level.



What would also be helpful is some insight into how the training experience will unfold, including key messages and anticipated takeaways.



Could you please let me know if you're able to provide a proposal, and if so, by when?



Once again – thank you for your patience as we continue to move forward with our evaluation.

activities.subject: Hi <PERSON>
activities.body:
Hi <PERSON>, how are you, especially considering the DEI pullback lately by companies like Harley Davidson, Ford, Lowe's, <PERSON>, Jack Daniel's and Tractor Supply?  Their statements (except perhaps Tractor Supply's) seem to want it both ways, saying that inclusion and diversity are still incredibly important, and at the same time making extreme <LOCATION> conservative activists happy by retrenching on things like <NRP> inclusion (specifically removing themselves from the HRC Equality Index and/or promising not to participate in any more Pride parades). It's extremely disheartening that they're all copying each other on this - I can see how targeting the LGBTQ+ community is the 'easiest' target, we're such a minority, the object of so much far-right rage, and historically 'safe enough' to ignore. I have also seen companies dissolve their DEI teams, instead merging the practice into OD, Learning &  Development, or other areas under HR. So sad.

On the flip side, congratulations on being ranked #9 on Forbes list of <LOCATION>'s Best Employers for Diversity 2024 for the 6th consecutive year and #20 on Fair360's list of 2024 Top 50 Companies for the 12th year in a row!

I know a while ago we talked about strategies to upskill TD Bank's leaders around equity and belonging. Should we continue those discussions, or did you move in a different direction? Either way, I'd love to know, and also stay in touch and hopefully at some point there will be an opportunity for us to help operationalize your DEI strategy.

I'd be glad to set up a quick meeting (15 or 30 min) to connect!

activities.subject: Checking in - hope I'm not bothering you
activities.body:
Hi, <PERSON> and <PERSON> - how are you? It's been a little while since we spoke.

I wanted to check in and see how it was going with your plans around upskilling TD Bank leaders around equity and belonging.  I saw that TD Bank just created an Community Ad Board to support its Community Impact Plan for financial and social inclusion in the communities you serve.  And holy cow you got some stellar experience and skills on the Board - from the Chair of Pres. <PERSON>'s board of advisors on HBCU's, to the President and CEO of the National Assn for Latino Community Asset Builders, the ex-CDO of J&J, the President of the Urban League, the President of NeighborWorks and the President of the NCRC - many congratulations, you're investing and doing it the right way.

Would love to get an update from you on what you're thinking and strategizing about. What do you think about setting up a quick meeting?

Warmly,
<PERSON><PERSON><

activities.subject: RE: Scheduling mtg in early Dec?
activities.body:
Hi <PERSON>Apologies for the delay we have been waiting on a couple of internal discussions which we have now had.

We would like to revisit the proposal with the focus to start being:

  *   Facilitation of Unconscious Bias training sessions with facilitated open conversations on DEIB topics
  *   Explore accreditation for e2open designated team members to facilitate trainings

The proposal we have received is fantastic and very detailed but I think is an aspirational learning journey, we need to crawl before we run. We need first to set the tone and share insights and awareness before we look to embed into the learning culture (at this time anyway).

If you can in the mean time look at a scaled back version that would be really appreciated.

activities.body:
PHISH ALERT! CHECK VALIDITY IF CLICKING, SHARING, RESPONDING

Hi <PERSON>,

Thanks for your message, and I hope you enjoy a well-deserved break! I appreciate the heads-up about your return to the office on January 3rd.

We are definitely on board for catching up in the new year to discuss the amendments and plans. It sounds like a great way to kick off 2024. Would you like to get a January meeting in the books now, or should we follow up with you after the 3rd?

Wishing you happy holidays!

activities.subject: RE: Scheduling mtg in early Dec?
activities.body:
PHISH ALERT! CHECK VALIDITY IF CLICKING, SHARING, RESPONDING

Hi <PERSON>,

We can definitely make the adjustments to our proposal.

Re: the unconscious bias training:

  *   Which constituencies should we be targeting in the revised proposal?  The ELT? People Managers? Both? Individual contributors?  We have UB sessions targeted to 'everyone' and another targeted to people leaders that goes deeper into how UB influences how we treat/evaluate people.[Comment/Remark SMa]  We want to cover all team members including leaders/executives
  *   We can certainly facilitate open conversations on DEIB topics, or alternatively we could supply you with <PERSON> so that E2open can facilitate these conversations internally
  *   We can definitely provide accreditation/Train-the-Trainer option for your internal team of facilitators.

Is there any way you could fit in a 30-minute meeting next week with <PERSON> and I, to talk through this real quick, so we have what we need to send you the updated proposal?

Look forward to hearing from you!

Woo hoo! $40k of new money! <PERSON> and I will design and deliver this (she already said yes), so it will be like a pilot for a new product!

activities.subject: Quickly poking our head in
activities.body:
Hi <PERSON>, just checking in again on status for this project.

Please note that we are very open to discussing your budget and adapting a plan that meets your needs. Our goal is to partner with you to find the best, most cost-effective solutions for E2open. We'd love to have the opportunity to respond to your concerns and make adjustments to ensure alignment.

Best!
<PERSON><PERSON> (MBA, Latina, <NRP>, Mom)
(she/her) Why pronouns matter<

activities.subject: RE: Gentle followup: New proposal options for E2open
activities.body:
Hi <PERSON>! Sorry to bother you again - I just re-read our notes from our last meeting and noticed you mentioned you wanted to make a decision by March 1st, which is approaching quickly. Lmk if you'd like to set up a meeting. If we are going to be working together, I also want to ensure we have all our ducks in a row on our end in terms of resource allocation. Thank you! <PERSON><PERSON>
(she/her)
Head of Client Solutions
XYZ

activities.subject: RE: Gentle followup: New proposal options for E2open
activities.body:

As always, please let us know if you need help with anything.
Best!
<PERSON><PERSON>
(she/her)

XYZ

activities.subject: Gentle followup: New proposal options for E2open
activities.body:
Hi <PERSON>,
How are you?
<PERSON> and I are hoping that the revised proposals were clear.
Would it be convenient for you if we scheduled a meeting to walk you through it and answer your questions (next week, the week after, the week after that - whatever works for you)?
I can't believe it's almost February!

activities.subject: WSJ article "Corporate America Tweaks Diversity Initiatives" & my analysis
activities.body:
Hi <PERSON>,

As you continue to be a SME for E2open’s top leaders, I wanted to send you this article which you may have already seen. It’s pretty short, and gives language about the current challenges in corporate <LOCATION> (which are spreading to other parts of the world, unfortunately). You can help your stakeholders make sense of it.

Here are my thoughts. It seems to me the two main points that are being pushed back against are:

  1.  Hiring or promotion ‘quotas’ (which is something that XYZ or any other DEI professional I know or have worked with has ever recommended) and
  2.  ‘Blaming’ white populations by, for example, calling people ‘white supremacists’ or stating something ridiculous like all white people are racist.

Neither of the points above are part of what achieving DEI is all about. Inclusive practices are alive and well, and I think that most organizations understand that there’s no going back.

<URL><<URL>>

activities.subject: Do you know of a team struggling with alignment or interpersonal issues?
activities.body:
Dear <PERSON>,

Hope you’re having a productive <US_DRIVER_LICENSE> – I can’t believe it’s almost over already!

I know we’re currently in communication, just wanted to let you about a new XYZ offering.

<PERSON> said that “culture eats strategy for breakfast” – and we continue to see examples that prove him right. 

We’ve developed an intensive program where we help team members create the team culture they need and crave to succeed. 

This workshop is for intact teams who are struggling with issues that are interfering with their performance due to ineffective communication and/or working relationships, for example:
- Interpersonal issues
- Issues with the leader/manager 
- Poor group dynamics
- Harmful microbehaviors
The workshop content has its strong foundation, but we tailor it based on interviews, focus groups, or surveys of all team members. This is key. During the program itself, facilitators and your stakeholder together, create a “brave” space for all participants to feel heard and be engaged During the program, participants co-create a Team Charter: five to seven concrete behaviors that all team members will commit to going forward The workshop is facilitated by 2 highly skilled professionals who coach participants to arrive at solutions The workshop is designed for intact teams of up to 20 participants, conducive to deep attention to key issues that are getting in their way If this intervention sounds like something that would help remove an obstacle for your team (or another team in your org), we’d love to hear more and see if/how we could help. 

Simply reply to this email and we can send a few available timeslots for you to choose from, or you could send us your availability if you prefer.

activities.subject: RE: Revised Cultural Competency Proposal from XYZ ("Proposal C")
activities.body:
Hello XYZ team,



We appreciate the time and effort you invested in preparing and submitting your proposals in response to our recent request for cultural competency training.



After careful consideration of all submitted proposals, we have decided on another vendor.  While your proposal demonstrated several strengths, ultimately alignment on budget and customization needs were met elsewhere.



We genuinely value the opportunity to review your proposal and the conversations we had on this project.  We want to extend our gratitude for your interest and participation in the process and still regard XYZ as an expert in the space.



Although your proposal was not selected on this occasion, we believe XYZ’s capabilities and expertise may align with our needs in the future.

Thanks again, and please do not hesitate to reach out if you have any questions.

activities.subject: Revised Cultural Competency Proposal from XYZ ("Proposal C")
activities.body:
EXTERNAL MAIL: USE CAUTION BEFORE CLICKING LINKS OR OPENING ATTACHMENTS. ALWAYS VERIFY THE SOURCE OF MESSAGES.

Hi, Envestnet team –



Attached please find a revised proposal, which includes onsite, in person sessions vs. virtual.



As I thought through the one-facilitator model for these sessions, I realized I was too quick in my response during our meeting last week. I wasn’t thinking about how large these groups were (75-100), plus to get the full learning across these culture-specific, longer workshops we do require one cultural insider (a member of the culture being taught about) and an ally (non-culture member) to deliver and model the concepts and strategies in the content. In this case, for “Working with the USA”, a <LOCATION> American DEI expert would be the cultural insider and the ally would ideally be an <NRP> cofacilitator (we’d scan our global network to find someone in <LOCATION>). An <NRP> DEI expert would be the cultural insider for “Working with India” and the ally would be an <NRP>.



We can develop a shorter post-workshop sessions specifically for people managers, as we talked about last week. We can discuss what that would look like, and add those to this SOW or create a separate SOW in the future – whichever option works best for you. There would be a development cost and a facilitation cost for such a session. For a one hour session, for example, the cost ballpark would be about $4-$5k for development (assuming about two days of work) and then about $4500k for virtual facilitation and $10k for onsite facilitation.



Finally, is there anything that we haven’t asked you or talked about that  you need from this initiative?

activities.subject: Proposals from XYZ: Cultural Competency Training
activities.body:
Hi, <PERSON>.



Thanks again for giving us the opportunity to partner with Envestnet to optimize collaboration among your <LOCATION> and <LOCATION> development teams – in particular when it comes to understanding and bridging cultural differences.



Attached are two proposals:

  *   Proposal A outlines cultural competence workshops that align with your desired outcomes, with some discovery work on the front end
  *   Proposal B outlines a cultural competence curriculum that includes the same workshops, and is designed to support participants with scalable digital courseware, prework, post-workshop learning reinforcements, as well as more robust discovery/diagnostics on the front end



We’ve assumed one session for the <LOCATION> and 3 sessions for <LOCATION>, but we can adjust those as needed.



Finally, we realize that your RFP also asked us to include testimonials or case studies from previous clients who have benefited from our services. We’ll follow up with those under separate cover if that’s okay. We wanted to send you the main proposal as quickly as possible!



<PERSON>, if the attached is only almost right for your needs, then we look forward to hearing from you so that we can respond swiftly, make adjustments, and get you what you need to ensure alignment.



We look forward to working with you!

activities.subject: Follow-up question RE: Cultural Competency Training
activities.body:
Hello Envestnet team, how are you today?



I’d like to clarify numbers of participants per workshop.



During our conversation last week I thought I heard that out of the approx. 512 participants, 75-100 are people managers.



I thought I also heard that out of the group of 512, about 70% are in <LOCATION> and 30% in the <LOCATION> Is that right?



I’m trying to discern how many workshops would be needed for <LOCATION>-based folks (about <LOCATION> cultural styles and contexts) vs. <LOCATION>-based folks (about <NRP> cultural styles and contexts.)



If we cap our workshops at 100, then based on the above we’d initially plan on:

  *   About 4 sessions for <NRP> audiences
  *   About 2 sessions for <NRP> audiences



There would be a mix of managers and individual contributors in each session.



Thanks!



<PERSON> (MBA, Latina, <NRP>, Mom)

(she/her) Why pronouns matter<

Takeaways:

*Multiple teams (Development team, QA function team, product team, business analysts, operations, and etc) working together daily (Scrum team has daily standups) in <LOCATION> and <LOCATION>.

*Junior emerging leaders in <LOCATION> have had less exposure working with <LOCATION> team leaders (i.e. more limited resources and turnover in <LOCATION>) and are not operating with as effective of collaboration as Senior leaders in <LOCATION>.

*Increase confidence with teams in <LOCATION> to support communication and collaboration with teams in the <LOCATION>.

*Cultural competence for teams in <LOCATION> and <LOCATION> to best understand one another’s communication styles.



Looking forward to the opportunity to work with you,



<PERSON> and Team XYZ

activities.subject: Short, high-impact sessions on the <NRP> and the Jewish Experiences in the <LOCATION>
activities.body:
Hi Tisha,​

We’re thrilled to shared that we’re launching two brand new Spotlight sessions aimed at highlighting the experiences, influences, values and rich cultures of the <NRP> and <NRP> communities in the <LOCATION>

Our Spotlights are one-hour, interactive, deep-dive workshops are focused on the experience of being a member of these communities, and contribute to building cultural competence, inclusion skills, and a culture of belonging throughout your organization. 

☪️Spotlight on the Muslim Community (1-hr)
This session explores the complexities of being <NRP> in <LOCATION> and the simultaneously varied and shared experiences and worldviews of <LOCATION>’s <NRP> community. In this session, we unpack the concepts of culture versus religion and discuss current issues and events impacting the <NRP> experience and perspectives. Best practices for allyship and countering bias in the workplace will be shared. Session objectives:
Explore factors that have shaped the lived experiences and cultural values of the <NRP> community, including shared experiences and common influences Recognize the depth and diversity of the <NRP> community in the <LOCATION> Discuss <NRP> sentiment (especially since 9/11) and its impact on the <NRP> community Explore strategies to support and be an ally to your <NRP> colleagues and the community at large 
🔯Spotlight on the Jewish Community (1-hr)
This session introduces participants to key historical and social/cultural events that shape this community, as well as the cultural values and practices that influence the <NRP> experience. The session will also unpack stereotypes, debunk myths, and address antisemitism and its impact in the workplace today. We share best practices for supporting and providing allyship to our colleagues with the community, and how to counter antisemitic bias and microaggressions. Session objectives:
Explore factors that have shaped the lived experiences and cultural values of the <NRP> community, including shared experiences and common influences. Recognize the depth and diversity of the <NRP> community in the <LOCATION> Discuss the current state of Antisemitism and its impact on the <NRP> community. Explore strategies to support and be an ally to your <NRP> colleagues and the community at large. Below are one-pagers for each session, that you may share with your stakeholders. 

Other Spotlights that you may consider for 2024:
Being an Ally for the Asian American Community (May, AAPI Heritage Month) Spotlight on the LGBTQ+ Community (June, LGBTQ+ Pride Month) Spotlight on Persons with Disabilities (July, Disability Pride Month) Spotlight on U.S. Generations (April, August, December, anytime) Spotlight on the <NRP>/Latinx/e Community (September, Hispanic Heritage Month 9/15-10/15) Spotlight on Indigenous People in <LOCATION> (October, Indigenous Peoples’ Day or November, Native American Heritage Month) Spotlight on the U.S. Veterans Community (November, Veterans’ Day) If you have any questions and would like to connect, please let me what days work best and I’ll send over some times.

activities.subject: <PERSON> from XYZ checking in
activities.body:
Hi, <PERSON> -



I hope this email finds you well and enjoying the new year. Wanted to let you know that <PERSON> is leaving XYZ at the end of January and I will be serving as <PERSON> consultant at XYZ going forward. I was already working with you and supporting <PERSON>, so I was happy to hear that your account was 'officially' transitioned to me.



Anyway, there's a lot of discourse about DEI right now and much of it is unhelpful to people charged with solving complex people dynamics in the workplace.



On our end, I'm emphasizing ensuring people understand what we mean by inclusion and equity (countering some of the media narrative re: 'DEI' being about discrimination) and that inclusion means everyone, continuing to find ways to collect useful and compelling data that shows inconsistent experiences within the org (in particular around development/career advancement opportunities, pay, promotion rates, and psychological safety), and designing/embedding inclusive practices into the org's day-to-day operations rather than it being perceived as a separate thing.



This brand new HBR article by <PERSON><<URL>> talks about the current landscape as an opportunity to reimagine or 'reset' DEI. Lily presents the FAIR acronym, which is substantially similar to DEI. However, I want to highlight <PERSON>'s intriguing reframing  of the 'R' which stands for representation. Framing representation as a matter of transparency, trust, and a track record of accountability. Here's an excerpt:

If a product team aims to build products "for all people" but does not consult or include perspectives from a key audience in their design process, that audience lacks representation - even if a member of the product team shares an identity with that audience.... Representation is a matter of trust, not tokenism. While people may be slightly more inclined to trust those who share identities in common with them, trust is more dependent on the behavior and track record of those in power. It's possible for a leadership team made up entirely of women to be non-representative of women if none of the leaders take the effort to understand and advocate for the needs of the women they supposedly represent. On the other hand, it's possible that a product team without direct experience living in rural communities might be very representative of rural communities due to frequent communication, active outreach, and ongoing efforts to understand and advocate for rural communities' needs.



What are <PERSON> inclusion goals for 2025? I'd love to hear about them, including what kind of support you're getting from leadership.



Would you be open to a brief call next week or the next?



Looking forward to reconnecting!

activities.subject: Short, high-impact sessions on the <NRP> and the Jewish Experiences in the <LOCATION>
activities.body:
CAUTION EXTERNAL EMAIL
Hi Justine,​

We’re thrilled to shared that we’re launching two brand new Spotlight sessions aimed at highlighting the experiences, influences, values and rich cultures of the <NRP> and <NRP> communities in the <LOCATION>

Our Spotlights are one-hour, interactive, deep-dive workshops are focused on the experience of being a member of these communities, and contribute to building cultural competence, inclusion skills, and a culture of belonging throughout your organization.

☪️Spotlight on the Muslim Community (1-hr)
This session explores the complexities of being <NRP> in <LOCATION> and the simultaneously varied and shared experiences and worldviews of <LOCATION>’s <NRP> community. In this session, we unpack the concepts of culture versus religion and discuss current issues and events impacting the <NRP> experience and perspectives. Best practices for allyship and countering bias in the workplace will be shared. Session objectives:

  *   Explore factors that have shaped the lived experiences and cultural values of the <NRP> community, including shared experiences and common influences
  *   Recognize the depth and diversity of the <NRP> community in the <LOCATION>
  *   Discuss <NRP> sentiment (especially since 9/11) and its impact on the <NRP> community
  *   Explore strategies to support and be an ally to your <NRP> colleagues and the community at large

🔯Spotlight on the Jewish Community (1-hr)
This session introduces participants to key historical and social/cultural events that shape this community, as well as the cultural values and practices that influence the <NRP> experience. The session will also unpack stereotypes, debunk myths, and address antisemitism and its impact in the workplace today. We share best practices for supporting and providing allyship to our colleagues with the community, and how to counter antisemitic bias and microaggressions. Session objectives:

  *   Explore factors that have shaped the lived experiences and cultural values of the <NRP> community, including shared experiences and common influences.
  *   Recognize the depth and diversity of the <NRP> community in the <LOCATION>
  *   Discuss the current state of Antisemitism and its impact on the <NRP> community.
  *   Explore strategies to support and be an ally to your <NRP> colleagues and the community at large.
Below are one-pagers for each session, that you may share with your stakeholders.

Other Spotlights that you may consider for 2024:

  *   Being an Ally for the Asian American Community (May, AAPI Heritage Month)
  *   Spotlight on the LGBTQ+ Community (June, LGBTQ+ Pride Month)
  *   Spotlight on Persons with Disabilities (July, Disability Pride Month)
  *   Spotlight on U.S. Generations (April, August, December, anytime)
  *   Spotlight on the <NRP>/Latinx/e Community (September, Hispanic Heritage Month 9/15-10/15)
  *   Spotlight on Indigenous People in <LOCATION> (October, Indigenous Peoples’ Day or November, Native American Heritage Month)
  *   Spotlight on the U.S. Veterans Community (November, Veterans’ Day)
If you have any questions and would like to connect, please let me what days work best and I’ll send over some times.

[Image removed by sender.]
[Image removed by sender.]

activities.subject: <PERSON> from XYZ checking in
activities.body:
Hi, <PERSON> -



I hope this email finds you well and enjoying the new year. Wanted to let you know that <PERSON> is leaving XYZ at the end of January and I will be serving as <PERSON> consultant at XYZ going forward. I was already working with you and supporting <PERSON>, so I was happy to hear that your account was ‘officially’ transitioned to me.



Anyway, there’s a lot of discourse about DEI right now and much of it is unhelpful to people charged with solving complex people dynamics in the workplace.



On our end, I’m emphasizing ensuring people understand what we mean by inclusion and equity (countering some of the media narrative re: ‘DEI’ being about discrimination) and that inclusion means everyone, continuing to find ways to collect useful and compelling data that shows inconsistent experiences within the org (in particular around development/career advancement opportunities, pay, promotion rates, and psychological safety), and designing/embedding inclusive practices into the org’s day-to-day operations rather than it being perceived as a separate thing.



This brand new HBR article by <PERSON><<URL>> talks about the current landscape as an opportunity to reimagine or ‘reset’ DEI. Lily presents the FAIR acronym, which is substantially similar to DEI. However, I want to highlight <PERSON>’s intriguing reframing  of the ‘R’ which stands for representation. Framing representation as a matter of transparency, trust, and a track record of accountability. Here’s an excerpt:

If a product team aims to build products “for all people” but does not consult or include perspectives from a key audience in their design process, that audience lacks representation — even if a member of the product team shares an identity with that audience…. Representation is a matter of trust, not tokenism. While people may be slightly more inclined to trust those who share identities in common with them, trust is more dependent on the behavior and track record of those in power. It’s possible for a leadership team made up entirely of women to be non-representative of women if none of the leaders take the effort to understand and advocate for the needs of the women they supposedly represent. On the other hand, it’s possible that a product team without direct experience living in rural communities might be very representative of rural communities due to frequent communication, active outreach, and ongoing efforts to understand and advocate for rural communities’ needs.



What are <PERSON> inclusion goals for 2025? I’d love to hear about them, including what kind of support you’re getting from leadership.



Would you be open to a brief call next week or the next?



Looking forward to reconnecting!

activities.subject: Exclusive Invitation to Participate in XYZ's climate Interview
activities.body:
Dear Justine,​

Over the past 24 years of working with organizations like yours, we have learned the impact internal and external climates have on our clients doing the work to support inclusion within their organizations. These past few years have truly been filled with change, directional shifts, and future uncertainty. We understand the importance of being a true partner and are excited to announce our exclusive initiative to support our stakeholders by conducting a comprehensive climate interview and survey. The goal of the survey will be to assess how the mindsets and systems within organizations have influenced organizational climate over the past few years and impacted inclusive workplaces. The information we collect from the interview and survey will be treated with utmost confidentiality and the key takeaways will be shared with all selected participants. Based on the key takeaways, we will be sharing relevant resources, developing new content, providing action steps, and offering opportunities to learn and collaborate with peers. 

Please select the time that works best for a 30-minute interview: <URL>

Thank you for considering this opportunity. We look forward to your participation and serving as a continued resource to you and your organization.

activities.note_body: 3/20/24 CALL REPORTClient part: <PERSON>, Sr. Mgr of DEI (since Dec 2022)XYZ part: <PERSON>, <PERSON>-call <PERSON> (requests from emails, other knowledge)Thompson Hine LLP is a business law firm with approximately 400 lawyers in eight offices – 4 of them located in <LOCATION> (ATL, CHI, CIN, CLE, <LOCATION>, <LOCATION>, <LOCATION>, <LOCATION>). The firm was founded in 1911 and has a broad range of specialties, including real estate, corporate securities, banking, labor, environmental, bankruptcy, estate planning, litigation, and employee <URL>ompson Hine DEI Commitments and GoalsSent them XYZ inclusive leadership competencies in Feb 2023.3/15/24 Email from <PERSON> to <PERSON>: “We have the greenlight to move forward with working with an outside consultant for our DEI Report. Can we connect to discuss and get an updated proposal?“The proposal <PERSON> is referring to is probably this <URL>LL NOTES:·         Budget was finally approved – it took three months to approve this year’s budget!·         Annual DEI Report has historically been done in-house, their marketing dept. It took a lot of resources.·         <PERSON> (their C Talent Officer) suggested contacting us to see how we can help. They put $ in the budget to improve our DEI Report and outsource it.·         Looking at expanding it from annual. We’re really doing it every 18 mos but focus on the prior year. For example the one that’s up there now says 2023 but it’s actually from our 2022 activity.·         We need DEI lens to help us bring forth the stories and info that should be in a DEI report. The marketing dept has been doing the same thing every year, but want to take another look.·         We want to ensure we’re highlighting some of our people, you would help us interview specific folks to get their quotes in the report. We also want to highlight people - their connection to our firm and how they fit into the bigger picture of DEI in the org.·         New report should be more engaging, interactive, graphics, maybe more white space, less text.·         We’d want you to create the whole thing, lay it out, and graphic design it.·         We want to highlight outcomes, outside of representation (already had a bad experience with this in the past). We want to highlight our internal processes.·         My role has had a lot of turnover – a lot of what was done in the past was in response to what happened in 2020. Trying to ‘fix’ the disparity (in representation) instead of focusing on inclusion and equity (which then in turn will naturally increase diversity). We need to focus on how we’re keeping people at TH – focus on retaining the people who are already here. Doesn’t mean that we can’t make our recruiting process more inclusive, for example. We’ve done great around diverse slates – Mansfield Rule certified.·         Women and POC still have a higher attrition rate.·         Now <PERSON> has a better handle on TH data, more organized. Not sure we want not do full page interviews anymore. Make it more interactive, pull quotes and graphics.·         Want to talk more about what we’re actually doing.·         What are the ways we’re doing to be inclusive – DEI Summit, other programs, initiatives, and what the outcomes are starting to look like.·         Highlight excellence at Thompson Hine of POC, women, PwD, LGBTQ+, etc.  ·         This is confidential info so don’t share, but as of May 1st we’ll have a new Managing Partner, <PERSON>, who is Black. He’s been in exec committee and has had many leadership positions at TH. The outgoing Managing Partner is <PERSON>. In our current DEI Report we have an interview between <PERSON> and <PERSON> – it would be great to have a similar interview in the new DEI report, but  between <PERSON> and <PERSON> – <PERSON> interviewing <PERSON> for example.  ·         This will be a client facing document, up on our web site. What do our clients want to see? And also employee and potential employee facing.  ·         To price and provide turnaround time, we need to know the scope of content.·         $35-$40k budget.·         <PERSON> will provide us with data, interviewees (our guidance re: what kinds of people to interview), <PERSON> and <PERSON> will facilitate connections within TH.  ·         2024 Diversity Summit – August 1-2, would love to get it done by then - but would be completely okay if we delivered after that.====================================================Post-call debrief with <PERSON>, <PERSON>, <PERSON>:We could go high and then we hire 1 or 2 people to help us do it. <PERSON>’s List playbook, Quad playbooks.Potential SMEs:·         <PERSON>·         <PERSON>·         <PERSON>·         <PERSON>·         Ex-Aon person, <PERSON> (<PERSON> knows her)Next steps:·         Get back to TH with a proposal by next week.

activities.subject: Short, high-impact sessions on the <NRP> and the Jewish Experiences in the <LOCATION>
activities.body:
CAUTION EXTERNAL EMAIL
Hi Justine,​

We’re thrilled to shared that we’re launching two brand new Spotlight sessions aimed at highlighting the experiences, influences, values and rich cultures of the <NRP> and <NRP> communities in the <LOCATION>

Our Spotlights are one-hour, interactive, deep-dive workshops are focused on the experience of being a member of these communities, and contribute to building cultural competence, inclusion skills, and a culture of belonging throughout your organization.

☪️Spotlight on the Muslim Community (1-hr)
This session explores the complexities of being <NRP> in <LOCATION> and the simultaneously varied and shared experiences and worldviews of <LOCATION>’s <NRP> community. In this session, we unpack the concepts of culture versus religion and discuss current issues and events impacting the <NRP> experience and perspectives. Best practices for allyship and countering bias in the workplace will be shared. Session objectives:

  *   Explore factors that have shaped the lived experiences and cultural values of the <NRP> community, including shared experiences and common influences
  *   Recognize the depth and diversity of the <NRP> community in the <LOCATION>
  *   Discuss <NRP> sentiment (especially since 9/11) and its impact on the <NRP> community
  *   Explore strategies to support and be an ally to your <NRP> colleagues and the community at large

🔯Spotlight on the Jewish Community (1-hr)
This session introduces participants to key historical and social/cultural events that shape this community, as well as the cultural values and practices that influence the <NRP> experience. The session will also unpack stereotypes, debunk myths, and address antisemitism and its impact in the workplace today. We share best practices for supporting and providing allyship to our colleagues with the community, and how to counter antisemitic bias and microaggressions. Session objectives:

  *   Explore factors that have shaped the lived experiences and cultural values of the <NRP> community, including shared experiences and common influences.
  *   Recognize the depth and diversity of the <NRP> community in the <LOCATION>
  *   Discuss the current state of Antisemitism and its impact on the <NRP> community.
  *   Explore strategies to support and be an ally to your <NRP> colleagues and the community at large.
Below are one-pagers for each session, that you may share with your stakeholders.

Other Spotlights that you may consider for 2024:

  *   Being an Ally for the Asian American Community (May, AAPI Heritage Month)
  *   Spotlight on the LGBTQ+ Community (June, LGBTQ+ Pride Month)
  *   Spotlight on Persons with Disabilities (July, Disability Pride Month)
  *   Spotlight on U.S. Generations (April, August, December, anytime)
  *   Spotlight on the <NRP>/Latinx/e Community (September, Hispanic Heritage Month 9/15-10/15)
  *   Spotlight on Indigenous People in <LOCATION> (October, Indigenous Peoples’ Day or November, Native American Heritage Month)
  *   Spotlight on the U.S. Veterans Community (November, Veterans’ Day)
If you have any questions and would like to connect, please let me what days work best and I’ll send over some times.

[Image removed by sender.]
[Image removed by sender.]

activities.subject: RE: Essential Guide to Dialogues about <LOCATION>-Palestine
activities.body: Thanks <PERSON>.

activities.subject: Essential Guide to Dialogues about <LOCATION>-Palestine
activities.body:
CAUTION EXTERNAL EMAIL
Hi Justine,​

We know that world events impact us in many ways, and that we don’t stop being who we are when we to go to work. With the ongoing <LOCATION>-Palestine conflict, we thought it would be helpful to provide you with a structure and process for having this type of dialogue. We wanted to send you this Essential Guide to Dialogues about <LOCATION>-Palestine<<URL>>, put out by the organization Essential Partners<<URL>>. It’s excellent.

The bulk of this guide/resource is about how to set up such a dialogue – including:

  *   The difference between dialogue and debate
  *   The importance of communication agreements (some really good ones included – please see bottom of p. 6/top of p. 7)
  *   Logistics (how, where, what)
  *   Structures for reflection, speaking & listening (the Go-Round; the Intentional Pause; Reflect, Write, Respond)
  *   Preparing for the dialogue as a facilitator (lots of support provided!)
  *   Participant intervention tips (in-depth and valuable)
  *   A sample agenda
  *   Dialogue prompts (they offer a few sets of prompts, depending on what your audience and context is – please see the one on p. 20 which is designed for the purpose of ‘better understanding different perspectives’:
This dialogue guide is a great complement to our two brand new workshops: Spotlight on the Muslim Community in the <LOCATION> and Spotlight on the Jewish Community in the <LOCATION> - one-hour interactive, deep-dive workshops are focused on the experience of being a member of these communities, and aim at highlighting their experiences, influences, values and rich cultures.

☪️Spotlight on the Muslim Community (1-hr): Explores the complexities of being <NRP> in <LOCATION> and the simultaneously varied and shared experiences and worldviews of <LOCATION>’s <NRP> community. In this session, we unpack the concepts of culture versus religion and discuss current issues and events impacting the <NRP> experience and perspectives. Best practices for allyship and countering bias in the workplace will be shared.

🔯Spotlight on the Jewish Community (1-hr): Introduces participants to key historical and social/cultural events that shape this community, as well as the cultural values and practices that influence the <NRP> experience. The session will also unpack stereotypes, debunk myths, and address antisemitism and its impact in the workplace today. We share best practices for supporting and providing allyship to our colleagues with the community, and how to counter antisemitic bias and microaggressions.

If you’re interested in talking further about scheduling these vital learning opportunities, please reply to this email and we can set up a meeting.

activities.subject: <PERSON> from XYZ checking in
activities.body:
Hi, <PERSON> -



I hope this email finds you well and enjoying the new year. Wanted to let you know that <PERSON> is leaving XYZ at the end of January and I will be serving as <PERSON> consultant at XYZ going forward. I was already working with you and supporting <PERSON>, so I was happy to hear that your account was ‘officially’ transitioned to me.



Anyway, there’s a lot of discourse about DEI right now and much of it is unhelpful to people charged with solving complex people dynamics in the workplace.



On our end, I’m emphasizing ensuring people understand what we mean by inclusion and equity (countering some of the media narrative re: ‘DEI’ being about discrimination) and that inclusion means everyone, continuing to find ways to collect useful and compelling data that shows inconsistent experiences within the org (in particular around development/career advancement opportunities, pay, promotion rates, and psychological safety), and designing/embedding inclusive practices into the org’s day-to-day operations rather than it being perceived as a separate thing.



This brand new HBR article by <PERSON><<URL>> talks about the current landscape as an opportunity to reimagine or ‘reset’ DEI. Lily presents the FAIR acronym, which is substantially similar to DEI. However, I want to highlight <PERSON>’s intriguing reframing  of the ‘R’ which stands for representation. Framing representation as a matter of transparency, trust, and a track record of accountability. Here’s an excerpt:

If a product team aims to build products “for all people” but does not consult or include perspectives from a key audience in their design process, that audience lacks representation — even if a member of the product team shares an identity with that audience…. Representation is a matter of trust, not tokenism. While people may be slightly more inclined to trust those who share identities in common with them, trust is more dependent on the behavior and track record of those in power. It’s possible for a leadership team made up entirely of women to be non-representative of women if none of the leaders take the effort to understand and advocate for the needs of the women they supposedly represent. On the other hand, it’s possible that a product team without direct experience living in rural communities might be very representative of rural communities due to frequent communication, active outreach, and ongoing efforts to understand and advocate for rural communities’ needs.



What are <PERSON> inclusion goals for 2025? I’d love to hear about them, including what kind of support you’re getting from leadership.



Would you be open to a brief call next week or the next?



Looking forward to reconnecting!

activities.subject: RE: REGISTER FOR FREE PREVIEW: Spotlights on the <NRP> & Jewish Communities in the <LOCATION>
activities.body:
Hi <PERSON>,

Hope all is well! Just wanted to bring this back up for your review. Have a wonderful day!

activities.subject: REGISTER FOR FREE PREVIEW: Spotlights on the <NRP> & Jewish Communities in the <LOCATION>
activities.body:
Hi Justine,​

As part of our ongoing commitment to fostering cultural understanding and promoting inclusion, we’re excited to announce an upcoming no-cost session previewing our two new programs: " Spotlight on the Jewish Community in the <LOCATION>" and " Spotlight on the Muslim Community in the <LOCATION>." The preview will take place on May 29th, 2024 from 2-3pm ET / 1-2pm CT.

These two additions to our Spotlights library were carefully designed and vetted by interculturalists and culture-expert members of the <NRP> and <NRP> community. Facilitated by two cross-cultural expert facilitators (one a member of the community and one ally), the Spotlights provide participants with valuable insights into the histories, values, experiences, and influences that shape each of these distinct cultures, and deliver an insightful and nuanced understanding of the <NRP> and <NRP> experiences in <LOCATION> - dispelling misconceptions and fostering empathy. These sessions do not explain or resolve current geopolitical events, do not advocate particular points of view or debate history, and like all of our Spotlights, aim to build cultural competence and understanding.

The Spotlights helps participants:

  *   Explore factors that have shaped the lived experiences and cultural values of the community in the <LOCATION>, including shared experiences and common influences.
  *   Recognize the depth and diversity of the community in the <LOCATION>
  *   Discuss historical and contemporary prejudice against the community.
  *   Explore strategies to support and be an ally to your colleagues and the community at large.
In our preview we’ll demonstrate sample content from both Spotlights, show you the agenda for each, and answer your questions.

REGISTER FOR THE SPOTLIGHTS PREVIEW:
Wednesday, May 29th, 2024 from 2-3pm ET / 1-2pm CT Register Here<<URL>>

We believe that these Spotlights can be valuable tools which, in conjunction with other elements of your DEI infrastructure, work towards de-polarization and enhancing participants’ ability to engage meaningfully with individuals from these backgrounds.

We're looking forward to seeing you there!

activities.subject: REGISTER FOR FREE PREVIEW: Spotlights on the <NRP> & Jewish Communities in the <LOCATION>
activities.body:
Hi Justine,​

As part of our ongoing commitment to fostering cultural understanding and promoting inclusion, we’re excited to announce an upcoming no-cost session previewing our two new programs: "Spotlight on the Jewish Community in the <LOCATION>" and "Spotlight on the Muslim Community in the <LOCATION>." The preview will take place on May 29th, 2024 from 2-3pm ET / 1-2pm CT. 

These two additions to our Spotlights library were carefully designed and vetted by interculturalists and culture-expert members of the <NRP> and <NRP> community. Facilitated by two cross-cultural expert facilitators (one a member of the community and one ally), the Spotlights provide participants with valuable insights into the histories, values, experiences, and influences that shape each of these distinct cultures, and deliver an insightful and nuanced understanding of the <NRP> and <NRP> experiences in <LOCATION> - dispelling misconceptions and fostering empathy. These sessions do not explain or resolve current geopolitical events, do not advocate particular points of view or debate history, and like all of our Spotlights, aim to build cultural competence and understanding. 

The Spotlights helps participants: 
Explore factors that have shaped the lived experiences and cultural values of the community in the <LOCATION>, including shared experiences and common influences. Recognize the depth and diversity of the community in the <LOCATION> Discuss historical and contemporary prejudice against the community. Explore strategies to support and be an ally to your colleagues and the community at large. In our preview we’ll demonstrate sample content from both Spotlights, show you the agenda for each, and answer your questions. 

REGISTER FOR THE SPOTLIGHTS PREVIEW:
Wednesday, May 29th, 2024 from 2-3pm ET / 1-2pm CT Register Here: <URL> 

We believe that these Spotlights can be valuable tools which, in conjunction with other elements of your DEI infrastructure, work towards de-polarization and enhancing participants’ ability to engage meaningfully with individuals from these backgrounds. 

We're looking forward to seeing you there!

activities.subject: Essential Guide to Dialogues about <LOCATION>-Palestine
activities.body:
Hi Justine,​

We know that world events impact us in many ways, and that we don’t stop being who we are when we to go to work. With the ongoing <LOCATION>-Palestine conflict, we thought it would be helpful to provide you with a structure and process for having this type of dialogue. We wanted to send you this Essential Guide to Dialogues about <LOCATION>-Palestine: wanted%20to%20send%20you%20a%20quick%20note%20to%20let%20you%20know%20that%20we%20know%20that%20many%20workplaces%20have%20been%20talking%20about%20and%20affected%20by%20the%20Israel-Palestine%20conflict.%20We%20also%20know%20that%20world%20events%20impact%20us%20in%20many%20ways,%20and%20that%20we%20don’t%20stop%20being%20who%20we%20are%20when%20we%20to%20go%20to%20work.%20In%20case%20you%20or%20any%20of%20your%20colleagues%20is%20interested%20in%20a%20structure%20and%20process%20for%20having%20this%20dialogue,%20I%20attach%20the%20recently%20published%20Essential%20Guide%20to%20Dialogues%20about%20Israel-Palestine,%20put%20out%20by%20the%20organization%20Essential%20Partners.%20%20It’s%20excellent.%20%20The%20bulk%20of%20this%20guide/resource%20is%20about%20how%20to%20set%20up%20such%20a%20dialogue%20–%20including:, put out by the organization Essential Partners: <URL> It’s excellent. 

The bulk of this guide/resource is about how to set up such a dialogue – including:
The difference between dialogue and debate The importance of communication agreements (some really good ones included – please see bottom of p. 6/top of p. 7) Logistics (how, where, what) Structures for reflection, speaking & listening (the Go-Round; the Intentional Pause; Reflect, Write, Respond) Preparing for the dialogue as a facilitator (lots of support provided!) Participant intervention tips (in-depth and valuable) A sample agenda Dialogue prompts (they offer a few sets of prompts, depending on what your audience and context is – please see the one on p. 20 which is designed for the purpose of ‘better understanding different perspectives’: This dialogue guide is a great complement to our two brand new workshops: Spotlight on the Muslim Community in the <LOCATION> and Spotlight on the Jewish Community in the <LOCATION> - one-hour interactive, deep-dive workshops are focused on the experience of being a member of these communities, and aim at highlighting their experiences, influences, values and rich cultures. 

☪️Spotlight on the Muslim Community (1-hr): Explores the complexities of being <NRP> in <LOCATION> and the simultaneously varied and shared experiences and worldviews of <LOCATION>’s <NRP> community. In this session, we unpack the concepts of culture versus religion and discuss current issues and events impacting the <NRP> experience and perspectives. Best practices for allyship and countering bias in the workplace will be shared. 

🔯Spotlight on the Jewish Community (1-hr): Introduces participants to key historical and social/cultural events that shape this community, as well as the cultural values and practices that influence the <NRP> experience. The session will also unpack stereotypes, debunk myths, and address antisemitism and its impact in the workplace today. We share best practices for supporting and providing allyship to our colleagues with the community, and how to counter antisemitic bias and microaggressions. 

If you’re interested in talking further about scheduling these vital learning opportunities, please reply to this email and we can set up a meeting.

activities.subject: <PERSON> from XYZ checking in
activities.body:
Hi, <PERSON> -



I hope this email finds you well and enjoying the new year. Wanted to let you know that <PERSON> is leaving XYZ at the end of January and I will be serving as <PERSON> consultant at XYZ going forward. I was already working with you and supporting <PERSON>, so I was happy to hear that your account was ‘officially’ transitioned to me.



Anyway, there’s a lot of discourse about DEI right now and much of it is unhelpful to people charged with solving complex people dynamics in the workplace.



On our end, I’m emphasizing ensuring people understand what we mean by inclusion and equity (countering some of the media narrative re: ‘DEI’ being about discrimination) and that inclusion means everyone, continuing to find ways to collect useful and compelling data that shows inconsistent experiences within the org (in particular around development/career advancement opportunities, pay, promotion rates, and psychological safety), and designing/embedding inclusive practices into the org’s day-to-day operations rather than it being perceived as a separate thing.



This brand new HBR article by <PERSON><<URL>> talks about the current landscape as an opportunity to reimagine or ‘reset’ DEI. Lily presents the FAIR acronym, which is substantially similar to DEI. However, I want to highlight <PERSON>’s intriguing reframing  of the ‘R’ which stands for representation. Framing representation as a matter of transparency, trust, and a track record of accountability. Here’s an excerpt:

If a product team aims to build products “for all people” but does not consult or include perspectives from a key audience in their design process, that audience lacks representation — even if a member of the product team shares an identity with that audience…. Representation is a matter of trust, not tokenism. While people may be slightly more inclined to trust those who share identities in common with them, trust is more dependent on the behavior and track record of those in power. It’s possible for a leadership team made up entirely of women to be non-representative of women if none of the leaders take the effort to understand and advocate for the needs of the women they supposedly represent. On the other hand, it’s possible that a product team without direct experience living in rural communities might be very representative of rural communities due to frequent communication, active outreach, and ongoing efforts to understand and advocate for rural communities’ needs.



What are <PERSON> inclusion goals for 2025? I’d love to hear about them, including what kind of support you’re getting from leadership.



Would you be open to a brief call next week or the next?



Looking forward to reconnecting!

<PERSON><

activities.subject: Commemorating Juneteenth & Its Legacy
activities.body:
Dear Justine,​

Many employers are planning to recognize <LOCATION> this year to celebrate this significant date in <NRP> history. 

<LOCATION>, a federal holiday celebrated annually on June 19th, marks the completion of emancipation of enslaved <NRP> in <LOCATION>, and symbolizes freedom, resilience, and the ongoing struggle for equality.

We believe that it's crucial to take the opportunity to reflect, learn, and engage in meaningful conversations about <LOCATION> and its importance to our employees and clients. To help you facilitate this dialogue, we have developed a one-hour session on this topic.

Our virtual workshop, Understanding <LOCATION> and Its Legacy, has the following objectives:
Explore <LOCATION>’s historical context, its significance in <NRP> history, and how it has evolved over time. Understand how many organizations have historically exploited the holiday. Explore ways in which individuals and organizations can commit to supporting and advocating for <NRP> communities beyond designated months or holidays. We also invite you to sample our “Commemorating Juneteenth” microlearning via this link: <URL> It will remain open and available for you until May 31st. Just enter your email address and name, and you’ll get access.

Understanding the roots of this holiday and its lasting impact is an important element for fostering empathy, awareness, and inclusion. Bringing colleagues together to engage in this opportunity to learn about history and progress has a positive impact in the workplace.

If you’re interested or have any questions, please reply to this email and we can set up a meeting.
