activities.subject: Do you know of a team struggling with alignment or interpersonal issues?
activities.body:
Dear Justine,​

Hope you’re having a productive <US_DRIVER_LICENSE> – I can’t believe it’s almost over already!

Reaching out to see if we could help you solve a problem you or others in your org may be having. 
Is your or another team you know of, struggling with alignment, communication, interpersonal dynamics, trust, or collaboration? Are cultural issues holding this team back? <PERSON> said that “culture eats strategy for breakfast” – and we continue to see examples that prove him right. 

We’ve developed an intensive program where we help team members create the team culture they need and crave to succeed. 

This workshop is for intact teams who are struggling with issues that are interfering with their performance due to ineffective communication and/or working relationships, for example:
- Interpersonal issues
- Issues with the leader/manager 
- Poor group dynamics
- Harmful microbehaviors
The workshop content has its strong foundation, but we tailor it based on interviews, focus groups, or surveys of all team members. This is key. During the program itself, facilitators and your stakeholder together, create a “brave” space for all participants to feel heard and be engaged During the program, participants co-create a Team Charter: five to seven concrete behaviors that all team members will commit to going forward The workshop is facilitated by 2 highly skilled professionals who coach participants to arrive at solutions The workshop is designed for intact teams of up to 20 participants, conducive to deep attention to key issues that are getting in their way If this intervention sounds like something that would help remove an obstacle for your team (or another team in your org), we’d love to hear more and see if/how we could help. 

Simply reply to this email and we can send a few available timeslots for you to choose from, or you could send us your availability if you prefer.

activities.subject: Exclusive Invitation to Participate in XYZ's climate Interview
activities.body:
Dear Justine,​

Over the past 24 years of working with organizations like yours, we have learned the impact internal and external climates have on our clients doing the work to support inclusion within their organizations. These past few years have truly been filled with change, directional shifts, and future uncertainty. We understand the importance of being a true partner and are excited to announce our exclusive initiative to support our stakeholders by conducting a comprehensive climate interview and survey. The goal of the survey will be to assess how the mindsets and systems within organizations have influenced organizational climate over the past few years and impacted inclusive workplaces. The information we collect from the interview and survey will be treated with utmost confidentiality and the key takeaways will be shared with all selected participants. Based on the key takeaways, we will be sharing relevant resources, developing new content, providing action steps, and offering opportunities to learn and collaborate with peers. 

Please select the time that works best for a 30-minute interview: <URL>

Thank you for considering this opportunity. We look forward to your participation and serving as a continued resource to you and your organization.

activities.meeting_title: Thompson Hine & XYZ: <NRP> Spotlight Touch Base

activities.note_body: 3/20/24 CALL REPORTClient part: <PERSON>, Sr. Mgr of DEI (since Dec 2022)XYZ part: <PERSON>, <PERSON>-call <PERSON> (requests from emails, other knowledge)Thompson Hine LLP is a business law firm with approximately 400 lawyers in eight offices – 4 of them located in <LOCATION> (ATL, CHI, CIN, CLE, <LOCATION>, <LOCATION>, <LOCATION>, <LOCATION>). The firm was founded in 1911 and has a broad range of specialties, including real estate, corporate securities, banking, labor, environmental, bankruptcy, estate planning, litigation, and employee <URL>ompson Hine DEI Commitments and GoalsSent them XYZ inclusive leadership competencies in Feb 2023.3/15/24 Email from <PERSON> to <PERSON>: “We have the greenlight to move forward with working with an outside consultant for our DEI Report. Can we connect to discuss and get an updated proposal?“The proposal <PERSON> is referring to is probably this <URL>LL NOTES:·         Budget was finally approved – it took three months to approve this year’s budget!·         Annual DEI Report has historically been done in-house, their marketing dept. It took a lot of resources.·         <PERSON> (their C Talent Officer) suggested contacting us to see how we can help. They put $ in the budget to improve our DEI Report and outsource it.·         Looking at expanding it from annual. We’re really doing it every 18 mos but focus on the prior year. For example the one that’s up there now says 2023 but it’s actually from our 2022 activity.·         We need DEI lens to help us bring forth the stories and info that should be in a DEI report. The marketing dept has been doing the same thing every year, but want to take another look.·         We want to ensure we’re highlighting some of our people, you would help us interview specific folks to get their quotes in the report. We also want to highlight people - their connection to our firm and how they fit into the bigger picture of DEI in the org.·         New report should be more engaging, interactive, graphics, maybe more white space, less text.·         We’d want you to create the whole thing, lay it out, and graphic design it.·         We want to highlight outcomes, outside of representation (already had a bad experience with this in the past). We want to highlight our internal processes.·         My role has had a lot of turnover – a lot of what was done in the past was in response to what happened in 2020. Trying to ‘fix’ the disparity (in representation) instead of focusing on inclusion and equity (which then in turn will naturally increase diversity). We need to focus on how we’re keeping people at TH – focus on retaining the people who are already here. Doesn’t mean that we can’t make our recruiting process more inclusive, for example. We’ve done great around diverse slates – Mansfield Rule certified.·         Women and POC still have a higher attrition rate.·         Now <PERSON> has a better handle on TH data, more organized. Not sure we want not do full page interviews anymore. Make it more interactive, pull quotes and graphics.·         Want to talk more about what we’re actually doing.·         What are the ways we’re doing to be inclusive – DEI Summit, other programs, initiatives, and what the outcomes are starting to look like.·         Highlight excellence at Thompson Hine of POC, women, PwD, LGBTQ+, etc.  ·         This is confidential info so don’t share, but as of May 1st we’ll have a new Managing Partner, <PERSON>, who is Black. He’s been in exec committee and has had many leadership positions at TH. The outgoing Managing Partner is <PERSON>. In our current DEI Report we have an interview between <PERSON> and <PERSON> – it would be great to have a similar interview in the new DEI report, but  between <PERSON> and <PERSON> – <PERSON> interviewing <PERSON> for example.  ·         This will be a client facing document, up on our web site. What do our clients want to see? And also employee and potential employee facing.  ·         To price and provide turnaround time, we need to know the scope of content.·         $35-$40k budget.·         <PERSON> will provide us with data, interviewees (our guidance re: what kinds of people to interview), <PERSON> and <PERSON> will facilitate connections within TH.  ·         2024 Diversity Summit – August 1-2, would love to get it done by then - but would be completely okay if we delivered after that.====================================================Post-call debrief with <PERSON>, <PERSON>, <PERSON>:We could go high and then we hire 1 or 2 people to help us do it. <PERSON>’s List playbook, Quad playbooks.Potential SMEs:·         <PERSON>·         <PERSON>·         <PERSON>·         <PERSON>·         Ex-Aon person, <PERSON> (<PERSON> knows her)Next steps:·         Get back to TH with a proposal by next week.

Hi Lissa,​

We’re thrilled to shared that we’re launching two brand new Spotlight sessions aimed at highlighting the experiences, influences, values and rich cultures of the <NRP> and <NRP> communities in the <LOCATION>

Our Spotlights are one-hour, interactive, deep-dive workshops are focused on the experience of being a member of these communities, and contribute to building cultural competence, inclusion skills, and a culture of belonging throughout your organization. 

☪️Spotlight on the Muslim Community (1-hr)
This session explores the complexities of being <NRP> in <LOCATION> and the simultaneously varied and shared experiences and worldviews of <LOCATION>’s <NRP> community. In this session, we unpack the concepts of culture versus religion and discuss current issues and events impacting the <NRP> experience and perspectives. Best practices for allyship and countering bias in the workplace will be shared. Session objectives:
Explore factors that have shaped the lived experiences and cultural values of the <NRP> community, including shared experiences and common influences Recognize the depth and diversity of the <NRP> community in the <LOCATION> Discuss <NRP> sentiment (especially since 9/11) and its impact on the <NRP> community Explore strategies to support and be an ally to your <NRP> colleagues and the community at large 
🔯Spotlight on the Jewish Community (1-hr)
This session introduces participants to key historical and social/cultural events that shape this community, as well as the cultural values and practices that influence the <NRP> experience. The session will also unpack stereotypes, debunk myths, and address antisemitism and its impact in the workplace today. We share best practices for supporting and providing allyship to our colleagues with the community, and how to counter antisemitic bias and microaggressions. Session objectives:
Explore factors that have shaped the lived experiences and cultural values of the <NRP> community, including shared experiences and common influences. Recognize the depth and diversity of the <NRP> community in the <LOCATION> Discuss the current state of Antisemitism and its impact on the <NRP> community. Explore strategies to support and be an ally to your <NRP> colleagues and the community at large. Below are one-pagers for each session, that you may share with your stakeholders. 

Other Spotlights that you may consider for 2024:
Being an Ally for the Asian American Community (May, AAPI Heritage Month) Spotlight on the LGBTQ+ Community (June, LGBTQ+ Pride Month) Spotlight on Persons with Disabilities (July, Disability Pride Month) Spotlight on U.S. Generations (April, August, December, anytime) Spotlight on the <NRP>/Latinx/e Community (September, Hispanic Heritage Month 9/15-10/15) Spotlight on Indigenous People in <LOCATION> (October, Indigenous Peoples’ Day or November, Native American Heritage Month) Spotlight on the U.S. Veterans Community (November, Veterans’ Day) If you have any questions and would like to connect, please let me what days work best and I’ll send over some times.

activities.subject: RE: Following up: Update on RFP submission for BCG X Delivery
activities.body:
Thank you very much, <PERSON>. We can definitely appreciate that it takes time to aggregate feedback, thank you.

Your note below is especially disappointing to hear because:

  *   I can't find anywhere in the RFP document or in <PERSON>'s email where we were asked to provide detail around trainers and facilitators (name, qualifications, experience, etc.)  Had that been asked of us, we of course would have provided it with the RFP response.
  *   Workshop participant capacity of 50 was a suggestion, and absolutely flexible. Many organizations prefer workshops with even larger groups to save costs, but of course we often facilitate (and recommend) smaller group sizes to maximize learning. 50 is an average group size based on our experience with our clients, but it's always a tradeoff (cost and group size), since the smaller the groups the more numerous the workshops. This is a question that we always leave up to the client.
  *   We have a long history of working closely with BCG's various business units and know you well.
  *   We would have very much welcomed a conversation about costs, to have an opportunity to more closely match the other vendors and also to clarify your questions.

We'd welcome any additional info you can provide, including how off our pricing was as compared to the others.

Thanks again for your collaboration in responding to our request!

Hello, <PERSON> and team.

This is obviously very disappointing, but we understand how these things go.

It would be extremely helpful for us as an organization to understand specifically why we weren't chosen, why the other vendor was chosen, and also who is the vendor you chose (if you don't mind).  We put significant time into crafting the proposal, and are very interested in understanding where our proposal fell short, as compared to the other vendor. Is it possible to have a quick 15  min call about this? Or, email is fine too if that's easier for you.  Getting your feedback is extremely important to us as we continue our journey, as it would help us to understand the areas where we can improve.

activities.subject: RE: Looking for learning solutions for DE&I Training Program - BCG X Delivery
activities.body:
Hi <PERSON>,

The RFP we shared can be treated as a baseline for your solution framework and there is definitely room to wiggle in terms of duration and content. We highly rely on your expertise to gauge and create bespoke training plan for us. Given you have prior experience working with BCG, we would like to believe that you have a fair idea of the TG and what would work best for them. So, we sort of depend on you telling us the way forward. The 2 topics shall remain our focus area and you can play around the content beneath these -

  1.  Inclusive Leadership and creating inclusive teams (for senior cohort)
  2.  Building sensitivity & inclusive communications (for junior cohort)

Please see my responses in line below.

<EMAIL_ADDRESS><mailto:<EMAIL_ADDRESS>>
Hello again, <PERSON> and <PERSON>.

We have some initial questions about the RFP if you don't mind:



  *   Confirming that we'll be designing three workshops - one for approx. 450 analysts, one for approx. 100 managers and senior managers, and one for approx. 40 Director and above - It could be 2 groups or 3 groups depending on the content/material. What is your opinion on this? Should we club manager and director cohorts, is there a possibility to deliver a training that would make sense covering both cohorts together and justify it or should we cater to them separately? Please suggest


  *   Could you please say more about the max 12-16 hours of training? Does that refer to the total time for all sessions for all constituencies? (i.e., all trainings for everyone should be completed within 12-16 hours total time of duration?) Or does it refer to 12-16 hours of training for each of the three constituencies? - Highlighted. These 12-16 hours should majorly comprise of live sessions, training, workshop, immersive learning etc and not self-paced learning. If you offer self-paced modules as well as part of your solution, that could be over and above of this duration but should not go beyond 4-5 hours. That means 12-16 hours of interactive sessions + 4-5 hours of self-learning. This is little flexible and open for discussion if needed


  *   We tend to recommend online class sizes to be between 30-40 people. Would this work for you? Or were you looking for larger groups? - We don't really mind having big or small groups as long they are interactive and engaging for everyone. It totally depends on the solution you offer. What is the right number for a group size according to you in such trainings?


  *   Will all the workshops be delivered in English? - Yes


  *   Were you envisioning creating adapted/different versions of the training for different world regions (NAMR, EMEA, <LOCATION>, APAC)? Or were you thinking of one 'global' version of each training? - Yes, we want to proceed with an idea of capturing the regional essence in the training making it more relatable for the TG. Please be mindful of the cultural differences/ biases while curating the training material


  *   Do you have information on the diversity profiles (gender, race, ethnicity, nationality, ages, etc.) of all team members? - We don't keep records of personal information of our employees


That's it for now.

Not sure if you've received questions from other vendors, but we'd love to see those, with your answers, as well - if possible.

Thank you very much!
<PERSON><PERSON><

activities.subject: Exclusive Invitation to Participate in XYZ's climate Interview
activities.body:
Dear Lissa,​

Over the past 24 years of working with organizations like yours, we have learned the impact internal and external climates have on our clients doing the work to support inclusion within their organizations. These past few years have truly been filled with change, directional shifts, and future uncertainty. We understand the importance of being a true partner and are excited to announce our exclusive initiative to support our stakeholders by conducting a comprehensive climate interview and survey. The goal of the survey will be to assess how the mindsets and systems within organizations have influenced organizational climate over the past few years and impacted inclusive workplaces. The information we collect from the interview and survey will be treated with utmost confidentiality and the key takeaways will be shared with all selected participants. Based on the key takeaways, we will be sharing relevant resources, developing new content, providing action steps, and offering opportunities to learn and collaborate with peers. 

Please select the time that works best for a 30-minute interview: <URL>

Thank you for considering this opportunity. We look forward to your participation and serving as a continued resource to you and your organization.

activities.subject: New XYZ Spotlight: Neurodiversity Inclusion in the Workplace
activities.body:
Hi Andrés,​

I hope this message finds you well. We’re excited to introduce our latest timely training session, Spotlight on Neurodiversity Inclusion in the Workplace. This 75-minute virtual session, structured similar to our library of spotlights on various communities, is designed to offer valuable insights into the experiences of neurodivergent colleagues and provide practical strategies for fostering an inclusive workplace.

In this session, you’ll:
Learn the terminology and models to better understand neurodivergent experiences. Gain insights into the shared cultural experiences of neurodivergent individuals. Acquire actionable strategies to create an inclusive environment for neurodivergent team members. This course not only dives into the definitions and experiences of neurodivergent people but also helps you build an inclusive culture where every neurological difference is respected and celebrated.

Would you be open to discussing how this training can enhance your team's approach to inclusivity? We’d be happy to schedule a meeting in the next week to explore this further.

Looking forward to hearing from you.

activities.subject: RE: Building a Culture of Inclusion workshop

I'm sorry for the addl email - I forgot to ask, when would you like this session to take place? Did you have a date range in mind? Thanks again!

activities.subject: Building a Culture of Inclusion workshop
activities.body:
Good morning, <PERSON> and happy Friday!

Again, thanks so much for reaching out to us for inclusion training, we really appreciate and would very much look forward to it.

We have variations of the Building a Culture of Inclusion workshop, depending on the audience. Will the ~90 people be all managers, or a mix of roles (individual contributors and managers/leaders)? Or is it a group of people managers/leaders only?

Also, how much time can you give us for the workshop? Is two hours too long?

We can deliver the session virtually or in person.

A two hour session delivered in English, off the shelf (no customizations), with one facilitator will cost:

Virtual: $6,000
In person: $10,000 (assume in <LOCATION>?)

Delivery in <NRP> will also involve translation costs - I can look into about how much that would be.  I will add probably around $2-$3k to the cost.

Thanks so much!
<PERSON><PERSON><

activities.body:

I hope you're doing well! Thank you for getting back to me about the workshop inquiry.

I appreciate your help in clarifying the workshop details. There was a slight misunderstanding about the workshop name. Based on your suggestion, "Building a Culture of Inclusion" sounds like the workshop we're interested in.

To give you more information:

  1.  Workshop Goals: We hope to learn how to make our workplace more inclusive and welcoming.
  2.  Who's Coming: We want the workshop to benefit everyone on our Finance team, no matter their role or level.
  3.  How Many: While we're still figuring out the exact number, we expect around 90 people to attend.
  4.  How We'd Like to Do It: We're happy to do the workshop online, but if it's possible to do it in person, we'd like to explore that, too. Could you provide an option to provide the workshop in Spanish?

I hope this helps! Feel free to let me know if you need more information or if there's anything else I can do.

Thanks again for your help!

activities.subject: Essential Guide to Dialogues about <LOCATION>-Palestine
activities.body:
Hi Andrés,​

We know that world events impact us in many ways, and that we don’t stop being who we are when we to go to work. With the ongoing <LOCATION>-Palestine conflict, we thought it would be helpful to provide you with a structure and process for having this type of dialogue. We wanted to send you this Essential Guide to Dialogues about <LOCATION>-Palestine: wanted%20to%20send%20you%20a%20quick%20note%20to%20let%20you%20know%20that%20we%20know%20that%20many%20workplaces%20have%20been%20talking%20about%20and%20affected%20by%20the%20Israel-Palestine%20conflict.%20We%20also%20know%20that%20world%20events%20impact%20us%20in%20many%20ways,%20and%20that%20we%20don’t%20stop%20being%20who%20we%20are%20when%20we%20to%20go%20to%20work.%20In%20case%20you%20or%20any%20of%20your%20colleagues%20is%20interested%20in%20a%20structure%20and%20process%20for%20having%20this%20dialogue,%20I%20attach%20the%20recently%20published%20Essential%20Guide%20to%20Dialogues%20about%20Israel-Palestine,%20put%20out%20by%20the%20organization%20Essential%20Partners.%20%20It’s%20excellent.%20%20The%20bulk%20of%20this%20guide/resource%20is%20about%20how%20to%20set%20up%20such%20a%20dialogue%20–%20including:, put out by the organization Essential Partners: <URL> It’s excellent. 

The bulk of this guide/resource is about how to set up such a dialogue – including:
The difference between dialogue and debate The importance of communication agreements (some really good ones included – please see bottom of p. 6/top of p. 7) Logistics (how, where, what) Structures for reflection, speaking & listening (the Go-Round; the Intentional Pause; Reflect, Write, Respond) Preparing for the dialogue as a facilitator (lots of support provided!) Participant intervention tips (in-depth and valuable) A sample agenda Dialogue prompts (they offer a few sets of prompts, depending on what your audience and context is – please see the one on p. 20 which is designed for the purpose of ‘better understanding different perspectives’: This dialogue guide is a great complement to our two brand new workshops: Spotlight on the Muslim Community in the <LOCATION> and Spotlight on the Jewish Community in the <LOCATION> - one-hour interactive, deep-dive workshops are focused on the experience of being a member of these communities, and aim at highlighting their experiences, influences, values and rich cultures. 

☪️Spotlight on the Muslim Community (1-hr): Explores the complexities of being <NRP> in <LOCATION> and the simultaneously varied and shared experiences and worldviews of <LOCATION>’s <NRP> community. In this session, we unpack the concepts of culture versus religion and discuss current issues and events impacting the <NRP> experience and perspectives. Best practices for allyship and countering bias in the workplace will be shared. 

🔯Spotlight on the Jewish Community (1-hr): Introduces participants to key historical and social/cultural events that shape this community, as well as the cultural values and practices that influence the <NRP> experience. The session will also unpack stereotypes, debunk myths, and address antisemitism and its impact in the workplace today. We share best practices for supporting and providing allyship to our colleagues with the community, and how to counter antisemitic bias and microaggressions. 

If you’re interested in talking further about scheduling these vital learning opportunities, please reply to this email and we can set up a meeting.

activities.subject: REGISTER FOR FREE PREVIEW: Spotlights on the <NRP> & Jewish Communities in the <LOCATION>
activities.body:
Hi Andrés,​

As part of our ongoing commitment to fostering cultural understanding and promoting inclusion, we’re excited to announce an upcoming no-cost session previewing our two new programs: " Spotlight on the Jewish Community in the <LOCATION>" and " Spotlight on the Muslim Community in the <LOCATION>." The preview will take place on May 29th, 2024 from 2-3pm ET / 1-2pm CT.

These two additions to our Spotlights library were carefully designed and vetted by interculturalists and culture-expert members of the <NRP> and <NRP> community. Facilitated by two cross-cultural expert facilitators (one a member of the community and one ally), the Spotlights provide participants with valuable insights into the histories, values, experiences, and influences that shape each of these distinct cultures, and deliver an insightful and nuanced understanding of the <NRP> and <NRP> experiences in <LOCATION> - dispelling misconceptions and fostering empathy. These sessions do not explain or resolve current geopolitical events, do not advocate particular points of view or debate history, and like all of our Spotlights, aim to build cultural competence and understanding.

The Spotlights helps participants:

  *   Explore factors that have shaped the lived experiences and cultural values of the community in the <LOCATION>, including shared experiences and common influences.
  *   Recognize the depth and diversity of the community in the <LOCATION>
  *   Discuss historical and contemporary prejudice against the community.
  *   Explore strategies to support and be an ally to your colleagues and the community at large.
In our preview we’ll demonstrate sample content from both Spotlights, show you the agenda for each, and answer your questions.

REGISTER FOR THE SPOTLIGHTS PREVIEW:
Wednesday, May 29th, 2024 from 2-3pm ET / 1-2pm CT Register Here<<URL>>

We believe that these Spotlights can be valuable tools which, in conjunction with other elements of your DEI infrastructure, work towards de-polarization and enhancing participants’ ability to engage meaningfully with individuals from these backgrounds.

We're looking forward to seeing you there!

activities.subject: Introducing Our New Cross Cultural Learning Partner Program
activities.body:
Dear Andrés,​

I hope this message finds you well. At XYZ, we are always striving to innovate and provide the most impactful solutions for fostering Diversity, Equity, and Inclusion within organizations. With that commitment in mind, we are excited to introduce our newest training program: The Cross Cultural Learning Partner (CCLP).

What makes our CCLP program stand out from traditional DEI training programs? It’s designed to offer a more personalized, in-depth, and continuous learning experience. Here’s how:
Collaborative Learning: Unlike typical trainings where participants learn individually, CCLP pairs each participant with a learning partner that is culturally different in a significant way. This partnership encourages mutual support and shared growth, making the learning process richer and more effective. The cultural differences between partners offer real, lived scenarios that can be explored through open communication. Extended Engagement: While most DEI sessions are limited to just a few hours, our CCLP program spans 6 to 12 months. This extended timeframe allows for a deeper exploration of cultural competencies, continuous learning, and the opportunity to apply and reflect on insights over time. Real-World Scenarios: CCLP moves beyond hypothetical situations by integrating your unique experiences into the training. This makes the learning more relevant and directly applicable to the challenges and opportunities within your organization. Measurable Growth: Understanding your progress is key to effective learning. CCLP includes pre- and post-assessments, enabling participants to track their development and gain clear insights into how much they’ve grown throughout the program. We believe that our CCLP program offers a transformative approach to DEI training, and we would love to explore how it can benefit your team or organization. If you’re interested in learning more or setting up a time to discuss further, please don’t hesitate to reach out.

Looking forward to connecting!

Each of these sessions provides practical strategies for teams to work more cohesively in today’s diverse environments.

Whether your goal is to drive engagement, inclusion, or cultural literacy, our <LOCATION> are a flexible resource that can be tailored to fit your organization’s unique goals.

Take a look at our Miniworkshop Sessions Overview: <URL> where you'll see the breadth of topics we cover (we can custom-build one for you too!).

We’d love to discuss how these sessions could align with your 2025 learning goals.

Looking forward to connecting!

activities.subject: Commemorating Juneteenth & Its Legacy
activities.body:
Dear Andrés,​

Many employers are planning to recognize <LOCATION> this year to celebrate this significant date in <NRP> history. 

<LOCATION>, a federal holiday celebrated annually on June 19th, marks the completion of emancipation of enslaved <NRP> in <LOCATION>, and symbolizes freedom, resilience, and the ongoing struggle for equality.

We believe that it's crucial to take the opportunity to reflect, learn, and engage in meaningful conversations about <LOCATION> and its importance to our employees and clients. To help you facilitate this dialogue, we have developed a one-hour session on this topic.

Our virtual workshop, Understanding <LOCATION> and Its Legacy, has the following objectives:
Explore <LOCATION>’s historical context, its significance in <NRP> history, and how it has evolved over time. Understand how many organizations have historically exploited the holiday. Explore ways in which individuals and organizations can commit to supporting and advocating for <NRP> communities beyond designated months or holidays. We also invite you to sample our “Commemorating Juneteenth” microlearning via this link: <URL> It will remain open and available for you until May 31st. Just enter your email address and name, and you’ll get access.

Understanding the roots of this holiday and its lasting impact is an important element for fostering empathy, awareness, and inclusion. Bringing colleagues together to engage in this opportunity to learn about history and progress has a positive impact in the workplace.

If you’re interested or have any questions, please reply to this email and we can set up a meeting.

Overview of our Spotlight Series: 
The Muslim Community – suggested delivery date, January (Muslim Heritage Month) (2 facilitators: 1 Cultural Insider & 1 Ally) Black/African Community – suggested delivery date, February (Black History month) (1 Facilitator) Women in Leadership – suggested delivery date, March (Women’s History Month) (1 Facilitator) The Jewish Community – suggested delivery date, May (Jewish Heritage Month) (2 facilitators: 1 Cultural Insider & 1 Ally) Being an Ally for the Asian American Community – Suggested delivery date, May (AAPI Heritage month) (2 facilitators: 1 Cultural Insider & 1 Ally) The LGBTQ+ Community – suggested delivery date, June (Pride Month) (1 Facilitator) Persons with Disabilities – suggested delivery date, July (Disability Pride Month) (1 Facilitator) The Hispanic Community – suggested delivery date, September (Hispanic Heritage Month) (1 Facilitator) Indigenous People in <LOCATION> – suggested delivery date, October (Indigenous Peoples’ Day) or November (Native American Heritage Month) (2 facilitators: 1 Cultural Insider & 1 Ally) U.S. Veterans Community – suggested delivery date, November (Veterans’ Day) (1 Facilitator) U.S Generations – suggested delivery date, December, April or August (1 Facilitator) Special bundle pricing available for full rollouts. activities.subject: Introducing Our New Cross Cultural Learning Partner Program
activities.body:
Hello Andrés,​ 

I hope you're doing well. I wanted to follow up on my previous email regarding our new Cross Cultural Learning Partner (CCLP) program, as I understand things can get busy. 

To quickly recap, the CCLP program is an innovative and personalized DEI training designed to foster deeper cultural understanding and sustained growth. The Intercultural Development Inventory (IDI) Assessment is a crucial tool within the CCLP program, helping participants not only identify where they are in terms of intercultural competence but also guiding them through the phases of development. Here's how it elevates the training experience: 
Understanding Key Developmental Phases: Throughout the program, participants will navigate various phases of intercultural development, progressing from a primarily monocultural perspective to a more inclusive intercultural viewpoint. This understanding is essential for fostering inclusive environments and navigating cultural differences effectively. Targeted Growth: By taking the IDI assessment at the beginning of the program, participants establish a clear baseline of where they currently stand in their intercultural development journey. We follow up with post IDI assessments as well conducted at the end of the program. This allows us to clearly measure the progress they've made, highlighting the growth in their ability to navigate and understand cultural differences more effectively over the 6-12 month program. We’d love to set up a time to discuss how the how the IDI assessment and the CCLP program can be implemented to meet your team’s needs. Please let me know what week works best, and I can send over some times to connect. 

Looking forward to your response.

activities.subject: Another quick followup from our Tues mtg
activities.body:
<PERSON>, <PERSON> and <PERSON>'re looking forward to continuing our conversation on the 28th.

In the meantime, attached is an overview of XYZ.

We've been involved in many projects that involve upskilling around gender-related cultural competence and inclusion. But I wanted to specifically mention that we did a project for management consulting firm where we ran various focus groups (plus a couple of interviews) of women of color and women with intersectional identities, to identify and solve for organizational barriers to inclusion, belonging, engagement and retention.  Some of the themes we encountered will not be surprising to you:

  *   Career advancement system is biased and inefficient for many <NRP>
  *   Paying "diversity taxes" influences workload and engagement/belonging
  *   WOC cover important parts of who they are at work
  *   Women of color struggle to find mentors, advocates, champions
  *   WOC crave for people who understand their experience, therefore supportive networks tend to be other WOC
  *   WOC wish there was more transparency/openness around reporting and discussing DEI data
  *   Challenges or issues unique to intersectional identities are often disregarded
  *   WOC often face microinequities/microaggressions at work

Take care and talk soon!
<PERSON><PERSON><

activities.subject: Elevate Engagement and Collaboration in 2025 with XYZ’s <LOCATION>!
activities.body:
Hi Fabrice,​

As you look ahead to 2025, we’re excited to introduce XYZ’s lineup of <LOCATION>—a series of 75-minute dynamic, interactive virtual trainings designed to foster engagement, support effective collaboration, and enhance intercultural competence across your organization. These sessions delve into key areas such as inclusive leadership, building cultural competence, collaborating across generations, and neurodiversity inclusion in the workplace. Each of these sessions provides practical strategies for teams to work more cohesively in today’s diverse environments.

Whether your goal is to drive engagement, inclusion, or cultural literacy, our <LOCATION> are a flexible resource that can be tailored to fit your organization’s unique goals.

Take a look at our Miniworkshop Sessions Overview: <URL> where you'll see the breadth of topics we cover (we can custom-build one for you too!).

We’d love to discuss how these sessions could align with your 2025 learning goals.

Looking forward to connecting!

activities.subject: Missed Our Neurodiversity Spotlight Preview? Watch the Recording!

We’ve heard from other attendees that the session proved to be a catalyst for rich conversations in their organizations, and we're thrilled with the engagement and insights shared.

If you missed the live session—or want to revisit key moments—you can now access the recording!

Spotlight on Neurodiversity in the Workplace: <URL>

This recording is a great resource to:
Catch up on what you missed if you were unable to attend. Share with decision-making leaders and colleagues who couldn’t attend. Reflect on ways to foster more inclusive environments for neurodivergent talent. We believe that this preview will inspire deeper conversations within your team. Let us know if we can connect with you on scheduling sessions for your organization or if you'd like to learn more about our other award-winning, cost-effective training or consulting solutions.

Schedule a Meeting: <URL>

Looking forward to connecting with you!

activities.subject: Get Ready for Hispanic Heritage Month with XYZ's Spotlight Bundle Offer!
activities.body:
Hi Nissa,​ 

I hope all is well! As you are planning out end of summer initiatives, as well as, strategizing for the next quarter and year, I wanted to share some of the ways we support our clients when it comes to culture focused education initiatives. Below I’ve listed an overview of the type of rollout we see when clients purchase our various Community Spotlight Bundles. Our rollouts are flexible based on your budget. I would like to schedule time with you to learn more about how we can best partner and answer any questions, I’m happy to help! 

Overview of our Spotlight Series: 
The Muslim Community – suggested delivery date, January (Muslim Heritage Month) (2 facilitators: 1 Cultural Insider & 1 Ally) Black/African Community – suggested delivery date, February (Black History month) (1 Facilitator) Women in Leadership – suggested delivery date, March (Women’s History Month) (1 Facilitator) The Jewish Community – suggested delivery date, May (Jewish Heritage Month) (2 facilitators: 1 Cultural Insider & 1 Ally) Being an Ally for the Asian American Community – Suggested delivery date, May (AAPI Heritage month) (2 facilitators: 1 Cultural Insider & 1 Ally) The LGBTQ+ Community – suggested delivery date, June (Pride Month) (1 Facilitator) Persons with Disabilities – suggested delivery date, July (Disability Pride Month) (1 Facilitator) The Hispanic Community – suggested delivery date, September (Hispanic Heritage Month) (1 Facilitator) Indigenous People in <LOCATION> – suggested delivery date, October (Indigenous Peoples’ Day) or November (Native American Heritage Month) (2 facilitators: 1 Cultural Insider & 1 Ally) U.S. Veterans Community – suggested delivery date, November (Veterans’ Day) (1 Facilitator) U.S Generations – suggested delivery date, December, April or August (1 Facilitator) Special bundle pricing available for full rollouts. We’d love to connect to share additional resources with you. Let me know what week works best for you and I’ll send over some times. 

Have a great week!

This session will offer invaluable insights and practical strategies for fostering a more inclusive work environment, particularly for neurodivergent team members. Here’s what you can expect to learn:
Key definitions, models, and vocabulary that will help your team better understand the experiences of neurodivergent colleagues Exploration of shared cultural experiences and challenges that neurodivergent individuals often face in the workplace Proven strategies to create an inclusive environment where all neurological variations are respected and celebrated Practical inclusion skills you can apply immediately to make your workplace more welcoming to neurodivergent team members Whether you're looking to enhance your organization’s intercultural competence or create a more inclusive and supportive environment, this session provides a great opportunity to build understanding and take actionable steps toward fostering true inclusion for all.

activities.subject: Get Ready for Hispanic Heritage Month with XYZ's Spotlight Bundle Offer!
activities.body:
Dear Fabrice,​

As Hispanic Heritage Month approaches, now is the perfect time to celebrate and deepen your organization's understanding of the <NRP> community's rich history, culture, and contributions. At XYZ, we are excited to offer our Spotlight on the Hispanic Community, designed to educate and engage your teams in meaningful conversations during this important time. This Spotlight session is available both in English and Spanish.

Our Spotlights are one-hour, interactive, deep-dive workshops that focus on the experience of being a member of these communities, and contribute to building cultural competence, inclusion skills and a culture of belonging throughout the firm.

In addition, we are running a special offer on our Spotlight Bundle, which includes a total of 11 Spotlight sessions. As your teams plan for their 2025 initiatives, our Spotlight Bundle offers an excellent opportunity to ensure a focused and consistent effort to highlight and educate employees about various communities that make up their peers. Whether you're looking to enhance your DEI initiatives or simply want to keep the conversation going, we feel this bundle is a valuable resource for your organization.

Here’s are the names of the other 10 Spotlight sessions: The Jewish Community, The Muslim Community, Black/African Community, Women in Leadership, Being an Ally for the Asian American Community, The LGBTQ+ Community, Persons with Disabilities, Indigenous People in <LOCATION>, U.S. Veterans Community, and U.S Generations.

I’d love to schedule some time to discuss how our Spotlights can align with your goals and enrich your team's understanding of the <NRP> community and beyond. Let me know what week works best for you and I can send over some times to connect.

Looking forward to hearing from you!

activities.subject: Proposal from XYZ for June 11th session
activities.body:
Importance: High

Hi <PERSON> and <PERSON>,
Thanks for sharing your goals regarding increasing capability around inclusion skills within Strategy& leadership.

For the 1-hour session on June 11th during your Partners meeting in <LOCATION>, we propose a session called "Elevate Performance with Intercultural Competence" that will:

  *   Introduce intercultural competence and explain why it's a crucial skill for inclusive leaders
  *   Help participants see how intercultural competence can be applied to optimize collaboration, coaching, and developing people
  *   Provide a practical framework for navigating differences in productive ways
  *   Allow participants to apply the framework using scenarios provided in the content or scenarios they bring with them to the session from their own experience.

Participants will leave the workshop recognizing that operating with intercultural competence at Strategy& increases the likelihood that people feel heard, accepted, and connected - which sets the conditions for improved team performance.

Please see attached proposal for both virtual and in-person options.

If you all would like us to deliver the session on 6/11, we would have to move very quickly in order for us to meet your expectations.  I know we have a meeting in the books for Monday, which is great. If we could have a decision by Monday (or earlier!), that would be ideal. It's still a much tighter timeframe than is typical, but probably doable. We communicated with our <LOCATION>-based facilitator as soon as we finished our last meeting, but do you happen to have the timeslot  for this particular session?

activities.body:
Hi Fabrice,​

I hope this message finds you well. We’re excited to introduce our latest timely training session, Spotlight on Neurodiversity Inclusion in the Workplace. This 75-minute virtual session, structured similar to our library of spotlights on various communities, is designed to offer valuable insights into the experiences of neurodivergent colleagues and provide practical strategies for fostering an inclusive workplace.

In this session, you’ll:
Learn the terminology and models to better understand neurodivergent experiences. Gain insights into the shared cultural experiences of neurodivergent individuals. Acquire actionable strategies to create an inclusive environment for neurodivergent team members. This course not only dives into the definitions and experiences of neurodivergent people but also helps you build an inclusive culture where every neurological difference is respected and celebrated.

Would you be open to discussing how this training can enhance your team's approach to inclusivity? We’d be happy to schedule a meeting in the next week to explore this further.

Looking forward to hearing from you.

activities.note_body: 5/14/24 Discovery Call NotesPwC participants: <PERSON>, Partner, Strategy & National Leader, PwC CanadaXYZ: RP, AlisaPre-call <PERSON> (requests from emails, other knowledge)Referred by <PERSON> from BCG – Fabrice says “I can give you the context and color when we speak. I look forward to speaking with you.”PwC Canada110-year history, 7,700+ partners and staff are located coast to coastAudit and assurance, tax, deals, and consulting targeting solutions for cybersecurity, privacy, financial crime, workforce of the future, finance transformation, value creation, strategic reassessment and cost optimization. CALL NOTES:Joined PwC 2 years ago, came from BCG and IBMIn Montreal, my role is pan CanadianIn 2014, PwC acquired Booz & Company (changed its name to “Strategy&”)In <LOCATION> grown organically, verticallyWe have 75 ppl (22 women), including 14 partners (2 women) in this Strategy Canada groupSeeking help with gender – has done surveysDid performance reviews, we have an HR person there who participates in all the assessments. Similar to BCG process (RP: CDC – Career Development Committee, was BCG’s process).Worried about growth of female talent. We studied the performance eval data and what came out was that, for women, there is a bigger concentration within the average vs. in excellent / outstanding. [RP1] We can’t argue about quality of female talent bc 22 is a pretty significant number and performance s/be closer to a normal distributionIs there bias? Not sureAre there ERGs? Not in this <LOCATION> bc we’re considered too <URL>ople not being super empathetic around differences, managing diversity. I got through quite a few trainings at BCG (2007-2019). We were taught about the differences between genders. Caring and connectivity. Most of the partners haven’t experienced <URL>st of us know about the theories and concepts, but not about the differences. We need more in the room, role plays, <URL> root cause performance review process, or is it before the perf reviews, in the day to day work?·         We had UB training right before the review process btw.·         Some of the behaviors I’ve seen are ‘cowboyish’. For example there was this male partner: he’s educated, etc. but made a comment to a woman partner:  ‘so now you’re going back to your kids?’Must function differently to connect with and work with <URL>ercultural competenceOur work involves high intensity sprints – managing stress, people react differently, people cry.·         (RP didn’t get to say: we need to be okay with that. That’s one way women (and many men!) express their emotions, and even though it might make you uncomfortable we need to stretch.·         Just like women for decades have had to adapt to more male behaviors like slamming fist on table, raising voice, playing golf, drinking.I’m the end client but I need other folks, HR, I report to the head of consulting in <LOCATION>, to get on board.We’d want to understand the process.We’re finishing our FY at end of June. Give me a couple of weeks.I’m in <LOCATION> but most of Strategy team is in <URL><PERSON> asked about their metrics. Fabrice: gender parity metrics but at the Consulting level. What I’m worried about is bare bones – like hiring, esp at the more senior level. And growing and retaining women. How do we address inclusion and belonging? We also don’t want to engage in reverse discrimination.RP: we’d Look at engagement survey data, conduct interviews or focus groupsRP: What’s the difference between Strategy and consulting? Grown a lot in 2022-23. We’ve been stagnant in the last year, consulting has been hit a little hard. We’re part of Consulting, but we have our own thing – like Platinion or Gamma, separate legal entity. In <LOCATION> in the <LOCATION> we’re part of consulting (‘advisory’). I was one of the two <LOCATION>’s that started Platinion. I loved the firm.RP notes:·         We need to set the stage for people to be open to listening to the issues, and to engage in adaptations.·         People need to see their perspectives as cultural – not as ‘this is the best way to work and women need to adapt’.We don’t see <LOCATION> as an extension to the <LOCATION> – even through we’re based here we’re sensitive that we need to have our <LOCATION> cultural lens <URL><PERSON> post call debrief: usually these things are driven by women so it’s great that he’s driving this <URL>xt steps:·         Send them info about XYZ, consulting projects, building IC and practice based trainings·         Include some things that we didn’t get to tell him [RP1]Why? How is performance assessed? What gets ‘excellent’ points?

5/28/24 CALL NOTESStrategy&/PwC Part: <PERSON> (only stayed for 20 min), Nissa ShariffXYZ Part: <PERSON>, <PERSON>, leads D&I for Strategy& - goes in 3x a week·         <PERSON> into 3 sections, worked in <LOCATION> in the pastEffective leaders and consultants develop a range of styles and skillsDo they have input from internal people already? Not reallyCoaching solution?  CCLP?Develop something that works for S&Nissa – D&I lead and also leads recruiting for S&·         Because if we only bring 2 women to final round, the probability of them going to the case interview is low likelihood, so how do we open the pipeline to get more diversity in there? This is one thing we’re working on, but not what we need help with right now.·         Another partner who leads the performance appraisal process, we get on these calls listening to appraisals, we give live feedback (when someone says ‘she’s too quiet’, ‘whiny’ we speak up – “But does she have a perspective?” These are not appropriate adjectives to use.  Calling these out.·         We need help with coaching skills – shining the spotlight for example. Are male leaders shining the spotlight on women? Are they coaching everyone the same way (the way they would coach men)? Do we need to teach them?  ·         How do we encourage everyone to self-advocate? (RP: do we need to tweak the system such that self-advocating is not as vital to success?)Nissa- we don’t have a lot of surveys, bc PwC does a lot of surveys already.<PERSON>: we need a workshop – cultural differences. We’ve never had that.RP: IDI assessment?Fabrice: We want practice, like with role playing. Scenarios that involve giving feedback on a specific project for example. RP: DIN model <URL>e cases – one is more immediate, partner session on June 11th , one hour of the time to this topic. Hands on role <URL>en later, Part 2 project – This collaboration can be more project based, like maybe an assessment. We’d want to include partners, directors, and senior managers. Provide them with timelines and costs.About our organization:Last couple of years has added to the gender imbalance.We’re sitting as 3 industry verticals as opposed to the one S& team.S& has biweekly huddles, the partner and director groups get together to talk about common things. But attendance has dropped, ppl aren’t showing up bc reward and assessment feels more vertically aligned.But end of year performance assessments are done a group of 3 – the whole S&. So there’s a disconnect between how we’re showing up day to day (as one section) vs. during appraisals (as one organization).Fabrice is trying to bring us together more often as one cohesive S& firm.Fabrice said he didn’t think any of the men realized that no women were ranked as ‘tier 1’, all the chair 1 rankings this year were white men. We have non-white men, we have women at S&.There’s nothing that I can point to at CRT’s that was done inappropriately, but it’s manifesting itself at CRTs (Career Round Table is the name of the end-of-year performance <LOCATION> female partners in S& (<NRP> and <PERSON>). <PERSON> is not seen as Strategy&, in a day to day way. Strategy and CRT’s are attended by <PERSON> and 10 or 11 <URL>le partners - half are new, others – I don’t think it’s the old school behaviors (they’re in 40s/early 50s Gen X) but I think that there’s still some inherent bias.  For example, I made partner remotely. 10 days after my kid came out of the NICU, I was on the call advocating for myself to achieve partnership. I’ve always been in this position, for better or worse I’ve normalized this <URL> do we open everyone’s eyes that there is a bit of a problem and here are some very tactical ways for how this is manifesting on your team. For example, when we get on calls, there’s usually 5 min of banter among the men mostly, while people are joining. Men make well intended derogatory comments towaredds each other, teasing each other (“are you really working or are you…” automatically alienates the women  - bc that’s not our style and we’re excluded. The men haven’t behaved inappropriately towards the women, but the outcome is, women are not <URL><PERSON> done nothing that’s a compliance violation it’s beyond, it’s about inclusion. I can help you write 4 or 5 scenarios. I don’t want this to be a check the box exercise or a compliance exercise – I want this to be a cultural conversation for us.If someone isn’t speaking a language fluently, concerns arise.  What kind of situation helps make it better? Is it better to know employee beyond the project, but for example there was a woman who got engaged. A woman got engaged, but men didn’t mention it to me when she came up. Remind them the benefits of relationship building and how that has a big impact on how people show up on projects. The downstream impacts of our behavior. Vignettes would be helpful. It’s not about censoring yourself or changing who you are.June 11 – in <LOCATION>?  And it’s about talking about how men and women are socialized – and about having conversations. Women feeling safe and comfortable bringing things up and men feeling safe asking questions and making <URL>thing documented, but I have had chats with more vocal ppl managers who are coming up to the senior ranks. Something is wrong but I can’t tell what it is.RP thoughts:·         How do women feel about bringing issues up? Are there potential negative consequences?·         Also, what’s considered excellent performance? Is it generally creating the conditions for women being the gender that has to stretch?·         Behaviors: Interrupting, jumping in, assertiveness, deviating from female stereotypes, behaviors associated with power and competitiveness, microaggressions (video in Leading with Conscious Inclusion is all about gender related <PERSON>’s)·         It would have been great to do IDI’s and use this hour to do a group debriefPracticality within the one hour – what’s going on that day aside from this? How does this fit in?Next steps:·         Get back to them with what we can do in one hour·         Tell them what else we could do – as a larger initiative·         Is there an opp to do more than an hour?·         RP: What are the behaviors that are typically rewarded for promotion and making partner?

You don't often get email from <EMAIL_ADDRESS><mailto:<EMAIL_ADDRESS>>. Learn why this is important<<URL>>
EXTERNAL MAIL: USE CAUTION BEFORE CLICKING LINKS OR OPENING ATTACHMENTS. ALWAYS VERIFY THE SOURCE OF MESSAGES.
Dear Tisha,​

Many employers are planning to recognize <LOCATION> this year to celebrate this significant date in <NRP> history.

<LOCATION>, a federal holiday celebrated annually on June 19th, marks the completion of emancipation of enslaved <NRP> in <LOCATION>, and symbolizes freedom, resilience, and the ongoing struggle for equality.

We believe that it's crucial to take the opportunity to reflect, learn, and engage in meaningful conversations about <LOCATION> and its importance to our employees and clients. To help you facilitate this dialogue, we have developed a one-hour session on this topic.

Our virtual workshop, Understanding <LOCATION> and Its Legacy, has the following objectives:

  1.  Explore <LOCATION>’s historical context, its significance in <NRP> history, and how it has evolved over time.
  2.  Understand how many organizations have historically exploited the holiday.
  3.  Explore ways in which individuals and organizations can commit to supporting and advocating for <NRP> communities beyond designated months or holidays.
We also invite you to sample our “Commemorating Juneteenth” microlearning via this link<<URL>>. It will remain open and available for you until May 31st. Just enter your email address and name, and you’ll get access.

Understanding the roots of this holiday and its lasting impact is an important element for fostering empathy, awareness, and inclusion. Bringing colleagues together to engage in this opportunity to learn about history and progress has a positive impact in the workplace.

If you’re interested or have any questions, please reply to this email and we can set up a meeting.

activities.subject: Essential Guide to Dialogues about <LOCATION>-Palestine
activities.body:
Hi Tisha,​

We know that world events impact us in many ways, and that we don’t stop being who we are when we to go to work. With the ongoing <LOCATION>-Palestine conflict, we thought it would be helpful to provide you with a structure and process for having this type of dialogue. We wanted to send you this Essential Guide to Dialogues about <LOCATION>-Palestine: wanted%20to%20send%20you%20a%20quick%20note%20to%20let%20you%20know%20that%20we%20know%20that%20many%20workplaces%20have%20been%20talking%20about%20and%20affected%20by%20the%20Israel-Palestine%20conflict.%20We%20also%20know%20that%20world%20events%20impact%20us%20in%20many%20ways,%20and%20that%20we%20don’t%20stop%20being%20who%20we%20are%20when%20we%20to%20go%20to%20work.%20In%20case%20you%20or%20any%20of%20your%20colleagues%20is%20interested%20in%20a%20structure%20and%20process%20for%20having%20this%20dialogue,%20I%20attach%20the%20recently%20published%20Essential%20Guide%20to%20Dialogues%20about%20Israel-Palestine,%20put%20out%20by%20the%20organization%20Essential%20Partners.%20%20It’s%20excellent.%20%20The%20bulk%20of%20this%20guide/resource%20is%20about%20how%20to%20set%20up%20such%20a%20dialogue%20–%20including:, put out by the organization Essential Partners: <URL> It’s excellent. 

The bulk of this guide/resource is about how to set up such a dialogue – including:
The difference between dialogue and debate The importance of communication agreements (some really good ones included – please see bottom of p. 6/top of p. 7) Logistics (how, where, what) Structures for reflection, speaking & listening (the Go-Round; the Intentional Pause; Reflect, Write, Respond) Preparing for the dialogue as a facilitator (lots of support provided!) Participant intervention tips (in-depth and valuable) A sample agenda Dialogue prompts (they offer a few sets of prompts, depending on what your audience and context is – please see the one on p. 20 which is designed for the purpose of ‘better understanding different perspectives’: This dialogue guide is a great complement to our two brand new workshops: Spotlight on the Muslim Community in the <LOCATION> and Spotlight on the Jewish Community in the <LOCATION> - one-hour interactive, deep-dive workshops are focused on the experience of being a member of these communities, and aim at highlighting their experiences, influences, values and rich cultures. 

☪️Spotlight on the Muslim Community (1-hr): Explores the complexities of being <NRP> in <LOCATION> and the simultaneously varied and shared experiences and worldviews of <LOCATION>’s <NRP> community. In this session, we unpack the concepts of culture versus religion and discuss current issues and events impacting the <NRP> experience and perspectives. Best practices for allyship and countering bias in the workplace will be shared. 

🔯Spotlight on the Jewish Community (1-hr): Introduces participants to key historical and social/cultural events that shape this community, as well as the cultural values and practices that influence the <NRP> experience. The session will also unpack stereotypes, debunk myths, and address antisemitism and its impact in the workplace today. We share best practices for supporting and providing allyship to our colleagues with the community, and how to counter antisemitic bias and microaggressions. 

If you’re interested in talking further about scheduling these vital learning opportunities, please reply to this email and we can set up a meeting.

(for IDI assessment/group debrief) (COO direct reports)2nd Group is about 25 individuals (IDI assessment/BCI pilot, no debrief) (folks from different departments) (goal is to pilot BCI)Patricia mentioned talking with RP about whether the 2nd group should do the IDI's?Next steps: Updated proposal, while <PERSON> checks about <URL>e week of the 8th we can all regroup. Meeting set for the 9th at 3pm EST.

5/22/24 <PERSON>'s CALL NOTESDate: 5/22/2024Client: Link Logistics (Blackstone portfolio company)Client Participants & roles: <PERSON>, <NRP> Manager DEIXYZ <PERSON>, <PERSON>, and SarahTopic/Purpose Inclusive Leadership TrainingPre-call <PERSON> (requests from emails, other knowledge)-vendors for inclusive leadership training (web form submission)Call notes:-Peggy <PERSON> comes from Google and prior to that PwC.-D&I practitioner network is where she heard of us from AAPI identifiers and informal-370 People managers training (field workers, to corporate functions.-Org is very new to DEI. Only have one 2 hour session annually prior to this.-Field is very Homogenous.-There has not been any people training and any inclusive leadership.-Building very foundational skills, along with mico aggression.-Based in <LOCATION> but all time zones.-There was hyper growth and finally are stable and are building consistency.-New people managers are new and want foundation .Next steps:Building a Culture of InclusionIDI, need to identify cultural appetiteAction step 2Behavior boostsBuiding a Culture of Inclusion vs Leading Inclusively to see proof of concept.Outline of roadmap for building a culture of inclusionWould love to see leading with culture of inclusion.40-50 people per <URL>gust is remote month for the company (training by end of year)<US_DRIVER_LICENSE> roll-outBudget will take a few weeks to <URL>al Estate Commercial <URL>day is what they use microlearning.

Call Notes 5/22/24Attendees: <PERSON>: <PERSON>, <PERSON>, <PERSON> ·         Quick round of intros·         <PERSON> is the senior DEI Manager at Link Logistics, started 6 months ago·         Why now? Nothing Major. Company is 5 years old but headcount has gone up a lot so it has to do with growth!·         <PERSON> started by going over some trainings they've done. (mandated baseline DEI training from Workday on microaggressions for property managers, having to do with customer facing interactions)·         300 <LOCATION> based managers roughly looking for training (closer to 400) 370 ish, at beginning of their learning journeys. Many are new people managers bc of exponential growth Link has been experiencing.·         Referral- DEI practitioner group on LinkedIn·         Focus should be on inclusive leadership.·         <PERSON> mentioned that the field of RE is very homogenous·         <PERSON> mentioned BCI for leaders, IDI's (BCI with and w/o IDIs), offered her a comp IDI for <PERSON> only. Decide who will take the IDI, doesn't have to be everyone.·         <PERSON> also recommended following BCI with Leading With Conscious Inclusion with Behavior Boosts·         <PERSON> asked about customization, <PERSON> explained the difference between tailoring and customization. <PERSON> wanted to see examples of customization with other comml real estate companies we've worked with·         <PERSON> wants an outline of what BCI and LCI·         Also wants pricing for both in person and virtual. Also pricing with IDI vs not, and additional costs for building out new content/customizations.·         Budget? Calendar by quarter. Reforecasting, no budget set for now, looks like she's going round pricing companies.·         Timeline? By end of year. No timeline, No urgency. <PERSON> mentioned ideally <US_DRIVER_LICENSE> or <LOCATION>.·         Leading with conscious inclusion·         <PERSON> for these virtual facilitations? <PERSON> mentioned 40 at first. maybe up to 50·         <PERSON> asked, any clients in commercial retail state? <PERSON> mentioned she can look into what she can share.

Call meeting 6/20/24Attendees: PeggyXYZ Attendees: <PERSON>, RP & PedroPeggy mentioned she would like to test pilot some training before going company wide. They just recently had a situation where a training didn't go as well as they thought it would. Leadership now wants to test things before moving forward. Demo would be on Thursday in July. 18th or 25th. <PERSON> mentioned we would demo the 4 hour session (BCI for leaders) in 1.5 hours. Team is interested in the assessment as well. <PERSON> asked the difference between 1 on 1 IDI debriefs vs a group debrief? RP explained the differences on how the results are handled. <PERSON> asked: Group debriefs, would it make sense for only those folks that actually work together? RP mentioned its best for people who share the same goal/company <URL><PERSON> mentioned 1.5 hours is the most time they can offer, and they would like an overview of both <URL><PERSON> mentioned their leaders have taken a mandatory D&I training, e-learning: What is D&I and why does it matter? Some folks have been to a virtual facilitated session, but not much training after that.RP asked what would be the best topics that resonate the most during that 1.5 hour demo. <PERSON> mentioned what RP included in the proposal. Also as appreciating differences in their teams. Also U.B as well. Get leaders to think about leading <URL><PERSON> asked what's covered in an 1.5 hour for the IDI group debrief? connect with RP about behavior boosts that we could perhaps share with <PERSON> too?Send <PERSON> invite to DEIB conference, complimentary pass. RP gave an overview of what the IDI group debrief covers as well as BCI 4 hour version.

6/20/24 Call NotesXYZ part: <PERSON>, RP, PedroClient part: <PERSON>:<PERSON> took the IDI on Tuesday – RP asked her to contact the IDI email to schedule the 1-1 <URL>e back from offsite in May – in person. A DEI training went sideways – women’s network, didn’t land very well. activities.body:
Hi Anna,​ 

I hope all is well! As you are planning out end of summer initiatives, as well as, strategizing for the next quarter and year, I wanted to share some of the ways we support our clients when it comes to culture focused education initiatives. Below I’ve listed an overview of the type of rollout we see when clients purchase our various Community Spotlight Bundles. Our rollouts are flexible based on your budget. I would like to schedule time with you to learn more about how we can best partner and answer any questions, I’m happy to help! 

Overview of our Spotlight Series: 
The Muslim Community – suggested delivery date, January (Muslim Heritage Month) (2 facilitators: 1 Cultural Insider & 1 Ally) Black/African Community – suggested delivery date, February (Black History month) (1 Facilitator) Women in Leadership – suggested delivery date, March (Women’s History Month) (1 Facilitator) The Jewish Community – suggested delivery date, May (Jewish Heritage Month) (2 facilitators: 1 Cultural Insider & 1 Ally) Being an Ally for the Asian American Community – Suggested delivery date, May (AAPI Heritage month) (2 facilitators: 1 Cultural Insider & 1 Ally) The LGBTQ+ Community – suggested delivery date, June (Pride Month) (1 Facilitator) Persons with Disabilities – suggested delivery date, July (Disability Pride Month) (1 Facilitator) The Hispanic Community – suggested delivery date, September (Hispanic Heritage Month) (1 Facilitator) Indigenous People in <LOCATION> – suggested delivery date, October (Indigenous Peoples’ Day) or November (Native American Heritage Month) (2 facilitators: 1 Cultural Insider & 1 Ally) U.S. Veterans Community – suggested delivery date, November (Veterans’ Day) (1 Facilitator) U.S Generations – suggested delivery date, December, April or August (1 Facilitator) Special bundle pricing available for full rollouts. We’d love to connect to share additional resources with you. Let me know what week works best for you and I’ll send over some times. 

Have a great week!

activities.subject: Short, high-impact sessions on the <NRP> and the Jewish Experiences in the <LOCATION>
activities.body:
Hi Lissa,​

We’re thrilled to shared that we’re launching two brand new Spotlight sessions aimed at highlighting the experiences, influences, values and rich cultures of the <NRP> and <NRP> communities in the <LOCATION>

Our Spotlights are one-hour, interactive, deep-dive workshops are focused on the experience of being a member of these communities, and contribute to building cultural competence, inclusion skills, and a culture of belonging throughout your organization. 

☪️Spotlight on the Muslim Community (1-hr)
This session explores the complexities of being <NRP> in <LOCATION> and the simultaneously varied and shared experiences and worldviews of <LOCATION>’s <NRP> community. In this session, we unpack the concepts of culture versus religion and discuss current issues and events impacting the <NRP> experience and perspectives. Best practices for allyship and countering bias in the workplace will be shared. Session objectives:
Explore factors that have shaped the lived experiences and cultural values of the <NRP> community, including shared experiences and common influences Recognize the depth and diversity of the <NRP> community in the <LOCATION> Discuss <NRP> sentiment (especially since 9/11) and its impact on the <NRP> community Explore strategies to support and be an ally to your <NRP> colleagues and the community at large 
🔯Spotlight on the Jewish Community (1-hr)
This session introduces participants to key historical and social/cultural events that shape this community, as well as the cultural values and practices that influence the <NRP> experience. The session will also unpack stereotypes, debunk myths, and address antisemitism and its impact in the workplace today. We share best practices for supporting and providing allyship to our colleagues with the community, and how to counter antisemitic bias and microaggressions. Session objectives:
Explore factors that have shaped the lived experiences and cultural values of the <NRP> community, including shared experiences and common influences. Recognize the depth and diversity of the <NRP> community in the <LOCATION> Discuss the current state of Antisemitism and its impact on the <NRP> community. Explore strategies to support and be an ally to your <NRP> colleagues and the community at large. Below are one-pagers for each session, that you may share with your stakeholders. 

Other Spotlights that you may consider for 2024:
Being an Ally for the Asian American Community (May, AAPI Heritage Month) Spotlight on the LGBTQ+ Community (June, LGBTQ+ Pride Month) Spotlight on Persons with Disabilities (July, Disability Pride Month) Spotlight on U.S. Generations (April, August, December, anytime) Spotlight on the <NRP>/Latinx/e Community (September, Hispanic Heritage Month 9/15-10/15) Spotlight on Indigenous People in <LOCATION> (October, Indigenous Peoples’ Day or November, Native American Heritage Month) Spotlight on the U.S. Veterans Community (November, Veterans’ Day) If you have any questions and would like to connect, please let me what days work best and I’ll send over some times.

activities.subject: Get Ready for Hispanic Heritage Month with XYZ's Spotlight Bundle Offer!
activities.body:
Dear Lissa,​

As Hispanic Heritage Month approaches, now is the perfect time to celebrate and deepen your organization's understanding of the <NRP> community's rich history, culture, and contributions. At XYZ, we are excited to offer our Spotlight on the Hispanic Community, designed to educate and engage your teams in meaningful conversations during this important time. This Spotlight session is available both in English and Spanish.

Our Spotlights are one-hour, interactive, deep-dive workshops that focus on the experience of being a member of these communities, and contribute to building cultural competence, inclusion skills and a culture of belonging throughout the firm.

In addition, we are running a special offer on our Spotlight Bundle, which includes a total of 11 Spotlight sessions. As your teams plan for their 2025 initiatives, our Spotlight Bundle offers an excellent opportunity to ensure a focused and consistent effort to highlight and educate employees about various communities that make up their peers. Whether you're looking to enhance your DEI initiatives or simply want to keep the conversation going, we feel this bundle is a valuable resource for your organization.

Here’s are the names of the other 10 Spotlight sessions: The Jewish Community, The Muslim Community, Black/African Community, Women in Leadership, Being an Ally for the Asian American Community, The LGBTQ+ Community, Persons with Disabilities, Indigenous People in <LOCATION>, U.S. Veterans Community, and U.S Generations.

I’d love to schedule some time to discuss how our Spotlights can align with your goals and enrich your team's understanding of the <NRP> community and beyond. Let me know what week works best for you and I can send over some times to connect.

Looking forward to hearing from you!

activities.subject: Introducing Our New Cross Cultural Learning Partner Program
activities.body:
Dear Lissa,​

I hope this message finds you well. At XYZ, we are always striving to innovate and provide the most impactful solutions for fostering Diversity, Equity, and Inclusion within organizations. With that commitment in mind, we are excited to introduce our newest training program: The Cross Cultural Learning Partner (CCLP).

What makes our CCLP program stand out from traditional DEI training programs? It’s designed to offer a more personalized, in-depth, and continuous learning experience. Here’s how:
Collaborative Learning: Unlike typical trainings where participants learn individually, CCLP pairs each participant with a learning partner that is culturally different in a significant way. This partnership encourages mutual support and shared growth, making the learning process richer and more effective. The cultural differences between partners offer real, lived scenarios that can be explored through open communication. Extended Engagement: While most DEI sessions are limited to just a few hours, our CCLP program spans 6 to 12 months. This extended timeframe allows for a deeper exploration of cultural competencies, continuous learning, and the opportunity to apply and reflect on insights over time. Real-World Scenarios: CCLP moves beyond hypothetical situations by integrating your unique experiences into the training. This makes the learning more relevant and directly applicable to the challenges and opportunities within your organization. Measurable Growth: Understanding your progress is key to effective learning. CCLP includes pre- and post-assessments, enabling participants to track their development and gain clear insights into how much they’ve grown throughout the program. We believe that our CCLP program offers a transformative approach to DEI training, and we would love to explore how it can benefit your team or organization. If you’re interested in learning more or setting up a time to discuss further, please don’t hesitate to reach out.

Looking forward to connecting!
